item.title: [PIPELINE-1304] Things To Do: Version 1.2
item.description:
Version 1.2 aims to build traffic and content by development of a 'holistic' widget approach for use accross other sites on the BBC.

Product integration work will build on and enhance the existing BBC module widgets that have been created for old stack, Forge and News.

We will also release an API for other BBC online services to provide a feed of activities from the Things To Do domain. The API will be available via a public URL, but data will only be made available to other services using a hashed key. This work was originally scoped in PIPELINE-853.

item.title: [PIPELINE-1301] Class Clips: Decommission realmedia from old-stack 'Learning Zone, Class Clips' site
item.description:
Site affected:

  • BBC - Learning Zone - Class Clips
    http://www.bbc.co.uk/learningzone/clips/

Current status:

  • Live on the old-stack

Proposed change:

  • The 'Class Clips' site serves video in Real Media, Windows Media and Flash formats.
  • This project plans to remove all Real Media from the site, thus removing the dependancies on ramraider and a number of legacy borg routes (and the media clip storage).
  • OTG would like to turn off ramraider at the end of January 2012 (c/o Diluk De Silva, Craig Taylor)
item.summary: Class Clips: Decommission realmedia from old-stack 'Learning Zone, Class Clips' site

comments.comment:
We don't think we'll need to follow the decommissioning process for this. No content which is available now will be removed, however the format which it can be consumed in will change.

We'll redirect users to the content in Flash, and update the site FAQ to explain our decision here.

More details of risk mitigation in the D&D document (attached) (coming soon).

Hi Ali,

Once you're ready for us to look at this please move to Ready for Pipeline and assign to me. I'll try and run it past our guys earlier just incase they have any questions.

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Ali,

I review this with Platform Engineering and they are happy for this to progress to Development so long as:

  • You are in touch with Craig Taylor (OTG TA), as there are certain things which need to be considered
  • You need to go through the Decommissioning checklist https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Decommissioning+checklist and determine which - if any - of the steps are applicable. For now just see if you can update steps 1-15. I'll copy the checklist into this ticket for you and I need you to update it. Please contact me if you've questions, or maybe Julian Tovey (K&L PM) who has already run through this may be a good contact for you - once you've updated the checklist I'll move this to Development

Rgds,
Siobain

Decommissioning checklist

Task Complete?
i). Ensure there is editorial buy-in on the concept of switching systems off.  
ii). Ensure there is management buy-in on the concept of switching systems off.  
iii). Ensure all applications have defined lifespans, and inception plus decommissioning dates.  
iv). Ensure all applications have an entry in the service catalogue.  
v). Notice there is a cause to decommission.  
vi). Raise a Pipeline Decommissioning ticket.
vii). Acknowledge the arrival of a request for decommissioning.
viii). Technical Decommissioning Review meeting with all stakeholders including TPM, Pipeline, Monitoring, Operations, Information & Archives. Once ALi has updated this checklist Siobain can touch base with OTG parties
ix). Consensus reached on fate of application and pages using the application - flattening pages, switching off monitoring, what about dependent systems, etc.  
x). Consensus reached on what response is served from an HTTP request. A 404 page? A holding page?  
xi). Consensus reached on what users will see.  
xii). Technical Project Manager creates decommissioning plan and adds it to Pipeline decommissioning ticket.  
xiii). Technical Project Manager creates back out plan and adds it to Pipeline decommissioning ticket.  
xiv). Technical Project Manager performs discovery.  
xv). Technical Project Manager raises testing tickets.  
xvi). Testers test decommissioning plan on Forge Stable environment, or appropriate other environment (Ext Dev etc).  
xvii). Testers test back-out plan on Forge Stable environment, or appropriate other environment (Ext Dev etc).  
xviii). TPM sign off on testing, and back out of change process.  
xix). TPM raises an CIS ticket to action the decommissioning.  
xx). TPM raises a MONitoring ticket to shut down monitoring of the application.  
xxi). TPM raise an OPS ticket to action the decommissioning.  
xxii). TPM raise an FSRV ticket to decommission flagpole - if required.  
xxiii). Monitoring Team switch off monitoring for application. Suppress alerts.  
xxiv). Ops Engineers execute OPS ticket and decommission application.  
xxv). If required, flatten pages.  
xxvi). If required, archive code.  
xxvii). If required, Information and Archives rescue and archive historic documents and records.  
xxviii). 24 / 7 Operations check decommissioning hasn't broken other systems.  
xxix). TPM and developers check decommissioning hasn't broken other systems.  
xxx). If decommissioning FAILS, Ops Engineers execute back-out plan.  
xxxi). Information & Archives archive relevant material.  
xxxii). TPM Organise a post decommissioning (wash up) meeting.  
xxxiii). TPM Update Service Catalogues as to current status of project.  
xxxiv). TPM Raise a Jira ticket (Jira project) to archive documentation.  
xxxv). Everyone attends the post decommissioning (wash up) meeting.  
xxxvi). TPM closes the PIPELINE decommissioning ticket.

Hi Ali,

Should this be in Feasibility? If not can you please move it to Ready for Pipeline and update the checklist so that Siobain can move this to Development status as she states above.

Thanks,
Tara.

I'll review this today and move it into "Ready for Pipeline".

If there is any work required by OTG, I'll flag it up then, although I don't think there will be - and this can hopefully be done by my team alone.

Ali

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: 03/02/2012 - Product team have okeyed this course of action. No progress on completing the decommissiong checklist on this yet. I'm hoping to free up time in the next week to do this. In the mean time, each of the content teams has been asked not to publish any new realmedia as a matter of course. Pushing the date back 2 weeks to accommodate for this.

item.title: [PIPELINE-1273] Webwise Release 3.1
item.description:
We are putting together an offering for Safer Internet Day in early February 2012 and WebWise will be the main destination for parents wanting to help keep their children safe online. CTA's will come from Radio 5 Live and BBC One's Inside Out.

Safer Internet Day is on Tuesday 7th February 2012

More broadly a more customisable homepage and horizontal navigation will allow us to more elegantly and engagingly present specific content.

Specific details are avilable on the Planning Board > Fix Version 3.1 https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/WEBWISE

Major Features

  • Video embedding on homepage
  • Introduction of content panel on homepage
  • Update to permitted type of links from homepage
  • Update to horizontal navigation (sub-category)

Architecture & Volumetrics
There is no Architectural Change. https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Technical+design

There is a change to expected Volumetrics. For this TX & CTA volumetrics could rise from 56,000 UU's p/w to between 80-90,000 UU's p/w
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Volumetrics

Further details on CTA in response to Andrew Hutson's comments 3.1.12

?R5 live 7.2.12
2 x packages 6am - 9am
Mentions during 9am - 10am phone in
1 x package 4pm - 7pm
1 x package 7pm - 10pm

?Inside Out / BBC One - regional version 6.2.12 OR 13.2.12
?Credit squeeze at 8pm
The total audience for Inside Out averages 3.3m viewers for all programmes.

For 5 live:

Breakfast Show - 6am 9am: 1.35m listeners - 2 CTAs anticipated
Breakfast Phone-in - 9am-10am : 0.5m listeners - CTAs throughout
Drive - 4pm - 7pm: 1m listeners - not confirmed
Sport - 7pm - 10.30pm: 800k listeners - not confirmed

comments.comment:
Linked exemption tickets and existing tickets from original Webwise release e.g. loadtest, cis, mon, rbreview

Have created new loadtest ticket for loadtest team to review - may not need new tests.

Ian Myatt has approved concept document and given the tight timescales I want to make sure we move to build as soon as we can - 3rd party developer currently in progress. Discovery & Definition doc to be completed in tandem with moving to 'ready for pipeline'.

We shouldn't need a Tech review as nothing has changed in this respect

Thanks

Luke

Please can this be reviewed for moving to Build.

There is no change to Technical Architecture

Thanks

Luke
Siobain to review with Platform Eng and Frameworks.

Hi Luke,

I reviewed this with Platform Eng (Mark G) and Frameworks (Nikos):
-They guys agreed I could move this to DEVELOPMENT without a tech review
-You should probably be be looking for EMP flagpoles/how to know if their service is down, how it will affect your service. I would suggest you raise a new MON ticket just to check this

I've emailed Yasser (the Capacity Mgr) to see if the increase in volumetrics require any action (copy of email below). Although LOADTEST outcome may show if this is sufficient.

Rgds,
Siobain

Email to Yasser

Hi Yasser

I have raised a loadtest ticket and our developer has confirmed the end points will be the same as for the original webwise loadtesting. https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-613

The results for the origianl testing are https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Webwise_220311

Luke

Feedback from Zoe Breen re: Volumetrics

Have looked at site traffic data for Give an Hour, the peak of users in one hour was 7,000 - this means that there are almost 2 users per second arriving on the site.

I think it would be fair to expect that Safer Internet Day traffic will behave similarly. As far as I know we will have 3 CTAs on 5 live on 7th Feb and further CTAs on Inside Out (BBC One) on either 6th or 13th Feb (up to 9 regional transmissions).

Will contact Yasser

On 03/01/2012 15:13, "Luke Tagg" <Luke.Tagg@bbc.co.uk> wrote:

Hi Yasser, Siobain

I have updated the Loadtest ticket raised for the Webwise 3.1 release https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-613

This contains details of the expected uu's per second - see comments.

Please let me know if this changes the planned loadtesting - thanks

Luke

---------------------------------------------------------------------
On 03/01/2012 15:43, "Siobain Collins" <Siobain.Collins@bbc.co.uk> wrote:

Hi Tamsin,

I assume this is your call. If theres anything you need from me please advise.

Hi Andy (Hutson),

Please see note the CTA/Txs in this pipeline ticket https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-1273 and also mentioned in https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-613?focusedCommentId=748401&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_748401

Rgds
Siobain

Coming into this a little cold, but if I understand correctly, there are at least two CTA's planned for this site, one on R5live and the other on BBC one? Do you have any details on the form the CTA will take? (Is it the main theme of the programme, is the audience encouraged to interact with the programme via the web site, or is it simply a URL trail at the end of an item / show?)

It's important to test against an accurate peak, and a per-hour peak is insufficient when talking about a TV CTA, which tend to result in very short sharp spikes in traffic. You need to get a per-second estimate, and test against this - if the volume is expected to be high, we may need to consider rate limiting.

What's the largest spike Web Wise has dealt with to date?

Further details on CTA in response to Andrew Hutson's comments 3.1.12

  • R5 live 7.2.12

2 x packages 6am - 9am
Mentions during 9am - 10am phone in
1 x package 4pm - 7pm
1 x package 7pm - 10pm

  • Inside Out / BBC One - regional version 6.2.12 OR 13.2.12
  • Credit squeeze at 8pm

The total audience for Inside Out averages 3.3m viewers for all programmes.

For 5 live:

Breakfast Show - 6am 9am: 1.35m listeners - 2 CTAs anticipated
Breakfast Phone-in - 9am-10am : 0.5m listeners - CTAs throughout
Drive - 4pm - 7pm: 1m listeners - not confirmed
Sport - 7pm - 10.30pm: 800k listeners - not confirmed.

Awaiting detail on largest spike to date. Please can we have some advice on the estimate for per-second traffic?

Apologies, I don't know what you mean by "package".

I suspect the one to worry about is the Inside Out CTA. There are two dates mentioned - is it the same programme being broadcast in different regions on each date? Is it just the credit squeeze that mentions the site or is there a CTA during the programme itself?

The LabUK folks have some experience estimating peak traffic following on-air CTA's. It can be difficult to do this with any degree of accuracy, but it's important we have confidence in the application being able to cope with peak demand without putting the platform at risk.

I have contacted Karen Slavick (LabUk) to get some info regarding this.

We have some updated info on analytics from Webwise from Zoe Breen also. I've added attachments and have added to the loadtest ticket too.

Package just means a news piece about something, sometimes involving an interview, case study or similar. We anticipate with Inside Out that the call to action will be in the form of a credit squeeze / voice over at the end of each programme. There are 11 Inside Out programmes that go out across the UK in the same slot at 7.30pm on a Monday evening.

Please find a spreadsheet of WebWise site traffic from the old Sage system. As you can see the highest number of weekly Unique Users was in w/c Oct 17 2010 (this corresponds with First Click CTAs on broadcasts). See also newer figures from iStats - there is a peak of 9440 uniques a day on 26 May 2011 which I believe corresponds to Adult Learners' week.

Hoping to get some further info from LabUk too.

Existing testing for Webwise https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Webwise_220311 used a value of 10 (I'm assuming this is 10 uu's per second)

CTA info from LabUk : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/labuk/CTA+Conversion+Rates and https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/labuk/Load+Test+Results

I haven't been able to get hold of Karen yet, but found these on Confluence. I've added these to the Loadtesting page too.

Can you advise what needs to happen next as I'm not sure how we get to the best estimate around expected usage

Hi all,

We have had feedback on an estimate of traffic following CTAs experiences from LabUk team. In summary neither CTA (radio or tv) would produce much more than 1 SU - depending what the offer is, Inside Out could produce 3-5 SU

Please let me know if anything is required for loadtesting

---Original Message---
From: Mike Orwell
Sent: 06 January 2012 13:15
To: Luke Tagg; Karen Slavick; Mark Landeryou; Joseph Coulson; Joseph Bell
Cc: Andy Gritton
Subject: RE: LABUK CTAs

Hi Luke,

It does depend a bit on the editorial offer of the CTA -

If it was something that was central to the thrust of the programme, or an intriguing question that people would like to answer for themselves (so they can participate in a debate etc.) then the uptake can be quite high.
For ancillary (additional information or 'you might be interested in...') tend to be much lower take-ups.

The editorial offer often defines the audience demographic as well - something youth skewed can take-off because of the greater tech literacy ( but the numbers on most BBC platforms are quite low).
Hitting the middle aged, broad interest heartland (aka The One Show audience) can get huge numbers in with the right associated editorial.

Credit squeezes perform quite poorly, no matter what.

Drivetime editorial discussion perform a bit better but people often aren't able to translate the CTA to a visit
(Radio sees less conversion because radio consumption is often done whilst doing something else ie driving, cooking etc TV consumption is more fertile ground for an onward digital journey)

I'd say neither CTA would produce much more than 1 SU - depending what the offer is, Inside Out could produce 3-5 SU. (The Big Risk Test had a credit squeeze on Bang! For 3 weeks and rarely achieved any more than that)

Hope that helps

Mike
Is any further action required from me before the release process can take place? Thanks, Zoe

Hi Zoe - I have got all info requested in both this ticket and the loadtesting ticket so we should be ok for move to Stage and subsequent loadtesting.

Will keep you informed on outcomes.

Assuming all ok, DESQ can then re-add their Webwise 3.2 update following this Webwise 3.1 go live 24.1.12

Thanks

Luke

item.title: [PIPELINE-1269] Bitesize: KS2 and Scottish 2nd Level
item.description:
Summary:

  • Migrate KS2 content out of Flip
  • Create new "Scottish 2nd Level" course in Bitesize
  • One consistent template (Caterpillar) across these 2 courses.

Details:

FLIP is being used by the Bitesize team to author and publish XML files. There are two business risks to FLIP that are the drivers behind the migration of Bitesize ro oXygen.

  • FLIP is due to be deprecated in 2011
  • Windows 7 does not support FLIP client.

We'll be migrating the existing KS2 content out of Flip and into the <oXygen/>+SVN workflow approved by OTAG.

We'll be tweaking the existing KS2 templates to allow us to adding a "Scottish 2nd Level".

Published pages will continue to be hosted on the old stack, but at a new location at /bitesize/ks2 and /bitesize/secondlevel.

comments.comment: Siobain to look at this and see how it relates/overlaps with parent ticket

Hi Ali,

Migrate KS2 content out of Flip: ACTION ALI: Please could you clarify where you are migrating Migrate KS2 content out of Flip, to? Is it to Oxygen (per PIPELINE-585)?

Create new "Scottish 2nd Level" course in Bitesize: This is ok, as it just looks like BAU

One consistent template (Caterpillar) across these 2 courses: This is ok, as it just looks like BAU

Rgds
SIobain

The KS2 content is being migrated into an Oxygen based production workflow (as per PIPELINE-585).

  • There's no significant change to public facing site - other than we're moving the content from /schools/ks2bitesize to /bitesize/ks2.
  • The profile of the audience is not changing.
Siobain to re-review with Platform Eng
Checking with Mark G whose going to take a quick look at PIPELINE-585 (Bitesize: Flip to Oxygen migration) and it's dependency PIPELINE-911 (Production facing SVN repository).

We'll be launching "Scottish 2nd Level" and "KS2" without the complete production workflow. We'll freeze all content production in these 2 courses/level until delivery of PIPELINE-911. In the meantime, the content is hosted in REPOAV.

I've discussed this with Robert Lee, who's agreed to chase the delivery of PIPELINE-911.

item.title: [PIPELINE-1250] knowledge and learning gamification
item.description:
BBC Knowledge and Learning (K&L) is planning a major strategy to embed learning into a very wide range of content across the BBC's web sites, and make learning as ubiquitous as search, news and the homepage. To accomplish this, K&L plans to build its offering around learning journeys through subjects, featurettes and 'Thing pages', a vision which will reshape content around different groups of users and focus K&L on user value. It has identified a number of factors in its current audience's usage of K&L sites, in particular poor cross-promotion between K&L content, utility as a key driver for users, formal learning as a barrier for users and a variety of playful behaviours which suggest that a playful approach towards learning may yield optimal results. Audience surveys have identified a range of user requirements which all reflect users' need for a playful, challenging and rewarding experience while learning. K&L plans to launch a number of learner tools, akin to apps, to be grouped around a user profile.

One of these learner tools, described informally as a 'Game of Me', describes
the mild use of games design mechanisms and other gamification techniques to incentivise and reward users' learning behaviour. K&L envisages a profound implementation of Games Grid to create meta-games that underpin the new K&L product.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Tender process to find suitable indie companies for the work

item.title: [PIPELINE-1249] Time Based Navigation
item.description:
Launching in late 2012, the Knowledge & Learning product will be a unified place for the BBC's factual and learning content, as well as being ubiquitous across BBC Online, creating journeys of learning across bbc.co.uk.

Timelines, including those contributed by users from their own lives and experiences, will provide a core means of serendipitous onward journey and become a recognisable motif of the K&L product and overall BBC Online service. This work is a combination of audience research, prototyping, and content piloting, to determine the right user proposition around timelines, and plan how K&L will deliver a truly pan-BBC Online new core feature, leading on behalf of the other 9 online products in this area.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: Green - currently in a tender process for companies to produce non audience facing prototypes

item.title: [PIPELINE-1243] Groundhog Enhancements
item.description:
Groundhog is the service that is used to extract and compile data from LabUK experiments to pass on to our partner scientists. The application runs scheduled jobs that extract data from a single experiment capturing participants who were active in a specified time period. Data must be managed in accordance with BBC governance policies at all times, so for example output is encrypted, participants are anonomised by removing personally identifiable information (each participant is given an anonomised key, and postcodes are narrowed to sector information only).

With this package of work, we plan to enhance functionality to address a set of shortcomings that have been identified:

  • Full extraction in a single job
  • Query number of participants that will be processed in a job
  • Extract data for participants who have completed more than one experiment
  • Improved interface to extractions
  • Output data in row wise format, rather than CSV
  • Extract set of email address of participants who have agreed to be contacted (for internal use only)

comments.comment: Please schedule teck kick-off, for the week of Jan 23. It can be done in a single meeting with the Experiment Builder teck kick-off.

Technical Architecture:
Technical design is not changing, except that we are adding a user-friendly interface. The technical diagram is here:

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/labuk/Groundhog+-+Technical+design

Volumetrics:
There is no change to volumetrics. Groundhog is used by a small group of BBC editorial staff (up to 10), and is generally used by only 1 at a time.

Siobain,

Would it be possible to schedule tech kick-off this week?

Thanks,
Karen

Siobain to review with Platform Eng Wed 25th Jan 2012

Karen, please:
1. Confirm your TA has signed the architecture off as containing no changes, from previously approved Lab Uk arch
2. Advise the attendees for the tech review and whether a conference bridge is required.

Rgds,
Siobain

1. Yes, Mark Landeryou has approved (he is acting as LabUK tech architect).
2. Just me and Mark Landeryou will be fine from our side. We're both in London.

Tech review meeting booked for Friday 27 January 2012 14:30-15:30, BC4 A3 M2 - Absolutely Fabulous
Required attendees: Siobain Collins; Karen Slavick; Mark Gledhill; Christopher Parker; Mark Landeryou
Optional attendees: Stephen Hunwick; Graham Lyons; Future Media OTG Monitoring Services; FM&T Service Managers; FM&T DD&O Change Management

Tech review meeting held Friday 27th Jan 2012, 2.30pm-3.30pm, BC4 A3 M2 (Absolutely Fabulous)
Attendees: Karen Slavick (TPM), Mark Landeryou <Mark.Landeryou (Developer, Lab UK), Mark Gledhill (Platform Eng), Rajesh Jha (DBA Team), Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager)

NOTES
-Aerian are the Indie developing this
-This is to make some changes to Groundhog, which extracts data for LabUK experiments. This is for use by Editorial staff
-This work is to improve what Groundhog does. This is driven by requests for enhancements from Editorial

CHANGES
Data extraction
1. Reduce memory footprint of Groundhog when doing large extraction
-Mark recommended you do as much as you can to optimise things on the DB side
-Volume of data will increase because at the moment processing is done in batches, one at a time. This will allow it to be run in one go - The impact is the job will access the DB for longer. If job breaks in middle, they re-schedule it and it'll start again and re-do the whole thing (or split it into two jobs)
-This should not cause performance problems for LabUK users, Editorial do not run this during the CTA peak
-Main LabUK data is stored in KV store
-ACTION: Send extract SQL statements to DBA team
-ACTION: Add information about the 'off' switch to the Run Book
2. Ability to query Number of participants that will be processed in a job - To query how may people done these experiments
3. Enable extractions of data for participants who have completed more than one experiment - Same as normal extract, but you'd expect a subset of data
-ACTION: Per (1) send DBA team the queries you are using
4.Groundhog should retry failures for calls to dependent services - BBC ID is stored in DB and when extraction is created a call is made to BBC ID to get users data (postcode, age, etc). To get this a call is made to BBC ID, if call fails, they want to re-try
User Interface
5. Create user-friendly interface to schedule extractions - Create a simple user interface to run extractions. Need to be cognisant that we are allowing people the ability to do something which will cause load and query the data - project team advised the users can already do this
6. Addition to 5
Data Output

8. Groundhog should not allow unencrypted dumps on live
9. Covert time to GMT instead of
10. Exclude from extraction data of participants with "deleted" flag - Show DBA team the queries for this
11. Groundhog should write postcodes for test users when extracting the participants file
12. Add 'last active' column to participants data extraction
13. Fix csv string escaping - Sometimes CSV output is broken because users my put data in results such as '/' or similar

PIPELINE ACTIVITIES

item.title: [PIPELINE-1242] LabUK Experiment Builder
item.description:
The Experiement Builder will be a robust, user-friendly tool that the LabUK editorial staff use to create and update the Experiment Definition File (EDF) for all future LabUK experiments.

Background:
Each LabUK experiment is configured and defined in a data construct known as the Experiment Definition File (EDF). The EDF is written & stored in JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) format which is accessed through the core LabUK API and is used to render experiment questions with standard widgets and to define parameters to calculate feedback.

An EDF can be created and edited with a simple text editor but due to its complexity the LabUK team developed a prototype editing tool called the Experiment Builder in the early days of the project to provide an interface for editorial staff to use.

This tool had many limitations. It could corrupt data and lacked effective validation. This caused numerous issues when developing experiments, and required ongoing FM developer support to fix errors in the EDF introduced by the tool. More issues were introduced with the release of the LabUK pal core v2 in August, making the tool virtually unusable for future experiments.

comments.comment:
I don't believe that we need loadtesting or CIS review for this piece of work:

1. This tool will only be used by BBC editorial staff who have been granted permissions, and that will be a maximum of 10 people at any time.

2. This tool does not give access to any sensitivedata. It is simply used to compose tasks and add variable sets for LabUK experiments.

Thoughts?
Please schedule teck kick-off, for the week of Jan 23 if possible. It can be done in a single meeting with the Groundhog Enhancements teck kick-off.

Hi Karen,

In order to review this with Platform Eng I need the Architecture (signed off by your TA) and the volumetrics.

Please also advise the attendees for the tech review and whether a conference bridge is required.

Rgds,
Siobain
Let's wait until I get back for this tech kickoff. I'll have the guys prepare everything while I'm gone.

Hi Karen,
Once you've got the arch diagram and volumetrics, please re-assign this to me and I'll set up the meeting. Enjoy the break.\
Rgds
Siobain

In this sprint, they intend to complete the ability to view, edit and save an experiement, and the ability to create, view, edit, and save tasks.

item.title: [PIPELINE-1222] Webwise 3.2 eAssessment Multi Question / Random Questions
item.description:
Project description [1]:This is an enhancement to the Webwise eAssessment site area. As part of the WebWise course, DESQ have developed an e-assessment which can be used to gain credits towards the ITQ offered by awarding bodies.

This proposal seeks to address the following issues:

As all multiple choice questions are drawn randomly from one large bank of questions, there is the chance that learners will get more than one question on some LOs (learning objectives) and no questions on other LOs.

Some of the awarding bodies have queried the validity of having one practice task per assessment sitting and that if a re-sit was requited, candidates would get the same practice task. This might infer that memory rather than understanding would then be tested.

Development by DESQ (Indie). DESQ PM Nick West

Confluence space needed? no (use space from Webwise PIPELINE-187)
Jira project needed? no using existing Webwise space

Product Owner = Zoe Breen
BBC Tech Arch = Robert Lee
TPM = Luke Tagg

*This is mainly a content improvment and therefore the only change required to the Webwise application is:*

The change that is required to the PAL app is to amend the XSLT/XML code for the page that launches the ActivEngine. The change will be to randomly choose one of 10 XML files that will define which set of content is used for the assessment. Currently only one XML file is specified per assessment. So, we will:

Amend assessment page xml to list the bank of separate instances by their ActivEngine xml. Eg internet.xml becomes internet1.xml to internet10.xml
Amend the page XSLT to take in all the xml and create a randomiser in either XSLT or JavaScript.

*There is no Architectural change or Volumetrics change*
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Technical+Design+WebWise+Course+2011
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Volumetrics
item.summary: Webwise 3.2 eAssessment Multi Question / Random Questions

item.title: [PIPELINE-1182] Class Clips
item.description:
Class Clips is an existing K&L proposition aimed at teachers offering access to approximately 15,000 clips of BBC content for use within the classroom.
At present, the clips are hosted and played out via a bespoke system and website. The key objective of this project is to build a new user interface utilising the iBroadcast media management system as the backbone and thus ensuring that the Class Clips proposition is on course to transition to the new K&L product.
This project will be run in parallel with an editorial managed initiative to review, expand and migrate the content offering into iBroadcast

Jira and Confluence spaces are being created

item.title: [PIPELINE-1175] K&L TLD Tombstoning, Moving and Deletion
item.description:
As part of BBC Online's public commitments under Putting Quality First it was decided that a number of TLD's would be reduced. These TLD's would either be deleted, tomstoned or moved under an archived area under an existing TLD. Working with Richard Smith and Gillian Clydesdale from Red Bee we will look to do this work through November 2011.

Process
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=42244041

DDO TA to confirm that htaccess that is going to be used is correct:
"ErrorDocument 404 /tld/index.shtml"

*Page 404s here http://vdev.national.core.bbc.co.uk/abolition/rats.shtml

http://www.bbc.co.uk/indiapakistan

comments.comment: Moving this ticket to "ready for pipeline" as we need to push this on ASAP.
Next action is for Chris Harrod and Siobain Collins to review the Red Bee process to see if anything additional is required to meet the new OTG decommissiong process.

Decommissioning checklist

# Task Comments Complete
1 Ensure there is editorial buy-in on the concept of switching systems off. Request came from I&A and Richard Smith
2 Ensure there is management buy-in on the concept of switching systems off. Covered in Red Bee process: Site Owners will be contacted Red Bee
3 Ensure all applications have defined lifespans, and inception plus decommissioning dates. N/A These sites pre-date concept

8 Technical Decommissioning Review meeting with all stakeholders including TPM, Pipeline, Monitoring, Operations, Information & Archives. Meeting held 23 Nov, attendees noted in comment dated 25th Nov (on this ticket)
9 Consensus reached on fate of application and pages using the application - flattening pages, switching off monitoring, what about dependent systems, etc. Decision made, see description
10 Consensus reached on what response is served from an HTTP request. A 404 page? A holding page? Decision made per https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=42244041
Julian to confirm this is ok with Craig Taylor 		Julian
11 Consensus reached on what users will see. As per 10.
12 Technical Project Manager creates decommissioning plan and adds it to Pipeline decommissioning ticket. Complete
13 Technical Project Manager creates back out plan and adds it to Pipeline decommissioning ticket. Julian advised 21 Nov: Atos will take an archive copy of the TLD before deletion. They should then be able to reinstate this quite quickly if there are issues. Red Bee confirmed this would be the process.
14 Technical Project Manager performs discovery. Note: This is a req for you to confirm you've addressed all (if any) dependencies on these sites.
Julian advised there are no dependencies from these sites, there will be links to this site from other BBC sites. Ian Myatt & Chris sizemore have signed off 		*
15 Technical Project Manager raises testing tickets. N/A Julian will validate this
16 Testers test decommissioning plan on Forge Stable environment, or appropriate other environment (Ext Dev etc). Julian advised 21 Nov: N/A
17 Testers test back-out plan on Forge Stable environment, or appropriate other environment (Ext Dev etc). Per 13.
18 TPM sign off on testing, and back out of change process. Julian advised 21 Nov: Red Bee will seek sign off once the tombstone is in place and before final deletion of files from TLD. Julian
19 TPM raises an CIS ticket to action the decommissioning. Julian linked to CIS-410, as these are static old stack pages there should be no CIS implications. Siobain emailed Stephen Butler to advise of this
20 TPM raises an OPS ticket to action the decommissioning. Julian to raise an OPS 'FYI' ticket Julian
21 TPM raises a MONitoring ticket to shut down monitoring of the application. Julian to raise a MON ticket, consider any URL monitoring that needs to be removed e.g pagemon, urlmonitor, gomez. Victoria advised it's most likely for there to be pagemon on SIS sites Julian
22 TPM raise an OPS ticket to action the decommissioning. N/A Duplicate
23 Monitoring Team switch off monitoring for application. Suppress alerts. Following Action 21 (i.e. after turning off monitoring) check for and suppress any alerts which may be generated Monitoring
24 Livesite Ops execute OPS ticket and decommission application. N/A this will be actioned by Red Bee
25 If required, flatten pages. Covered in Red Bee process Red Bee
26 If required, archive code. Covered in Red Bee process Red Bee
27 If required, Information and Archives rescue and archive historic documents and records. N/A as request initiated from I&A
28 24 / 7 Operations check decommissioning hasn't broken other systems. N/A as it's believed that
  • these URLs have no dependencies
  • no pages/services are dependent on these URLs
29 TPM and developers check decommissioning hasn't broken other systems. Believed N/A per 28
30 If decommissioning FAILS, Livesite Ops execute back-out plan. If required Red Bee
31 Information & Archives archive relevant material. These sites have already been archived
32 TPM Organise a post decommissioning (wash up) meeting. Siobain will organise this, once Julian advises the Red Bee work has completed Julian & Siobain
33 TPM Update Service Catalogues as to current status of project. Add note to OPS 'FYI' ticket to request Change Mgmt update the Service catalogue Julian
34 TPM Raise a Jira ticket (Jira project) to archive documentation. Julian to investigate if there are any Jira spaces or documentation on Confluence, Gateway, TechNet, or other. If anything exists, raise a Jira 'Documentation' (DOCU) ticket and provide the location of information that requires archiving Julian
35 Everyone attends the post decommissioning (wash up) meeting. Per 32. Julian & Siobain
36 TPM closes the PIPELINE decommissioning ticket. Julian will close this ticket once the work is done Julian
37 NEW Site Owners Database should be updated. Julian to ensure this is part of the Red Bee process Red Bee
38 NEW Ensure Internet Approvals have signed this off (Tim Varley, Fiona Batson). Julian emailed 'internet.approvals@bbc.co.uk' and got sign off from Fiona Batson
39 NEW Update process to add cache control headers to htaccess files Julian to get Red Bee to do this Julian

Hi Julian,

Chris and myself reviewed this and have made a stab at the checklist, we can talk through it tomorrow.
Some other questions:
a. Will we see 404 errors?
b. What 404 page are you using for deleted sites

item.title: [PIPELINE-1173] La Mappa Misteriosa Release 1.1
item.description:
Following the La Mappa Misteriosa release in September 2011 and post review, there are a number of amends required. These are minor amends mostly to the presentation of the site and also updating flexibility of page elements allowing for greater editorial team control e.g. client xml files can control elements of the page such as enabling/disabling buttons.

These are non-architectural changes and will have no impact on the existing volumetrics. https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/itlangdrama/Technical+design

Post Go Live amends as part of 'warranty period' therefore no cost:

https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-42 - add promo box to home page to be enabled/disabled by editorial
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-27 - Review timings of interaction in episode 5
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-31 - Review timings of interaction in episode 1
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-37 - Amend punctuation of good luck message

Post Go Live improvements as part of 'new work' therefore incurring cost:

https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-38 - Review timings of end of episode 2
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-16 - Possible issue with ActivEngine scoring - it looks like this is actually two issues, problems with the weighting in the excersie XML files and the calculations we perform

https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-18 - Continue button behaviour inconsistent, We will add node to XML to enable continue button.
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-5 - In the top bar of the interaction we wnat the text 'Sign in' to change if the user is signed in. We need to add an extra node to the XML to allow for this.
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-23 - 'Styling' improvement required on Episode 3. We need to move the notes / coins position
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-40 - On the exercise page we need to add a 'Glossary' box. This is controlled by the exercise xml page and can be managed by editorial
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/ITLANGDRAMA-41 - On the syllabus page we need to add a print icon in all boxes. It exists in the 'Objectives' box but needs adding to the sections for the activities.

comments.comment:
Hi Luke,

Please could you clarify how you are going to give editors greater editorial control (e.g. will you use KV Store; deploy changes via RPMs).

Rgds,
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

La Mappa team control content and elements on the page using .xml files stored on downloads. The PAL application looks at these config files to determine what it should present to end user

Things like turning off the continue button using a node in the xml of <continuebutton> off </continuebutton>
It wouldn't need a new release / RPMs

Hope this helps

thanks

Luke

Hi just to confirm too, the XML flexibility isn't a new feature , they already edit XML files to Update the front end. We are just improving elements of this

Thanks

Luke

Luke Tagg
Technical Project Manager
BBC Knowledge & Learning

Sent from my iPhone

As you can see I don't think the changes in this release give rise to new Loadtest, CIS or MON tickets.

I have linked the existing ones

Thanks

Luke

Hi Siobain,

This is a minor set of improvements to La Mappa as described.

Please can you let me know if this requires new CIS, Mon or if we can use the existing as there isn't anything in the release that I think requires new CIS/Mon tickets.

This is also the case for Loadtesting - should I contact Tamsin to confirm that the existing Loadtesting sign off is still valid?

Thanks

Luke

Hi Luke,

Thanks for your statement regarding architecture and volumetrics. You can link to previous Load Test (as same volumetrics), CIS and MON tickets as you have, but it's you self certifying that these are will still be valid for the service once you release the changes per this ticket. If in doubt, please contact the associated teams if you need to check.

Please ensure you have an up to date run book and if there are only minor changes you can link your previous RBREVIEW ticket, otherwise you should raise a new one.

This will stay in RADAR for a couple days until I can run it past Platform Eng and Frameworks.

Rgds,
Siobain

Discussed with Rob Lee (TA) K&L

Agreed no need for new MON or CIS. Have linked existing. Have raised Loadtest ticket - more of a sanity check, as it's not thought we'll need this

Also spoke with Siobain 16.11.11

Please can this be moved to Development. Due for Stage 21.11.11

Thanks

Luke
Platform Eng and Frameworks agreed to move to Dev without a tech review required.

Hi Luke,

Based on your Status update this looks to have successfully deployed - as such I'm moving this to Production Under Warranty.

Please update your 'Actual Go Live Date'

Rgds
Siobain

item.title: [PIPELINE-1136] Things To Do: Metrics, Exports, Project user, Inline image editor
item.description:
This pipeline addresses the release of functionality to enable partner building:

Project User

A project user requires a certificate to access BBC Admin and is added by the user interface to 1 or more projects.

They can:

  • edit, change status or create activities for their project(s)
  • create activities which appear as "Created by the BBC"
  • edit, change status or create any locations
  • edit, change status of partners for their projects (s)
  • see approval queues / filter counts for their project(s) only

A project user cannot:

  • see any links in BBC Admin apart from Partners link
  • see any projects listed in partners area apart from those they are approved on
  • edit, change status of partners status on other projects
  • change the partners overall status

A project user doucumentation:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/BBC+Admin+Project+User

Exports

Exports has been descoped from this pipeline. Further investigations are needed to find a more suitable solution.

Metrics

The following metrics will produced for 'all ttd', projects, promotions, partner, bbc region with date range querying to enable us to see:

  • The number of activities appearing live on front end each day
  • The number of occurences live on front end each day
  • The number of activities and occurences submitted via TTD admin AND/OR added by each XML ingest partner each day
  • The number of activities and occurences expired each day
  • The number of activities and occurences not approved each day
  • the number of partners with live activities
  • the number of partners with no live activities

We are open to receiving these metrics in a different way e.g. by daily email if that makes this easier to implement.

Doucumentation:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/BBC+Admin+Metrics

BBC & Partner Admin: Inline image editor
We propose to implement an inline image editor for both the BBC and partner admins that will provide partners with an integrated method of editing images to meet the specified requirements.

Doucumentation:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=42243386

Technical architecture
There is no change to the technical architecture for these updates but have included for reference
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Technical+Architecture
item.summary: Things To Do: Metrics, Exports, Project user, Inline image editor

******
A project user is the same as BBC Admin (currently implemented behind admin.bbc.co.uk with SSL cert) but with restricted access.

The access is restricted with Zend ACL (currently implemented), the project user role has just been added to the XML: https://repo.dev.bbc.co.uk/pal/thingstodo/backend/ttdadmin/branches/aerian-trunk/webapp/conf/acl.xml

The rudimentary access restrictions are there to remove actions which the users wont need to use thus simplifying their user experience rather than for preventing potential damage / DPA issues. All project users are BBC staff.

Project users will be administered in the same way BBC Admin users are currently administered, with user information is currently stored in the TTD database. https://admin.stage.bbc.co.uk/thingstodo/activitymaker/users

Attendees:
Julian Tovey
Robert Lee
Ziad Dajani
Ben Poole (ben.poole@aerian.com)

Tom Hicks (tom.hicks@aerian.com)

Conference Number: 109 109

Cheers
Julian

Tech review booked for Wed 09 November 2011 15:30-16:3030, BC3 D5 M1 (Marilyn)

Required attendees: Siobain Collins; Julian Tovey; Robert Lee; Ziad Dajani; Mark Gledhill; Graham Lyons; ben.poole@aerian.com; andy.max@aerian.com; tom.hicks@aerian.com
Optional attendees: Future Media OTG Monitoring Services; FM&T Service Managers; FM&T DD&O Change Management; Christopher Parker; Stephen Hunwick

Tech review meeting held Wednesday 9th November, 15:30-16:30, BC3 D5 M1 (Marilyn)
Attendees: LONDON - Mark Gledhill & Ikenna Ibeanu (Platform Eng), Michael Mathews (Frameworks), Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager); ON CALL - Julian Tovey (TPM), Robert Lee (TA), Ziad Dajani (Product Mgr) ; Ben Poole & Andy Max (Indie company Aerian)

NOTES

  • The Things To Do site points TV and Radio audiences to activities run by BCC or partners. These often link to our existing sites. This is seen as an outreach to audiences.
  • The Changes are broken down into 3 Areas
    Project User
    -Currently, the only user type is BBC admin and they can use everything. The team wish to add Project User so that responsibility (e.g. for moderation) can be delegated
    -All project users are BBC Staff
    -Technical changes (Ben from Aerian) advised that email addresses are stored in the TTD DB
    -Mark G suggested that instead of using Admin Gateway, the project team could use the Production Gateway. This would make issuing certs easier (as they are auto issued to everyone with Reith access)
    -Mark G suggested that you look into the service called ACE managed by POD (Steve Foster) which manages access (not a show stopper)
    Exports
    -This is now de-scoped So Mark just provided some advice (at the end)
    Metrics
    -Requirement by editorial team to have metrics so that they can understand how many partners are using system, how many activities are generated for projects (e.g. Springwatch, Halloween, Christmas, BBC Regions)
    -Editorial will look at Activities (e.g. a walk) and the number of occurrences (i.e. how many times it happens)
    -Admin going in and getting stats, caching day by day
    -Cron job expects to run 9 queries, each taking 15ms, once a day overnight
    In-line image editor
    -Each activity has an image which partners upload. Editorial have received a lot of feedback as partners struggle to resize images. It is desirable to have the inline image editor
    -Michael Mathews asked if this is an API? Andy advised it will stay in the browser (use create url browser command)
    -The Browser storage doesnt have a limit
    -Image stays on hard drive and a reference to it on the hard drive is stored
    -Glow is only supported for new work, jQuery is supported and encourage to use that. Project need to think about migrating to jQuery. Rob asked if you can mix Glow and jQuery Michael advised there are pages with both but its not ideal . 1.6 is available, upgrade to 1.7 soon
  • General:
    -Front end public application users memcache, BBC Admin doesnt use Memcache
    -Https is not currently implemented except for static assets and their widget

PIPELINE CHECKLIST

  • Volumetrics
    o 100 Project users in total and unlikely to all be on the site at same time, infrequent use by project users
    o Traffic to public facing site initial volumetrics still stand for traffic to the site
  • LOAD TEST Previously tested to 100 SU. Still valid so none is planned. Raise a ticket explain the delta and link to previous load test and not the action to look at how widget is used
  • MON - Had considered monitoring for the user, but as they are all BBC staff. Link to previous Mon ticket and monitoring not required ticket
  • CIS - Raise a ticket. Particularly if you are using the ACL or expanding it they will be interested
  • RUN BOOK - Update your run book

ACTION
1. Project team to find a way to manage your tenants (volumetrics for News and Olympics)
2. Project team to contact DBA team lead, Christopher Parker with respect to the new table you require

MEETING OUTCOME: Move to DEVELOPMENT

Although Exports is now de-scoped from this ticket Mark Gledhill provided some advice for when the team wish to develop this:
-Need to be able to export information from the system to create newsletters, e.g.
Retrieve all email addresses for partners for spring watch or country file
Retrieve a list of all the partners who dont have any live activities at the moment may want to do a mail shot to them
-Internal reporting, maybe reporting back to project execs on how many activities are live over a period of time

Advice and Thoughts:
-Its not categorised as personal data, its seen business to business data all corporate information. To ensure its not personal data and agree it is business data
oInfoSec are interested in the security of your data, how you are extracting the email addresses, who has access to them, is it a shared in box
oIPC (Info Policy & Compliance) are interested in what you are doing with the data talk through with Rachael Ward from IPC (she can advise about policy wording)
-Ikenna asked what format its stored in answer: csv
-At this point not sure if you need to have it encrypted or password protected, or make certain aspects or certain fields anonymous
-Can look into this early on, email Rachel Ward and Pete Juzl and say Mark Gledhill sent you
-iVote have a similar extraction on their data, Steve Calcott is a PM in that team

Moved to'Stage' on the Pipeline to reflect this has a planned go live in the next two weeks.

Please raise/link your RBREVIEW ticket and ensure your actions above have been addressed.

Hi Julian,

I'm not sure if you received the emails on the D lists, but as Homepage is deploying to live Mon 28th Nov and public facing Wed 30th Nov, it may not be possible to release on 29th. Please raise your OPS ticket to discuss planned go live date with the change team.

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

We have tickets in for the 29th and 1st now due to this. Will check with change management

Thank you for flagging.

Cheers
Julian

Hi Siobain,

This has now been released. Is this okay to now move to production under warranty?

Cheers
Julian

item.title: [PIPELINE-1128] Things To Do: Version 1.1
item.description:
Things To Do v1.1 is a new set of features to be released that will enhance and stabilise the partner admin, improve SEO and meet key compliance and contractual requirements.

Features:

  • Facets/Filters/counts
  • BBC Admin Export Data
  • Multibrowser inline image editor
  • Text formatting/links CFD for partners. Admin only need in FAQs
  • Cancelled / Postponed
  • Presentation of promotions on projects and activity pages
  • Social functionality
  • Auto addition of promotions to projects
  • Resubmitted activities
  • Flickr gallery
  • Improve No Results pages
  • Location mega-dropdown
  • More activity / Activities near here logic
  • Client side validation
  • Publish category, project and promotion IDs
  • Printable versions of activity pages and activity indexes
  • Project links on promotion pages
  • Add to iCal
  • Suitable for / Child friendly
  • In-line location information
  • Duplicate alerts

More detailed documentation can be found at: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/V1.1

https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/DBA-24

Tech review meeting Friday 6th Jan 2012 14:30-15:30, BC4 A3 M2 (Absolutely Fabulous)
Attendees: Bristol - Julian Tovey (TPM); Salford - Robert Lee (TA); Bath - Ben Poole and Andy Max from Aerian (Indie); London - Rajesh Jha (DBA Team), Mark Gledhill (Platform Eng), Andrew Hutson (Service Mgmt), Ziad Dajani (Content Producer), Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager)

PRODUCT OVERVIEW
Ziad took us through the background of the service
-Things To Do (TTD) enables the BBC and partners to put up activities which are run locally
-CTAs come from Brands (e.g. Springwatch, Autumnwatch, Countryfile) to point to activities, so that activities tie in to BBC output
-The term Project corresponds to a Brand, e.g. Springwatch, Autumnwatch, Countryfile
-The term Promotion corresponds to a theme/event, e.g. Springwatch Big Weekend, or half term (which goes across lots of projects)
-Partners (who run the activities), provide activities via:
a.Partner Admin, where they manually enter stuff which is moderated by TTD editorial content team
b.Upload XML directly if they are a Trusted Partner (such as Culture24, which is an Arts & Culture government body. Comic Relief and Wildlife Trust are expected future Trusted partners)

SCOPE
V1.1 is enhancements to the admin system and some public facing UX enhancements as listed below
Low level detail about the changes can be found at: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/V1.1

HIGH IMPACT CHANGES
1.Facets/Filters/counts: This is initially just for the front end, the data is already there so no DB changes, this will require changes to PAL layer and DB layer. This will require LOAD TESTING. The amount of work the cron is doing will stay the same (currently takes 1s on sandbox for the 2500 live activities). Action: Project team to speak with the DBA team about the new queries, table structure and the increased load
2.BBC Admin Export Data: Editorial team wish to be able to examine what partners we have, so they can send communications to Partners. Export data as part of CSV files so that BBC staff can use it to conduct communications with partners. Build a new SL end point, send back a native SQL requesting only specific fields. Data will be exported infrequently; at busiest this will be a couple times a day. Execution time for up to 500 partners (max expected records in next year or so), and query is under 40 ms. InfoSec review will look at process and interactions of people with it, so you will need to explain processes around people using this data appropriately, level or security and responsibly, what they do with the data and how they delete it when they are finished with it simple paragraph explaining the guidelines once youve downloaded it Mark does accept this is business data, so security implications are lower than personal data
3.Multibrowser inline image editor: Partners upload images for their activities onto the site. This is the single area partners complain most about as the image has to be a specific size, etc. which causes issues. In previous tech review, the project team got approval for HTML5 and so this is what they use, however as HTML5 is only supported by certain browsers, they need a solution to enable partners who dont use HTML5. Ben advised that there needs to be a temporary storage location while image is being edited. Uploader (which is already part of the arch) will be utilised for this, but images that are not deleted (i.e. if a browser session closes before upload) need to be cleared down daily. It was agreed that a nightly cron job could be used for this (number of expected images is in the 10s)

MEDIUM IMPACT CHANGES
4.TTDR-1329 - Text formatting/links for Admin only need in FAQs: Enable BBC staff to format the text. Integration of a 3rd party text editor, might go for the Glow editor (soon to be no longer supported) Action: Project team to speak to Frameworks, who may prefer you use jQuery instead of Glow
5.TTDR-169 - Cancelled / Postponed: This is to enable a Partner to flag an activity as postponed/cancelled. DBA team to review this
6.TTDR-2230 - Presentation of promotions on projects and activity pages: Horizontal linking, i.e. link Springwatch 'Project' to Spring Watch Big Weekend 'Promotion'. This will just be exposing endpoints that are already there. This is an additional request from PAL to SL
7.TTDR-427 - Social functionality: Using Sharetools. Ability to share an activity via twitter, facebook etc.. Action: Phil Poole (PSP TPM)/Kai En Ong (CD UX&D) to comment this ticket with confirmation the project team can use Sharetools and Sharetools can accommodate TTD volumetrics. Mark advised you need to ensure you follow the Sharetools rules
8.TTDR-2227 - Auto addition of activities to promotions: This is for the automatic addition of activities to promotions depending on project and dates. When an activity is saved, it will be automatically assigned to any AUTO promotion with matching dates. Partners cannot manually select/deselect AUTO promotions.
9.TTDR-2226 - Resubmitted activities: New filter for resubmitted activities in BBC Admin. This will require a DB change
10.TTDR-688 - Flickr gallery: Ability to change the Flickr 'Group' that appears on the Things To Do Homepage through controls in BBC admin. The Flickr API key is currently hard coded in one of the project config files along with other setting such as the Bing API key. Creation of a key/value config table (could be used elsewhere in the application). The team wish to store a single API key and a group ID Mark G suggested that if you have keys to call other APIs, put them in an OPS controlled config file, that way its more secure. If you have specific IDs they could go in the DB so they are easier to change. Theres a page on confluence called something like secret files Mark can dig out the link for you if you cant find it. Mark G advised the project team to watch out for setting Flickr cookies, as this can and has in the past, caused problems. DBA to review
11.TTDR-2231 - Improve No Results pages: If no results are found, it should show additional relevant results. Structure is defined by the team. It will only go one level up, so there is a maximum of two searches

LOW IMPACT CHANGES
12.TTDR-417 - Location mega-dropdown: Mega dropdown of BBC Regions (non js users wont see this)
13.TTDR-1564 - More activity / Activities near here logic: This is to change the logic behind how activities are displayed in certain sections so users can see examples of other activities near a location
14.TTDR-1233 - Client side validation: Addition of Client Side side validation using JS to validate Activity, Promotion and Project forms client side, before the form is submitted
15.TTDR-1334 - Publish category, project and promotion IDs: Trusted partners to see key information. Print existing primary key information onto a new PAL view in partner admin for XML partners
16.TTDR-1213 - Printable versions of activity pages and activity indexes: Optimise the printable versions of the CSS
17.TTDR-2238 - Project links on promotion pages: Print associated project information on promotion pages. Link to projects from promotions (other way around from - TTDR-2230 - Presentation of promotions on projects and activity pages)
18.TTDR-1318 - Add to iCal: Add a Partner to add an activity to their calendar
19.TTDR-2591 - In-line location information: More info on location so Partner is sure they are appending the correct location to an activity
20.TTDR-2629 - Duplicate alerts: Flagging to Partner if someone in their org has already created this activity

PIPELINE ACTIVITIES
-LOADTEST: Required
-CIS: Update arch and remember to include processes around data handling (per note for BBC Admin Export Data)
-MON: TBD
-RBREVIEW: Run book needs to be updated and made unrestricted (Ziad is going to look at whether the restriction needs to remain)

ACTIONS
1. Project team to speak with the DBA team, advising them of schema structure, volumetrics and example queries, for any DB changes, i.e.:
a. Facets/Filters/counts
b. TTDR-169 - Cancelled / Postponed
c. TTDR-2226 - Resubmitted activities
d. TTDR-688 - Flickr gallery
2. Project team to speak to Frameworks team to determine the 3rd Party Text Editor to use project team would like to use Glow, but this is no longer supported. Would like to use it for:
a. TTDR-1329
b. TTDR-1233 - Client side validation
3. Project team to update architecture to include any changes, i.e.:
a. TTDR-427 - Sharetools
b. TTDR-2227 - Auto addition to activities to promotions
c. TTDR-2226 - Resubmitted activities
d. TTDR-688 - Flickr gallery
e. TTDR-417 - Location mega-dropdown
f. TTDR-1564 - More activity / Activities near here logic
g. TTDR-1233 - Client side validation
h. TTDR-1334 - Publish category, project and promotion IDs
i. TTDR-1213 - Printable versions of activity pages and activity indexes
j. TTDR-2238 - Project links on promotion pages
k. TTDR-1318 - Add to iCal
l. TTDR-2591 - In-line location information
m. TTDR-2629 - Duplicate alerts
4. PROJECT TEAM to get confirmation from PSP Team for using Sharetools (for TTDR-427) and accommodation of TTD volumetrics by Sharetools
5. PROJECT TEAM to carry out Soak Testing. Mark Gledhill advised that Load Testing is critical, but in addition the project team need to do some soak testing as other projects (Food) had problems in this area (issues with caching which brought down their tomcat) Project team have already been speaking to Phil Lamond in Food

MEETING OUTCOME: This is being move to INCUBATION until:
-Ticket has been raised to DBA team (per Action 1)
-Action 2 is complete (i.e. decision as to use Glow or not has been agreed)
-Action 3 is complete
Other actions can be completed during DEVELOPMENT.

Hi Siobain,

Action 1 - Andy has raised a DBA ticket: DBA-28. This is being reviewed now.
Action 3 - I've updated our Technical Design page with the latest Technical Architecture diagram: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Technical+Architecture (I've also attached it to this ticket)
Action 2 - I've been in contact with Frameworks and Nic Ford (Barlesque Product Owner):

Its the same answer as before, Im afraid: you can use Glow if you feel its the right choice, but its deprecated, and doesnt have any support from an internal team. The message for the past two years or so has been, please start migrating to jQuery. Now, you as developers and product owners are in the best position to decide when is the right time to do that, and if that time has not yet come, then you are free to stick with Glow. But as I say, Im afraid youll need to support it yourselves.

Hope that helps.

Cheers

Nic Ford

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

On 12/01/2012 16:12, "Ben Poole" <Ben.Poole@aerian.com> wrote:
Hi Nic,

Are we able to get a decision on whether we can continue using Glow for the final stage of the Things To Do project? Its one of the actions preventing us moving to development on PIPELINE-1128

Ive ccd in Ziad(product manger) and Julian(TPM).

Many Thanks

Ben Poole
Developer | Aerian Studios

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: Ben Poole

Hi Nic,

Migrating to JQuery has been mentioned. Unfortunately, between the three ThingsToDo applications there are 30,816 Lines of Glow based JavaScript in 82 Files meaning migration is really not an option.

The final development stage of ThingsToDo is expected to finish by the end of March. Is there a chance we could get approval to use Glow for these final requirements? Ongoing support is going to be a problem regardless.

If Glow is a definite no, then we will of course look into JQuery alternatives.

Many Thanks

Ben Poole
Developer | Aerian Studios

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: Nic Ford Nic.Ford@bbc.co.uk

Hm. I see the problem.

Glow is, effectively, already deprecated. Only in rare circumstances do we support it any longer, and since its been open-sourced its largely now in the care of the dev community.

In all honesty, out preferred approach and this should have been communicated to you by the BBC PM is to move to jQuery. If you have the opportunity to do this, for reasons of ongoing support apart from anything else, Id strongly suggest you do that. Basically, that means not only adding a new dependency, but also removing Glow as one. So, at least the net number of dependencies wont change.

Hope that helps in some way apologies for suggesting additional work, but it really makes sense in the long run.

Cheers

Nic Ford
Product Owner, Barlesque & Mobilesque

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

On 09/01/2012 15:28, "Ben Poole" <Ben.Poole@aerian.com> wrote:
Hi Nic,

Im development lead on the Forge/PAL application ThingsToDo. During conversations with Frameworks about the continued use of the Glow JavaScript framework within the ThingsToDo PAL application theyve pointed me in your direction.

ThingsToDo consists of three PAL applications which all make heavy use of the Glow JavaScript framework. The ThingsToDo V1.1 contract is a new set of features to be released that will enhance and stabilize the application. V1.1 introduces two new client side requirements, a Rich Text Editor and Client Side Form Validation. Both of these requirements can be met making use of glow.widgets.editor and glow.forms within V1.7.7 of the Glow JavaScript framework.

We are aware that Glow is heading towards deprecation and that continued usage is discouraged, but it seems wrong adding another dependency to the application (JQuery) when everything we need is already present in the framework we are already using.

You opinion on this would be greatly appreciated. (Or a nudge in the right direction if Ive contacted the wrong person)

Many Thanks

Ben Poole
Developer | Aerian Studios

Hi Siobain,

See above for resolved actions blocking DEVELOPMENT.

Thanks
Ben

Hi Siobain,

Are we okay to move this to development?

Cheers
Julian

item.title: [PIPELINE-1119] Languages Profiling Game
item.description:
Using the existing activEngine component to deliver a Test your language skills game. It provides levels (beginner, post-beginner and intermediate) integrated with BBC iD and GamesGrid to enable learners to come back to test their level again.

All content and activities are already created.

Integration with GamesGrid to provide storage of progress and support repeat plays and store users' progress and feedback. Normally a pipeline ticket wouldn't be required for a team to use activEngine.

Background: Originally, a Languages Profiling Game was to be developed soley for Languages. However the activEngine application was developed to allow multiple tenants, not just Languages, to provide interactive online quizzes.

Related:
original Languages Profile Tool
JIRA https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LANGPROFILE
CONFLUENCE https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/langprofile/Languages+Profiling+Tool

activEngine - the successor to the original Profile Tool
JIRA https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PROFTOOL
CONFLUENCE https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/proftool/activEngine+%28aka+the+Profiling+Tool%29

comments.comment:
Hi Pipeline Team,

this pipeline ticket has been created as the Langauages Profile Tool will be a tenant of the existing activEngine and will use GamesGrid, however Gamesgrid has not yet been activated for this Languages Profile Tool.

An application form has been completed to request use of Gamesgrid and is currently in review.

A technical architecture diagram is in progress and we are therefore seeking guidance on whether or not the full pipeline process is needed:

  • Runbook
  • CIS
  • Loadtest
  • MON
  • Ops-stage and Ops-Live (note that the only thing going live is the content and activation of gamesgrid service). activEngine is already live

I can raise these either way so that we have referenced them for completeness and can document any decisions.

Hi Luke,

I discussed this today with Ian Myatt in our regular meet-up, and whilst your concept document has been signed off, I need to you to confirm that your Discovery phase/doc have been approved before the Pipeline Team move you to the pipeline Radar.

To answer your question above, this project will need to follow full pipeline process. The level of engagement with regards to specific areas such as LOADTEST, etc will come out in the tech review.

Regards,
Tara.

Hi Luke,

What is the status of this?

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Siobain

we are still in discovery phase and need to get the Discovery phase doc completed. Also need to book Tech Review.

This will influence the go live dates. How can I go about getting a Tech Review booked in please? Robert Lee is our TA up in Salford so could possibly do Video Conference?

Thanks

Luke

Hi Luke,

The pipeline tech review is to review your project once you've completed your Feasibility steps (Concept, Discovery, Feasibility) have your architecture and voluemtrics agreed with your product area, signed off by your TA and ready for review by OTG.

If you are still in discovery phase then this is too early for a pipeline tech review. The project team and TA can have tech reviews outside of our process and contact Platform Eng and Frameoworks directly if they have quesions.

Whilst you are still in this Feasibility phase, I'll move you back to Feasibility and you can move the ticket back to 'Ready for Pipeline' once the arch and voluemtrics are signed off and ready for review by OTG.

If you've any questions, please feel free to get me on IRC or IM.

Rgds
Siobain

Next steps:

1. Discovery Doc approval
2. Tech arch and volumetrics set up
3. Move to ready for pipeline
4. Tech Arch review book

Chat with Luke Tagg:

  • Will treat this as a proper pipeline ticket with the hope that tickets raised could then be utilised for an overarching ticket for all language flash games (similar to PIPELINE-608 for Children's)
  • Rob Lee will finish arch and volumetrics and then we will have a tech review
  • Siobain to talk with erik Upton about an overarching/maintenance ticket

Hi Siobain,

I'm moving this to Ready for Pipleine.

Technical Arch candidate is available at https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/langprofile/Technical+design along with Volumetrics.

Please can you let me know when we can book a Tech Review? Could this be done over the phone as we're up in Salford?
Thanks

Luke

Hi Luke,

Is your date 28th Nov? It's very soon.

A number of us are up in Salford next week for another training session if you want me to arrange it for Wed or Thu? Otherwise and if it needs to be sooner I'll arrange for this week if I can.

Rgds
Siobain

The 28th was very much a baseline date without knowing what work was needed for this to get it live. Johann's now off on Paternity leave until 5.12.11 and as there is still content outstanding the dates need pushing back.

Would there any possibility of getting a review w/c 5.12.11?

Thanks

Luke

Hi Luke,

I'll set up a tech review with your team. Platform Eng don't need to attend as they are happy with you are doing (Standard flash app with config). Have you spoken to BBC ID to confirm your usage of this? I'll cc Frameworks.

Please send me the attendees from your side.

Rgds
Siobain
Hi Luke, I've updated your planned go live to reflect this will be after 5th Dec, notionally 14th Dec (although this is during the change restriction which occurs prior to Change Freeze).

Hi Siobain

I have spoke with Richard @ BBC id and described what we are doing. He has confirmed that all is ok as we are communicating with BBC id via GAPI.

Thanks

Luke

Use of FLiP Description.

1. Accessed via login
2. User access managed by provider
3. FLiP doesn't publish
> builds pages on old stack

Content Workflow: VDEV > VSTAGE > Pages Added to live

Site development updates (non -content) will be subject to RedBee pre release testing e.g. code validation

Hi Siobain

Hope all well. What dates are you thinking of for the Tech Review?

Attendees from our area would be myself and Robert Lee TA for K&L

Thanks

Luke

Pipeline Review scheduled for Mon 5th Dec 3pm-4pm. Salford and London (BC3 C1 M2 Leaves)
Required attendees Luke, Rob and Siobain

Technical Design and Volumetrics for Tech Review:

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/langprofile/Technical+design

Pipeline Review held Monday 5th Dec 3pm, BC3 C1 M2 (Leaves) & conference call
Attendees: Luke Tagg, Robert Lee, Siobain Collins

OBJECTIVE
This meeting did not involve Platform Engineering or Frameworks as both teams are happy for this project to progress without a technical review. This meeting is to review what steps on the pipeline checklist are applicable.

NOTES

  • Luke provided a product overview: The Languages profiling Game is an interactive flash game that helps learners test their ability and record progress in French, Spanish, German and Italian across four skills (reading, writing, listening and speaking). It is embedded on the languages site.
  • Architecture & Volumetrics
    -The aim is to embed the Active Engine within a page on the languages site to allow a user to carry out a language test
    -The Active Engine is already live, this sits on Forge, this was deployed for La Mappa Misteriosa. No code changes will be made to the Active Engine for this deployment
    -The Languages page, which is on old stack, will pull in a html flash file for the Active Engine
    -The user will be required to sign in using BBC ID - Luke advised that Richard Northover in Frameworks has already approved this usage of BBC ID and their volumetrics
  • PIPELINE CHECKLIST
    -LOADTEST - Raise a ticket to see if required. NB: There's a 2 week lead time for load testing so please raise this ASAP
    -CIS - Complete templates an raise CIS ticket
    -MONITORING - Think about the services you are dependent on, e.g. BBC ID and Active Engine and think a) How you know if they are not working, are you reading flagpoles? b) What you do to gracefully degrade if they are not working. Also worth looking into URL Page Monitoring
    -RUN BOOK - Update/create Run Book and raise RBREVIEW ticket
    -OPS - Raise an 'OPS Change FYI' ticket. Change will be to publish some html on old stack to reference Active Engine & BBC ID on Forge. Even though there will be no deploy to Forge, you need to advise OPS of the deploy you are making to the old stack. These changes still fall within the constraints of the change freeze, so your ticket should be raised by Thursday 8th Dec and deployed no later than Thursday 15th Dec. Siobain advised Luke that if it is expected to fall outside this window, special dispensation will be required - please contact Darren Stocking in the Change & Release team
    -CTA/Tx - Luke advised n/a

MEETING OUTCOME: Move to DEVELOPMENT

Have created MON, CIS nd Loadtest as requested.

We will get runbook, CIS in shape and get dates for stage/live confirmed from Joahann (editorial)

Ops stage/live to be raised when the dates are confiemd as FYI tickets

thanks

Luke

Hi Luke,

We are reviewing all of the changes and associated Pipeline tickets with change management. You will need to have your info only tickets raised by the end of this week or else you may struggle to get the agreement to deploy in the change closure period ( W/C 12th - 16th dec).

I can see that you are still awaiting your Gamesgrid sign-off so If your go-live date changes can you please ensure that you update your Pipeline ticket
Regards
Stephen

Hi Stephen

I've createdOps stage and live tickets for this now as 'fyi only' tickets as it's on old stack.

Ive also asked that the GamesGrid tickets are resolved by GamesGrid's Sophie Bradshaw as they all seem fine after testing.

Thanks

Luke

Moving Go Live date into Jan as some issues have been found with activeEngine and GAPI communications.

These are being reviewed

MON requirements being dtermined. Need to review if MONITORING can/should be added to all /languages, or just the activengine page. Will see what PSHE old stack site did for MONITORING

Status:
LOADTEST-596 Green
CIS-546 Green
MON-943 Amber, back to Project Team
RBREVIEW-290 Red assigned to Jon Smith (247?)
OPS-55751 Live 11th Jan
OPS-55750 Stage 10th Jan
Not using GamesGrid now. Therefore all GamesGrid tickets linked can be ignored. Will find out if these tickets need to be resolved or can stay linked in case we use GamesGrid in future.

Runbook Review
The Languages Profile Game doesn't have a run book of it's own. It's an instance of the RE-USABLE activEngine .swf file (a customisable flash quiz .swf file) and is embedded into old stack /languages pages described in the sanity checks on the page. https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/langprofile/Languages+Profiling+Game+Run+Book

I wanted to raise this RunBook Review against the Languages Profile Game for completeness.

For the purpose of this RunBook Review the activEngine Run Book should be referred to which has been signed off.
?activEngine Run Book https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/proftool/activEngine+%28aka+the+Profiling+Tool%29++run+book

First Game 'German' now live.

All other languages games will be launched after this. I'll raise 'old stack FYI Ops stage/live tickets' and attach to this main pipleine. The other language games are exactly the same as the German game and aren't treated as seperate pipeline tickets.

Will aim to get at least 1 weeks notice per language game instance launch

Thanks

Luke

Chat with Luke:

Original plan, to release all games at once, was changed, such that only German was initially released to production.
