  • OPS-55750 STAGE release - Can be closed and removed by Luke, (to the best of my knowledge) there's not the concept of STAGE on the SIS stack

  • Planned Go Live Date to be set, by Luke, to reflect the next release to live and an OPS FYI ticket raised for each deploy (group multiple games if they all release to production on same date)

Siobain will keep this ticket in STAGING until all the games have been released to production.

Thanks

Luke

French and Italian Lang Games to be launched Thursday 19th Jan 2012.

item.title: [PIPELINE-1089] Things to do - Fortnightly releases
item.description:
Things To Do is a PAL application that is described here:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/TTDR+home

Things To Do deploys updates to live application every 2 weeks and these updates typically include:

New audience facing features
Bug fixes
Performance improvements
Localisation implementations
Accessibility improvements

This ticket has been created to provide visibility to the PIPELINE of the ongoing iterative releases of the Things To Do product.

In events where new features or functionality are introduced that change the architecture of the application, or change the level or profile of traffic expected, seperate PIPELINE tickets for these significant changes will be raised.

The release schedule for these BAU deployments can be found here: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Technical+Delivery

This ticket will remain valid so long as:

No architectural changes have been made
Compliance with the InfoSec/CIS approval is maintained
No additional monitoring is required
The Runbook is maintained with relevant updates
Load testing remains a valid representation of expected traffic

comments.comment: New pipeline as requested to track bug fixing and maintenance work.

Moving into Development as agreed in salford meeting on the 11th October 2011 this ticket will be used for bug fixes, no new features are to be delivered via this ticket.

Regards

Stephen

do you have an impending release on the horizon? If so can you please link the OPs tickets. If not can you move the planned go-live date out into the future so this remains on our radar.

Regards

Stephen

item.title: [PIPELINE-1061] Bitesize: Migration of quizzes from QuizEngine to ActivityMaker
item.description:
"Build on the success of quizzes in Bitesize; stable technology, consistency for the user, and a simpler production workflow."

Bitesize utilises the deprecated QuizEngine mod_perl application to serve up Test Bites (quizzes) to learners. QuizEngine is due to be decommissioned in Dec 2011. This project aims to replace this technology with something new, which is fit-for-purpose editorially, can be supported, and will simplify production workflows.
item.summary: Bitesize: Migration of quizzes from QuizEngine to ActivityMaker

comments.comment: Added draft 3 of concept document; + quiz usage statistics

Just to confirm, stich off date for QuizEngine is "end of March 2012" as mentioned by Simon Stevenson via email:

"This is unsupported in its current state and I would encourage all users of it to look for alternatives. The only switch off date that has been announced is that of the end of March. This is when Richard Cooper has suggested we switch off the Siemens cgi-apps servers that among other things host quizengine.pl. I have no plans/resources/priorities to replace/port/move quizengine to any other platform."

item.title: [PIPELINE-1058] CLOSED: Things To Do: TTD Widget on Local News pages

The Things To Do site (live at /thingstodo/) are providing a set of page includes for local News pages. item.title: [PIPELINE-1053] Planet Dinosaur - Flash game
item.description:
Flash game embedded in Progs v2 template to support Dinosaur season.

Built by Indie, Fish in a Bottle. Uses Games Grid to support login, save data, achievements, temporary player and istats functionality.

The ultimate aim of the Planet Dinosaur Game is to complete your Planet Dinosaur Collection, unlocking all Dinosaurs, Plants and Environmental objects in the game. To do this players will need to successfully grow a series of different dinosaurs, play through mini games and enter codes, acquired in various ways (released on TV, given away at museums, published in the Radio Times, etc.).

Game already in development on extdev. This page on stage is pulling it in.

http://www.stage.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b014m55k/flash/development-dino-game

Holding page : http://www.stage.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b014m55k/flash/planet-dinosaur-game

Impact on OPS : Expecting to be low. Emergency tech review required though to confirm.

----------
Confluence space needed? No - will be using the EARTH Confluence space as this integrates into Nature content.
Jira project needed? No - will be using the EARTH Jira space (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/earth/EARTH)
Product shortcode : n/a
Conf/Jira administrators : Not required. The EARTH Conf/Jira users are all that are needed.

comments.comment:
Chat with Erik, Erik to do the following:
1. Need know arch, e.g. uses Games Grid, BBC ID, embedded Flash in /programmes v2, aything else
2. Games Grid and BBC ID need agree to you being a tenant of theirs
3. Event Mgmt/Launches Calendars need to be updated for TXs/CTAs
4. Raise a load testing ticket and see if needed
5. How will it be monitored

9. Move the ticket to Feasibility

NB: Whilst this can be FTP'd up by the project team, they should not do so until points 1-9 have been addressed.

Siobain,

I have been working with the Indie with regards to the Games Grid functionality. We agree to Planet Dinosaur being a tenant on our platform, subject to a final Game review before going live.

Thanks
Sophie

Siobain,

Yes, a change ticket should be raised so that Ops are aware. I've also asked Erik for some more specific details about the CTA's.

This one has clearly hit us extremely late, but we do need to get those things in Siobain's comment covered off.

Andrew
Hi Sophie, is there a Games Grid applications ticket or some such that can be attached to this pipeline ticket? Or are you happy with me attaching the original application?

Quick notifications:

Loadtesting not required as long as GG and Identity are happy with volumetrics.

Runbook started here : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Planet+Dino+Game

I checked with Cathal Coughlan from /programmes v2 whether they had any concerns about this use/utilisation of /programmes v2?

Cathal Coughlan advised 27 Sep:
"No, that looks fine to me - in the event of major demand, our caching will be up to the task - the page in question isn't even very heavily programme data-driven (the actual registration and gaming back ends aren't our department).
'/programmes' mainly suffers if there's mass demand for a whole set of frequently-updated pages which carry a lot of queried data, such as schedules (as, for example, in the case of the DOS attacks on the World Service schedules from that ISP portal in Turkey, which have been happening every couple of months since last autumn).
thanks for letting me know"

Volumetrics

Any CTA from TV has the potential to produce a momentary spike of considerable size that could affect all of forge not just the Planet Dino game.

In the Games Grid application the suggestion was 15,000 per hour. On average that would be about 4 per second, but we really need a figure that represents the highest spike in traffic at the per second level. This is likely to be off the back of the BBC 1 10 second sting between programmes in primetime.

Not sure we have a precedent, so I'm going to make some assumptions

1. It's a sting, there's no audience engagement with the content, just a curious audience who want to see what it was about
2. The URL is to /dinosaurs which takes users to the Nature page first (http://www.bbc.co.uk/dinosaurs) , which should delay and distract users from clicking on any prominent link to the Dino game. Should help smooth out the spike anyway.
3. The Dino season page is getting 2-4000 page views per day. Last week, after a url trail at the back of the programme the Dino Season received <4000 views across the day. The whole Nature site also got around 5000 views during the hour after TX. So they are the max numbers we might expect with a simple url trail.
3. Previous highest CTA traffic for any of our products has been for LabUK Class experiment off the back of a One Show promotion where the maximum was 234 simultaneous users per second (SU's). But that was a very engaged curious audience with a substantial part of the programme dedicated to it.
4. Games Grid have never had a spike higher than 16 SU's, likely to have come from a CBBC CTA.

Therefore I'm going to suggest that we're unlikely to reach 100SU's on this one, but playing safe let's assume this is the per second spike that could occur.

Games Grid can handle 100 SU's
BBC ID can handle 1000+ SU's
Programmes pages handled by caching nicely (see Cathal's comments above)

Thanks Siobain,

Things are coming together. Updated checklist

1. Need know arch, e.g. uses Games Grid, BBC ID, embedded Flash in /programmes v2, anything else.
That's it by the looks of it. Robert Lee will be adding details to the runbook here : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Planet+Dino+Game

2. Games Grid and BBC ID need agree to you being a tenant of theirs - DONE (See comments above)

3. Event Mgmt/Launches Calendars need to be updated for TXs/CTAs (awaiting details from Marketing)

4. Raise a load testing ticket and see if needed (not required : see https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-447)

5. How will it be monitored (currently with Sarbast : https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/MON-767)

6. Is InfoSec required (still need to put in request, but awaiting runbook update first)

7. Have you a runbook : In progress - https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Planet+Dino+Game

8. Volumetrics need to be added to this ticket - see comment above

9. Move the ticket to Feasibility

Siobain to check tomorrow Platfrom Eng if a tech review needs to occur and see if OPS FYI chg ticket should be raised.

NB: Whilst this can be FTP'd up by the project team, they should not do so until points 1-9 have been addressed. (Editorial notified to await your approval)

Reviewed with Platform Eng and Frameworks who agreed this could be moved into DEVELOPMENT in the Pipeline, once the review with Games Grid is completed prior to go live and this has sign off from infosec - Erik, I would advise you raise a CIS (Compliance and Information Security) ticket ASAP

OPEN ACTIONS
3. Erik to update event/launch calendars
6. Erik to raise InfoSec ticket
7. Run book in progress and Matt Dellowes team are aware of this - the formal process is to raise a RBREVIEW ticket for 247 to review this
8. Volumetrics need to be added to this ticket
10. New: Raise an OPS FYI ticket for visibility

CLOSED ACTIONS
1. Arch described in 'Overview' section in Run Book
2. Games Grid review ticket linked. Frameworks passed on Richard Northover's advise that unless the volume of traffic is high, use of BBC ID will be covered by your discussions with Games Grid
4. LOADTEST-447 raised
5. MON-767 raised
9. Ticket progressed

Thanks Siobain,

Ok, Infosec ticket raised (CIS-476). Robert Lee having a look at populating it. Likely to be based on

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/children/CIS+software+weakness+review+for+Flash+Games
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/children/Compliance+summary+for+Flash+Games

Volumetrics have been added in a comment above. Is there a better form of doing this? Still a few questions around it that Andrew Hutson & I are chasing though so try and tighten it up.

Finally, what is an OPS FYI ticket?
I've created a RBReview ticket too now : https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/RBREVIEW-220

Morning.

A couple of updates.

Monitoring is approved (https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/MON-767). Sarbast says No extra monitoring is required beyond ID and GG monitoring.
Thanks to Rob for getting the runbook and compliance in order

  • https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Compliance+Summary+for+Dino+Game
  • https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Planet+Dino+Game
  • CIS review assigned to Stephen Butler who says "I have asked for this to be looked at outside of the standard meetings (otherwise it would not be reviewed until the 4th)."

Ok, more updates.

Flash has problems. Release to live is due tomorrow now. There's a change release ticket in place (OPS-50990) to cover this. All old stack and iSite though. Should this have been an OPS FYI ticket???
Best understanding of CTA dates and times are now in the Launch calendar.

New volumetrics.
Andrew Hutson & I cross-referenced traffic for The Code and a LabUK spike and came up with a new likely max peak traffic of 60-75 SU's. This should be ok for Games Grid and BBC ID, but it's not clear that Progs v2 Ancilliary pages have the capacity above 50SU's. Details to follow.

Remaining dependancies for go live:

1. Infosec approval (Siobain can you chase?)
2. Progs v2 confirmation of volumetrics support (due tomorrow)

Other work still required (not 100% sure if these are dependancies for go live)

1. Runbook completed and reviewed
2. Out of hours support and rollback instructions to be added to runbook (Erik will do this when he gets the info)

Many thanks,

Erik

item.title: [PIPELINE-1051] Frozen Planet - Second Screen BETA
item.description:
Project description : A feed of relevant K&L Thing pages on 2nd screens automatically triggered by subtitles. Context Frozen Planet with content from Wildlife Finder. Built by Indie : Backflip. Closed Beta for audience testing.

Confluence space needed? No, we are going to use the Earth confluence space : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/

Jira project needed? No, we are managing via Basecamp.

Product shortcode : not required

Conf/Jira administrators : n/a

comments.comment: Added PDG approved Concept & Feasability doc

Chat with Erik:

This is going to be a web site hosted externally by 'BackFlip' on behalf of the BBC.
Users will go directly to the website, they will not be re-directed from the BBC site.
URL not known at this time.
This will be a limited trail which runs in conjunction with second series of Frozen planet.

Next steps:

  • Erik to complete 3rd Party Hosting Form http://guidelines.gateway.bbc.co.uk/dq/thirdparties/isp.shtml
  • Raise a CIS ticket

Siobain to FYI this past Platform Eng (and Frameworks) and see if there's anything else Erik needs to do.

Erik,

Following a chat with Platfrom Eng, please could it be clear the business reason why this won't be hosted by the BBC.

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Erik,

Any update to Siobain's question above please?

Thanks,
Tara.

Hi both, apologies for the delay in responding.

The technology requires servers that support websockets. Not entirely clear on the exact nature of this so I've added Rob Lee as a watcher, and he may be better placed to explain.

Essentially though, we need to be able to simultaneously push a feed to mulitple users (<200) for an audience test of the application on the 26th Oct (1st Frozen Planet programme). My understanding is that the BBC doesn't offer this technology at the moment.

Meanwhile, we're are trying to fill in the 3rd party hosting form. Should be ready tomorrow, whereon I'll raise that CIS ticket too.

Many thanks,

Erik

Hi there, I've received this comment on why we're hosting 3rd party :

"The reason we're doing it on BackFlip's servers is mainly because the data to drive the app is being delivered using web sockets. To handle high volumes of socket connections we use node and socket.io. This would not be possible on the BBC stack as far as I'm aware. We are also up against it in terms of time before tx and to work off our own stack is much faster."

It is true that we've got to turn this around quickly, and also that it's not audience facing per-se. It's simply for audience research purposes.
I'm hoping that this implies for you guys that it doesn't matter too much where it's hosted beyond the normal InfoSec assessment.

All the best,

Erik
Ok, 3rd party hosting form and CIS ticket created and linked to the pipeline.

Hi Erik,

We're going to need a tech review for this. I think it goes without saying that this project has come to pipeline very late in the day and it is possibly too late to engage to get all discussions completed in time for this to launch for Tx.

Please advise on attendees from your side asap and I'll see what I can do.

Regards,
Tara.

Hi Tara,

I'll try to clear this up if I can here and now. And if you still feel we need a tech review, happy to pursue it.

Reasons I think, you might think we need a tech review:
1. This involves external hosting of a copy of some of our data (Wildlife Finder & The Earth from SDA) and presentation files.

Reasons I think I might not have made clear that might change your perspective:
1. The primary objective for this BETA from the business this side is simply to identify how the audience engage with a second screen experience whilst watching documentaries like Frozen Planet and what they like / don't like about it and as such we're not looking for perfection.
2. Less than 200 people outside of the BBC will see it and feedback on their experience (managed via M&A)
3. Success criteria requires excellent synchronisation of the second screen app with the TV programme both in timing, and in links to content.

  • high quality content : the spec of this has changed slightly to be a manually curated list of moments in the programme where some content will pop up on the 2nd screen. So there is no more dependency here on analysing subtitles for keywords as previously suggested.
  • timing : the use of the web sockets servers can ensure the synchronisation of the feed with the timing of the programme.

Dependancies on hitting the deadline:
1. The first programme in the Frozen Planet series is on the 26th Oct. Of all the programmes in the series, this one has the best range of content to test in the BETA applications, and we've got it prepped already. A switch to a later programme is possible, but it does require an editorial push to create content for the new animals and places in that programme.
2. Another 3rd party Indie, sourced by M&A are in the process of recruiting the audience. In doing so they pretty much lock us onto that date. At this moment it's not clear what would happen if we had to move this to another programme.

Ok, so from our side we would like to have

Mr Robert Lee (TA),
Myself (Product / Project Manager)
Could have Andy Littledale from Backflip phone in (based in Bath).

Cheers,

Erik
Do you have an email address for Andy in Bath please so I can add him to the invite?
Also, can you please link to any architecture diagrams you have, which will facilitate the meeting?

Andy will phone in for today's meeting.
I've request an architecture diagram from him.

Looking forward to sorting this later
Updated "Description field" - there is no longer any need for a separate instance of Jira and Confluence to support this project.
Tech Architecture diagram added to Earth Confluence space here : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Runbook+for+Frozen+Planet+2nd+Screen+BETA+application

Pipeline Tech Review : Frozen Planet - Second Screen BETA (PIPELINE-1051)
Held on Weds 12th Oct, 2.30-3.30pm in BC4 B2 M1 (Only Fools & Horses)

ATTENDEES
Graeme Forbes; Tara O'Reilly; Erik Upton; Robert Lee(phone); Andrew Littledale from Backflip(phone).

NOTES

  • First Tx for Frozen Planet on 26th Oct.
  • Controlled login trial experience to 27 users, sourced by an audience testing company contracted by MC&A. Trial users will see an editorially curated view.
  • There will be no TV/Social Media element occuring during the Tx trial (indicatd in the right hand side of the architecture diagram). This may be run offline at a later date to prove capability of technology, to be considered if the trial is to be taken forwards to full production.
  • Syncronisation with subtitling and programme: not an issue for this release, but may become an issue the future so please consider this for future planning.
  • Browser/OS support not a high priority for this trial, but may be later on in product life and should be considered if you plan to move out of trial.
  • Backflip has contracted this system to the BBC to allow 10 rebroadcasts of the test. This Pipeline ticket just accommodates this first trial with Frozen Planet. Any future trials or production projects will require a new Pipeline ticket.
  • The governance of BBC data both in transit and in storage needs to be handled better in future.
  • Is an encrypted image used on EC2? This should be used as a standard mechanism in the future, but not so much of a worry for this trial.

ACTIONS

  1. The project team need to clarify if data is being sent in the clear or not, if the data is sensitive in any way, and where encyption occurs if it happens.
  2. Project team to create a new section in the Earth Confluence space to accommodate all the documentation. Use standard templates for standard documents please!
  3. Andy (Backflip) to draft a list of browsers/OS that is supported by this system and ensure it is in the documentation and the CIS ticket.
  4. CIS-490 needs to include reference to all parts of this system, including software weakness reviews where appropriate, that all potentially exposed socket connections have been checked for penetration and security, that all 3rd party hosting forms are complete and incorporates and further 3rd party information regarding hosting contracts, etc.
  5. Monitoring: Handled contractually with the 3rd party. This should be covered off with the Monitoring team through a MON ticket.
  6. The Runbook will be basic but still needs to be present and a RBREVIEW ticket raised to bring it to 24/7 Ops attention.
  7. Loadtest: The trial only needs to support up to 27 concurrent users and the Backflip system has verified they can handle this. No internal BBC load test required.
  8. An OPS Change ticket should be raised for awareness of the Tx.
  9. Add the Frozen Planet Trial into the event calendar.
  10. Submit any relevent code the BBC should retain into Subversion.
  11. BBC project team to ensure that after the Tx trial, all clear-down and housekeeping is done to ensure BBC data is secured (e.g. from injection attacks, etc).
  12. (Point raised post-meeting!) Clarification required immediately on the use of Twitter feeds which was not discussed in the meeting. Please add this to your technical design pages, architecture, and CIS ticket and indicate on the Pipeline ticket (and directly to Graeme Forbes) when that information is there for further review by Platform Engineering.

.
Agreed to move this ticket to a status of DEVELOPMENT.

NOTE this trial should NOT go ahead without CIS approval due to the number of points which need signing off.
Attached tech architecture diagram
For more detail on the tech architecture, please see : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Frozen+Planet+2nd+Screen+BETA+Technical+Design

Hi Tara,

item.title: [PIPELINE-1015] Things To Do: Page includes for Local News pages
item.description:
The Things To Do service (live at /thingstodo/) are providing a set of page includes for the local News pages. For each set of local news region pages, TTD will provide an include showing activities for that region. Each activity will link to its equivalent page in TTD. There are 38 regions.

The Things To Do widget is currently LIVE and being used by /nature/uk and /history/handsonhistory

The proposed solution has been approved as BAU by Platform Services in FSRV-4754.

Stephen or Siobain to add meeting minutes

Tech review held on 11 October 2011 16:30-17:30, Dock House, Salford: Match of the Day DH-2-MR-01
Attendees: Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager); Stephen Hunwick (Pipeline Manager) Julian Tovey (TPM); Robert Lee (TA); Ben Poole; ben.poole@aerian.com; andy.max@aerian.com; Ziad Dajani (Product Owner); tom.hicks@aerian.com; Paul Tweedy (Platform Engineering); Magnus Dahlgren; Nikos Tsouknidas; Graham Lyons (Platform Engineering - Frameworks).

PRODUCT OVERVIEW
The purpose of this project is to add in the Widget on local news pages, of things to do in the local area. The widget shows sample activities and they an link through.

NOTES:

  • In order to sort embedding on news pages need to use SSI which requires changes in the Things To Do app.
  • There will be 2 types of widget across 38 local news regions.
  • Content will be consumed within local news pages
  • Widget include file for each, region index page and a story page.
  • Larger architectural changes come from having content consumed in local news pages.
  • Widget images served from Static.
  • There will be thresholds set for the widget and will alert when requests spiral over a certain figure via Zenoss alerting.
  • No use of Varnish layer as the caching in Squid is adequate. The Proxy solution in place and has been Load tested up to a 100 SU

VOLUMETRICS
News volumetrics (Key figures provided by Gareth Owen Product manager).

  • Entire news site is 5000 psec peak with a 1000 psec ave with 20 % or below to be considered for local news. (Peak relates to high peak event not daily peak)
  • The estimate from the product view from the widget through to Things To Do would equate to less than
  • 1 % of the total traffic to news pages. i.e. 10 calls per sec at peak, 2 calls per sec at normal
  • The Squid proxy soaks up most of the load.
  • The Widget links to the Things To Do PAL .
  • The anticipated click through rate is 1% of the 20% of traffic for local news = 10psec requests peak and 2psec normally.
  • There will be 5 min caching in place as this is better for editorial reasons. Caching strategy was discussed in FSRV -4754
  • Paul Tweedy noted: As long as the caching is correct and protects the PAL, then given the proxying is already in place, then with the volumetrics weve talked about (peak of 10 hits per sec) it should be ok from a Platform Engineering point of view (both teams)
  • There will be a tiny number of requests from the Squid proxy.
  • Use of Etag and last modified to re-validate the content.

ISSUES

  • The behaviour of the SQUID proxy is not well documented - blank content returns a 200 rather than a 404.

LOADTEST: Raise ticket to confirm with load testing if you believe its not required - the Load test on the first deployment was to 100 Su on main PAL app. Only 3 sus expected to main site. Is there a scenario where the platform proxy fails and so theres no caching and how the service handles it.
MONITORING: Required - Raise Monitoring ticket. Add in new KPIs and link to Pipeline-1015. Include monitoring using Zenoss
INFOSEC - Raise ticket and explain that nothing CIS-wise has changed.
RUNBOOK RAISE Run Book Review Ticket. An update required as this release will be adding new flagpoles so that ops know how to can turn the widget off. If the Flagpole raised is raised it,will stop widget. News need to respect the flagpole. News to stop including our widget. 24x7 escalation procedure

OUTCOME: The Project will move to Development. Planned Go-live date is to be updated.

item.title: [PIPELINE-1013] Things To Do: Mobile walks functionality using iSite
item.description:
Use iSite to publish mobile and desktop pages in order to provide the Mobile Walks functionality for Things To Do. At launch only mobile views will be available.

Things To Do is an existing live service. This Mobile Walks functionality is a new feature of the service which will offer users a guided tour when they visit various destinations. For example a guided tour around the Cardiff visiting Doctor Who locations. Places of interest will be augmented with text as well as audio and video (which will be published via iBroadcast)

We need to have the solution available on Live by October 24th to allow content to be added for Remembrance Day (11th November). There is no guaranteed TX for this but online promotion is planned. Further walks will follow, some of which will be TX tied e.g. Doctor Who Xmas special .

iSite will be used as the content production system. Therefore this functionality is dependent on iSite. The Things To Do team have already consulted with the iSite team. Subject to providing a plan for long term support and maintenance from Knowledge and Learning (the product group which TTD belong in) we have go-head from the iSite product owner.

Content will be published to bbc.co.uk/thingstodo/walks/

The following technical implementation follows the standard iSite implementation which has been used before for many previous implementations (e.g. Skillswise, Domesday, Primary Languages).

Once the content has been published by the content authors via iSite, the data is published to Electron. Electron is based on Atom Server, and also utilises SOLR for content indexing and searching. The PAL app interfaces with Electron via https://api.bbc.co.uk , either to retrieve indexed results (usually a search) or to retrieve full content results (usually when viewing a content page). The PAL app then uses this data to render the webpage.

For general information on iSite, see https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/isite/iSite+in+a+nutshell

Updated volumetrics.
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=28736083#Volumetrics%26LoadTesting-Mobilewalks

Time permitting we may review the Things To Do ticket for Maintenance & Business Critical Rollout Phase PIPELINE-691.

This meeting will be held whilst the OTG teams are up in Salford. For those outside of Salford there is a conference bridge for this meeting: tel 0844 8484840, pswd 109109
Updated architecture overview

Tech review held on 11 October 2011 16:30-17:30, Dock House, Salford: Match of the Day DH-2-MR-01
Attendees: Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager); Stephen Hunwick (Pipeline Manager) Julian Tovey (TPM); Robert Lee (TA); Ben Poole; ben.poole@aerian.com; andy.max@aerian.com; Ziad Dajani (Product Owner); tom.hicks@aerian.com; Paul Tweedy (Platform Engineering); Magnus Dahlgren; Nikos Tsouknidas; Graham Lyons (Platform Engineering - Frameworks).

PRODUCT OVERVIEW
The addition of Location walks follow routes around various locations. For example are locations from Dr Who in Cardiff. The will be text, video and audio provided as you follow the route. At launch only mobile views will be available.
Content will be published at bbc.co.uk/thingstodo/walks/
ARCHITECTURE

  • Architecture is attached to the pipeline ticket
  • Use of isite for CMS. Picks up data from the Electron Servers. ( iSite is a black box)
  • Main architectural change is interacting with Electron.
  • The PAL app will look up indexes in Electron (i.e. someone does search for mobile walks), and when rendering pages will pull in a list of results from SOLR with Atom store pulling content and then rendering it in PAL app.
  • Caching set as part of Electron Cache key and TTL. Cache on Model layer. Cache is fetched and re-used.
  • If you cant contact the Electron service the plan is to serve 500 errors, but OTG would prefer you to serve stale content and instead of serving a 500 error put up a nice page something like page not available if there is nothing in the cache
  • Cant do stale on error through Varnish. Mod cache will do stale on error and stale while re-validates, as long as its in the cache. Graham asked if cache time could be longer, but this was previously discussed and Editorial hoped to keep it at an hour and not extend it

VOLUMETRICS

  • Volumetrics for PAL are 3 sus per sec for volumetrics.
  • This is Location based content with a small number of walks rolling out. 3 sus average.
  • Anticipated Peak traffic around Christmas off of the back of Dr Who.
  • This is highly cacheable content with caching in Model Layer.
  • Model Layer TTL for an hour (memcahce)
    NOTES:
  • The product cannot utilise Varnish
  • The content will potentially change every hour as determined by the need for Editorial content freshness.
  • If BBC running an activity that is cancelled, it will require changes to be made more promptly.
  • Monitoring will be observing the Electron Flagpole if it is down it will return stale content

LOADTEST Raise a ticket to state if or if not needed
CIS APPROVAL - Required for addition of Electron

?Please could you advise if the architecture has changed or whether it's the same as before. If it has changed, please link an arch diagram and highlight the components which have changed

Linked https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/MON-433

?CTA/TX: In progress and dates to be confirmed

Thanks for the advice

Luke

Hi Siobain

Just to follow on from my previous comment - here is a list of the work involved in the Release 1.1. As you can see it falls with Minor Update/BAU. Will await to hear if there is a need for Tech Review. The Domesday team have a deadline of week 40 , 41 at latest as this is when all Submissions to Domesday close. Thanks

Luke

1) When submitting content, on both the picture and text forms, the "optional" contribution credit box asks you to leave it blank if you don't wish to be credited. Unfortunately it cannot currently be left blank. This is clumsy.

FIX: Remove requirement to submit "Contributor Details" from webform. (i.e. allow field to be left blank.)

2) When searching for content (rather than location), the results list contains mixture of 1986 and 2011 content. Unfortunately 2011 results show XML content such as line breaks (e.g. <br> tag) in description. This does not happen with 1986 results descriptions and looks like a tatty mistake.

FIX: Mend/correctly format the display of text search results.

3) Dblocks / search results elsewhere. We've a had several instances of people mistaking 1986 content for modern content. The likes of Portakabin Ltd., an owner of an airfield in Scotland, and even a Blue Peter researcher have all made the same mistake, and has led to unnecessary take-down requests and avoidable complaints. Each picture and text article should flag when the content was produced more prominently near the headline: e.g. "From 1986..." or "from 2011:..." as it's difficult to tell when searching from google (for example) when the article was written or when the picture was taken.

FIX: Adjust wording of each page headline to reflect when content was written/taken to better inform search engine results.

4) Dblocks - Further to the above, and for some reason lost from the original designs, but nevertheless key to our original Ed Pol advice, the Green box "What is domesday?" (visible on the homepage) should appear on every asset page to better clarify the archival nature and context of every piece of content.

FIX: Add "What is Domesday...?" box to RHS of each D-Block, Pic and Text page template, below the search box.

5) Webform on Get involved page. Image has some reason reverted to the old one.

FIX: Please replace picture of Domesday machine with the nice montage of images created by Neil Copeman (can supply).

6) Rather more importantly, currently the search facility doesn't accommodate non-Java-enabled browsing (contrary to BBC guidelines). Simple measures can fix that, and these would be almost essential prior to the capture (see Domesday End document) by The National Archives.

FIX: Change the default non-java version of the page to include the correct attribute to the text input box, adjust radio buttons etc..

7) Article and picture submissions arrive not safely UTF-8 encoded. We've had to learn an awful lot about character sets - manually correcting for different punctuation formats - when constructing our XML files for each submission.

FIX: Review and correctly set formatting on email submission forms.

Agreed with Platform Eng (both teams) that this could move to DEVELOPMENT without a tech review as these all appear to be bug fixes.

Frameworks have advised that you should be using jQuery instead of GLOW, so this is something you should discuss with your TA for the next major deploy you do.

Hi Luke,

Can you please ensure that you link this ticket to a Runbook review ticket. As this release appears to relate to fixes you may not need to make any run book amendments, in which case you can link to RBREVIEW-172 which is for instances where a review is not required.

However, if you are making any significant changes that require a run book update you should raise a new ticket for review.

Regards

Stephen
PIPELINE team, could you link the ticket to RBREVIEW-172 (no runbook review required). Luke is still on paternity leave, so won't be able to do it.
Please can this now be moved to production under warranty. This is now live as of 10.10.11
Moving to Production Under Warranty
Agreed in Pipeline View Meeting 22nd Dec 2011, that this could be closed.

item.title: [PIPELINE-913] Primary Teachers Sites
item.description:
Project to create a re-suable and sustainable approach to delivering any Primary Teachers content via the Forge platform. Primary Geography and Primary Art will be the first instances using this approach. Using a PAL application and iSite CMS.

Assets stored in iBroadcast2 and downloads.bbc.co.uk such as flash games, video and jpeg. (Note Games have been discussed with GamesGrid and a GamesGrid review ticket will be set up shortly)

JIRA: https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/primaryx

Confluence: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/primaryx/Primary+%27x%27+Sites

comments.comment:
Please can this be moved to Definition and Discovery phase - just beginning inception workshops

Luke

Luke

Attendees: Rob Lee - TA, Luke Tagg TPM

We'll upload the TA to confluence Monday https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/primaryx/Technical+design

This also shows volumetrics

Hopefully we can then have Tech Review on Wednesday. Thanks

Luke

Note: have changed baseline go live date to estimated date based on what we know now. This may be sooner, progress through sprints will give better estimate and understanding of this date
Siobain to review with Platform Eng and FW and set up meeting for Wed am when I'm in Salford.

Siobain to arrange a tech review, invite Frameworks (Ian Renyard) and Mark Gledhill. This looks quite standard but just to be on the safe side it would be worth having a quick tech review, Siobain to set up.

Hi Siobain,

this is a standard PAL app using iSite for content publishing.

Volumetrics: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/primaryx/Volumetrics
Tech Arch: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/primaryx/Technical+design

Tech Review booked for 21 December 2011 10:00-11:00
SALFORD: Countryfile DH-1-MR-04
LONDON BC3 D5 M4 (Dali)

Conference Bridge
Telephone: 0844 4 73 73 73
PIN for all is: 575454

Required: Mark Gledhill; Ian Renyard; Luke Tagg; Robert Lee
Attendees: Christopher Parker; Barry Tallon; Stephen Hunwick; Future Media OTG Monitoring Services; FM&T Service Managers; FM&T DD&O Change Management

OTG Pipeline Tech Review held Wednesday 21st Dec, 10am-11am, Salford: Countryfile DH-1-MR-04 and London: Dali (BC3 D5 M4)

Attendees - Salford: Rob Lee (TA), Luke Tagg (TPM), Barry Tallon (DBA), Chris Parker (DBA team lead), Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager). London: Mark Gledhill (Platform Eng), Ian Renyard (Frameworks)

NOTES

  • Creating a PAL app to rationalise all the primary websites. Initial site will be for Primary Geography
  • The approach is to use iSite as the CMS and create a PAL app which subjects can use, i.e. have the same wireframes and same look and feel
  • Users will not be required to log into BBC ID
  • Will use a little bit of Games Grid - this will use Games Grid as an asset database and use Games Grid iStats for tracking
  • Rob took us through arch https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/primaryx/Technical+design
    o Uses iSite as CMS
    o Electron as Content store
    o PAL app to surface content out of electron
    o Using iBroadcast v2 to manage audio and video clips, accessing data via Nitro (Dynamite replacement if it's available in time) or else use Dynamite to get data out of PIPS (if Nitro is not available in time)
    o This will also have Flash games/interactive quiz type assets, which will be FTP'd up to downloads, ideally would manage all assets through iBroadcast 2 (audio, video and jpeg), but iBroadcast 2 can't currently support PDF for flash assets
    o Links to Games Grid to register app with Games Grid
    o Links to iStats manage tracking
  • The initial release is intended to include Mobile views in first release, bit if this is not possible in the timeframe this may later be de-scoped. As such, the project team will build in use of Demi to understand type of client (e.g. desktop/mobile)
  • Caching: Plan is to use varnish up front and using memcahce to do SL caching of Nitro and Electron
  • Mark asked:
    o Are there other dependencies/sources of data, like newsletters? Rob advised, if there are, they will be in PDF format, so like the flash assets mentioned above, they will be hosted on downloads
    o Have you advised Nitro you want to be a client of theirs? Rob is taking this as an action
  • Ian asked: Have you considered using the Frameworks version of iStats rather than the Games Grid version? Rob advised, that they see Games Grid as better because they need globally identifying, and this will future proof them
  • When adding a new subject, volumetrics will change and there will be some PAL dev (i.e. to do maths, you'll need to update the pal app to support mathematical notations)
  • Mobile: Rob Lee has already spoken to James Sheppard about this. Mobile sub-domain https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-1064 (which is currently in Staging)

PIPELINE CHECKLIST

  • CIS: Required, although this is straightforward, a read only PAL app using standard BBC Systems in standard way
  • VOLUMETRICS: Don't have recent stats from all the sites, so they project team are using the volumetrics from Primary History, so these are the baseline and for the first release for Primary Geography they team will test to the volumetrics of Primary History and a bit above it
  • LOADTEST: Required
  • MON: Required
  • RBREVIEW: Required
  • CTA/Txs - Need to double check and need to advise the Product Manager that this should be their responsibility going forward, as once the project is delivered Event Calendar should be kept up to date with CTAs and TXs
  • No DBA changes

ACTIONS
1. ROB to advise Nitro that Primary Teachers Sites wish to be a tenant of Nitro (or Dynamite)
2. LUKE to check if there are any CTAs/TXs
3. LUKE: If you are dependent on the mobile sub-domain then link to PIPELINE-1064, and if you are dependent on Nitro link to the associated Pipeline ticket

MEETING OUTCOME: Move to DEVELOPMENT

item.title: [PIPELINE-911] Production facing SVN repository
item.description:
A new SVN repository, which is accessible via production (BBC Desktop) certificates is requested so that the Bitesize production team can store, and version control content assets.

Additionally, simplify the interface for them, we'd like to enable the following features:

  • webdav access
  • svn autoversioning

(To use version control right now, production staff each need a developer cert to user repo.dev.bbc.co.uk. This isn't ideal, as it means these staff then have access to all the places that developers do.)

Also see: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/bitesize/Subversion+in+Bitesize#SubversioninBitesize-\New\ProductionSVNRepo

item.title: [PIPELINE-889] [PLEASE DELETE] Things To Do: CIS review for API for Live & Deadly flash game
item.description:
PLEASE DELETE BECAUSE THIS IS A MISTAKEN CLONE OF PIPELINE-853. I can't seem to delete myself.

This work is part of the package of product development work captured in PIPELINE-691.

Pipeline checklist: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/PIPELINE-853+checklist

Intention for this minor update to Things To Do:
Provide an API for CBBC Live and Deadly flash game to provide a feed of activities from the Things To Do domain. The API will available via a public URL, but data will only be made available to Live & Deadly using a hashed key.

Schedule and launch deadline:

  • We would like to launch this update in mid-August
  • The Live & Deadly team require the API by early September

Levels of engagement:

  • Will require require InfoSec approval
  • May require Load Testing
  • May require further engagement with Monitoring Team
  • May require the run book to be updated

Volumetrics and Technical Architecture

  • Volumetrics are based the demand the Live and Deadly will places on the API feed: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/deadly2011/Things+To+Do+API#ThingsToDoAPI-4.Volumetrics
  • Technical architecture diagram is attached to this ticket, and can be replaced with improvements.

Risks and mitigations:

  • Risk: DOS attacks
  • Mitigation: Data will only be provided if the requester uses the correct hashed key
  • Risk: Some images provided in the feed are copyrighted, and shouldn't be made easily available to the public via a feed.
  • Mitigation: Data will only be provided if the requester uses the correct hashed key

item.description:

An API for other BBC online services to provide a feed of activities from the Things To Do domain. The API will be available via a public URL, but data will only be made available to other services using a hashed key.

Schedule and launch deadline:

  • CBBC's Live & Deadly team are likely to be the first service to require the API in September 2011

Levels of engagement:

  • Will require require InfoSec approval
  • May require Load Testing
  • May require further engagement with Monitoring Team
  • May require the run book to be updated

Volumetrics and Technical Architecture

  • Volumetrics are based the demand the Live and Deadly will places on the API feed: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/deadly2011/Things+To+Do+API#ThingsToDoAPI-4.Volumetrics
  • Technical architecture diagram is attached to this ticket, and can be replaced with improvements.

Risks and mitigations:

  • Risk: DOS attacks
  • Mitigation: Data will only be provided if the requester uses the correct hashed key
  • Risk: Some images provided in the feed are copyrighted, and shouldn't be made easily available to the public via a feed.
  • Mitigation: Data will only be provided if the requester uses the correct hashed key

item.description:

item.title: [PIPELINE-816] Things to Do: Integration with Locator
item.description:
This enhancement will migrate all dependencies on Bing location services / mapping to Location Services in advance of the end of the BBC's contract with Bing in February 2012.

This product enhancement is required for:

  • partners to be able to create locations for activities
  • users to be able to find activities near them
  • BBC News to be able to display activities scoped by BBC Region
  • TTD to add locally /regionally scoped local links
  • Internal partners to be able include widgets with search by postcode, place etc. This includes Countryfile, Springwatch and Olympics (Torch Relay, Festival 2012, Sports Online Services)

TTD / LS agreed 28/07 that TTD migration could take place in October 2011. This was delayed but has now been prioritised due to TTD use as events/participation backbone across Olympics.

As the Bing services currently in use as an interim solution do not support the translation of Channel Islands or Isle of Man postcodes to LAT/LONG the migration is urgent. TTD is opening to Olympics partners in December 2011.

Volumetrics:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=28736083
item.summary: Things to Do: Integration with Locator

comments.comment:
Email to Julian Tovey 31 Jan 2012:

After a conversation with Amanda, I see MTK (Mapping Toolkit) which is provided by the Cardiff team will be used by Things To Do. As this is a change to your architecture it needs to be reviewed.

Julian, if appropriate please add this to PIPELINE-816 Things to Do: Integration with Locator - whilst Im looking at that ticket it looks like it should be moved to Ready for Pipeline.

The MTK is already in use by TTD.

I would like to hold off moving this to Ready for Pipeline until we have a clear plan on how we are integrating with the generic locator. We are looking to go back to the locator team shortly with some questions around this.

Moved live date to March so this will give us time to release after the generic locator is available to be used (mid Feb).
Will confirm release dates with TTD and locator product owners.
Hi Julian - is this the correct pipeline ticket to link to the Torch Relay project as a dependency?

Hi Hannah,

The main widget pipeline is PIPELINE-1304 so you should link that one as the main dependency. This pipeline will feed into that one, but you can also link this one as it is a dependency.

Cheers
Julian

item.title: [PIPELINE-803] Bitesize: New subjects for KS3: History, Geography and ICT
item.description:
Delivery of 3 new subjects into the Bitesize proposition (History, Geography & ICT) at KS3 level.

There will be revision bites, test bites and flash activities for each.
History will also have video content, similar to that on the GCSE History pages

Est. delivery date : 01/Dec/11
item.summary: Bitesize: New subjects for KS3: History, Geography and ICT

comments.comment:

Please could you provide the following standard information for this:

Regards,
Tara.

Hi Ali,

Thanks for the information you provided. After discussing this in today's stand-up with Platform Engineering, by and large it all looks fine, but we should have a quick review with Platform Engineering and someone from Simon Stevenson's area (as you are using Quiz Engine) to ensure we are all happy with the approach.

Who should I invite from your side? Will that be by audio conference?

Regards,
Tara.

Sure, feel free to set something up. Audio conference is indeed the best bet for me atm.

Fyi There's a pipeline in to completely replace QuizEngine for Bitesize: PIPELINE-1061.
Meeting booked for Mon 24th Oct, 4.30-5pm.
Meeting moved to Weds 26th Oct, 11.30am-Noon.

Pipeline Tech Review : Bitesize: New KS3 Subjects (PIPELINE-803)
Meeting held Weds 26th Oct, 11.30-Noon in BC3 D5 M4 (Dali) / Conference Call.

ATTENDEES
Mark Gledhill; Simon Stevenson; Ali Craigmile; Tara O'Reilly

NOTES

  • Richard Cooper has indicated we'll be turning off various app servers on the Old Stack by end of March 2012. All products should be looking to move off using services currently on them. Fiona Batson has been in dialogue with Ali about this, and also Craig Taylor has been looking at the volume of current usage across all old stack services.
  • No support is provided for any old stack services, therefore product areas would be using these services at risk.
  • PIPELINE-1061 is the Bitesize action plan to move off usage of quiz engine by creation of a PAL app which will use Activity Maker (being delivered by Games Grid). Hope to deliver this by Jan 2012.
  • This project (PIPELINE-803) is therefore only a tactical solution for a couple of months and Bitesize will move to use the output of PIPELINE-1061 when it is ready.
  • SVN server (production facing SVN repository) hasn't had much movement but has been approved by OTAG. It is a blocker for this KS3 launch, although there is a contingency plan but that solution would not be preferred.
  • Staging downloads environment: Ali is talking to Craig Taylor about this and use of a downloads staging domain. Not a blocker as such but is a very nice to have, we should try to deliver it in time.
  • This project will be employing URL Monitor on indexes but not much more monitoring planned for this tactical project.

ACTIONS

  1. Ali to raise a ticket in IFLTECH jira space so that Simon Stevenson can track this work.
  2. Ali to progress the dialogue for the SVN server.
  3. Tara to prod TA's on movement of ticket TA-161 of the downloads staging domain.
  4. Raise a CIS ticket as usual describing overview, flow between components, people interactions, etc. It won't need a software weakness review.
  5. Raise a MON ticket to track the level of monitoring this product will have and agree with the Monitoring team.
  6. Raise RBREVIEW ticket to track the runbook changes and to get 24/7 to review it prior to launch.
  7. Loadtesting doesn't look like it is required, but raise a LOADTEST ticket to confirm this.
  8. Please link all above tickets to this Pipeline ticket.

.
Moving this ticket to DEVELOPMENT status in Pipeline.
The technical architecture is unchanged from when Bitesize v3 was first developed. Linking to the CIS-510 which reflects that design.
Although new content is being added, we agreed in the tech-review that we'd only be monitoring indexes, and that's already in place: See: MON-855

Rgds
Siobain

Rgds

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 2012 10:30:47 +0000
To: "john@workingedge.co.uk" <john@workingedge.co.uk>
Cc: Alan Moser <Alan.Moser@bbc.co.uk>, Ian Myatt <ian.myatt@bbc.co.uk>
Conversation: PIPELINE 803
Subject: Re: PIPELINE 803

Hi John,

ThE original plan was to deliver revision bites and test bites in December as a phase 1, and the flash activities (delivered by 3 digital agencies) in a phase 2 in March.

Since kicking off the project, weve decided to adopt a new infographics styleguide across Bitesize and so we decided to delay delivery of everything together until March.

Ali

Hi Ali,
Please look at the actions raised during the tech review and provide a status.
Rgds
Siobain

OUTSTANDING ACTIONS

  1. Ali to raise a ticket in IFLTECH jira space so that Simon Stevenson can track this work. (DONE - see IFLTECH-5)
  2. Ali to progress the dialogue for the SVN server. (ACTION Robert Lee - our TA is taking a lead on developing the workflows in co-operation with our Lead Developer, Sean Carroll)
  3. Tara to prod TA's on movement of ticket TA-161 of the downloads staging domain. (ACTION Robert Lee - our TA is taking a lead to confirm a plan around delivery of this element with OTG)
  4. Raise a CIS ticket as usual describing overview, flow between components, people interactions, etc. It won't need a software weakness review. (DONE - see CIS-510)
  5. Raise a MON ticket to track the level of monitoring this product will have and agree with the Monitoring team. (DONE - see MON-855)
  6. Raise RBREVIEW ticket to track the runbook changes and to get 24/7 to review it prior to launch. (DONE - Existing run book covers everything RBREVIEW-34)
  7. Loadtesting doesn't look like it is required, but raise a LOADTEST ticket to confirm this. (See: LOADTEST-575)

There are therefore 2 outstanding issues, both with Robert Lee.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue: The Workshop, Aardman Digital and Magnetic North.

5/Dec/11 - History and ICT will now deliver in Mar-12. Geography Revision Bites and Test Bites are due to deliver before Christmas (TBC with production team). UPDATE - All 3 new subjects now aiming to deliver in Mar/12.

item.title: [PIPELINE-791] LabUK Employability Experiment
item.description:
A new LabUK experiment which allows the audience to receive a summary of their workplace skills and a personalised plan for how to make them more employable.

This is expected to re-use existing LabUK core functionality with bespoke feedback, in common with previous LabUK experiments.

comments.comment:
Hi Karen,

Please could you confirm that this is following the pattern of the previous Lab UK experiments, or is there a need for a pipeline technical review?

Rgds,
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

Yes, this is just like all other LabUK experiments, so no tech review or CIS review is necessary.

Thanks,
Karen

Hi Karen,

Please link to the previous CIS approval, if it's still valid and determine if Monitoring and/or Run Book updates are required.

Please ensure you update the Event Mgmt Calendar.

Rgds
Siobain

Have linked CIS ticket.

I don't believe run book or monitoring review are necessary.
From Infosec, It has been a while since the previous review. Please clarify how you plan to collect and handle personal and\or sensitive data.
Assigning to Karen who is the LabUK TPM.

I haven't seen any mon ticket raised for this yet. Does it need monitoring?

Sarbast

On 28/09/2011 11:55, "Karen Slavick" <Karen.Slavick@bbc.co.uk> wrote:

Hi all,

I just wanted to give a heads-up concerning our plans for the LabUK Employability launch.

On Monday afternoon (Oct 3), we will release to Live what we plan will be a fully feature-complete, working version of Employability. That brings us to live 2 weeks before our first radio CTA, Sunday the 16th of October.

It is likely that we will be requesting a minor release during the two-week window. The only changes we plan to have in that release will be copy changes and small CSS tweaks. I'm hoping that this will be agreeable to OPs, as none of these changes could have any bearing on the platform, or knock-on effects in the experiment. Could you guys please confirm that it's ok?

Concerning load and rate limiting, I've requested a tech review for next Tuesday. Let's plan to discuss it there.

Thanks,
Karen

This has actually gone live but I'll keep in Staging to reflect that there is a live load test due.

Karen has updated to the Event Mgmt calendars to refelct this.

Hi Karen,

As the Live load test was undertaken on the 13th October LOADTEST-468 and the appropriate rate limiting applied via OPS-51976, I am moving this into production Under Warranty.

Regards

Stephen
Agreed in OTG Pipeline View meeting (Thursday 15th Dec 2011) that this could be moved to Production Under Warranty

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
Last updated - 20/10/2011

Employability has been running successfully. CTAs have been this week. About 19,000 participants have completed the experiment at this time.

This will be my last update in this ticket.
In partnership with Radio 1/BBC 3 & BBC Learning with associated CTA's

item.title: [PIPELINE-790] LabUK Morality Experiment
item.description:
A new LabUK experiment which investigates the evolution of morality whilst giving the users a personal moral profile.

This is expected to re-use existing LabUK core functionality with bespoke feedback, in common with previous LabUK experiments.

comments.comment:
Hi Karen,

Please link to your tickets for:

  • CIS: If your existing approval covers, you then link to that.
  • Monitoring: If you add new endpoints, then please update your Monitoring and raise a ticket
  • Run Book: Please update and raise a RBREVIW ticket

Rgds
Siobain
Siobain, regarding CIS approval, my understanding is that the LabUK experiments have never needed to go through the CIS approval process.

Hi Karen,

If the experiment hasn't had any significant changes then you should link to your covering CIS ticket for LabUK. Specifically,
-is the experiment being delivered in a similar format to previous ones
-are you collecting the same type of data

Please ensure you update the Event Mgmt Calendar and also assess the need for Monitoring, Run book.

Rgds
Siobain
Hi Karen. Pls could you address my previous questions.
Planned Go Live agreed w/ Ian

Hi Siobain,

Yes, this experiement is just like past experiements, both in how it is delivered, and how data is collected. So, past CIS review should cover it.

There should be no runbook or monitoring review necessary, as far as I can tell.

The experiement is already on stage, ready to go live (dependent on v2), so you may want to change the status to Staging.

Karen

From Infosec,

Are you capturing any sensitive information that will be personally identifiable?

We are capturing the same infomation that we have captured in all past experiments, such as post code, age, etc. There is nothing new in this experiment.

Does that suffice?

Thanks,
Karen

Hi Chris,

Looking back through history, it seems this is a discussion that is overdue. I think it would be worthwhile discussing in general how the LabUK experiments collect and store data.

If it's ok with you, I'm going to move the discussion out of this experiment-specific pipeline ticket, and open a CIS ticket for a InfoSec review of LabUK in general.

Thanks,
Karen

Moved to STAGE without a tech review.

NB: For your next pipelinet ticket for Lab UK, we need to have a tech review to see what has changed since over time with Lab UK and see if new CIS, MON, and Run Book updates are required.

Hi Karen,

Can you link your previous MON and RBREVIEW tickets for this.

Rgds
Siobain
Karen advised this is due to go into production Nov 17th

Hi Karen, as per Siobain's previous comment. could please update your Planned Go -Live date to reflect your new target date.
Many Thanks

Stephen

Stephen,

I had already done that, earlier this morning.
Agreed in Pipeline View Meeting 22nd Dec 2011, that this could be closed.

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
Last updated - 27/10/2011

Morality load tested well, and has now gone live!

This will be my last update in this Pipeline ticket.
In partnership with Horizon, expected BBC1 CTA

item.title: [PIPELINE-784] Rebrand Bitesize
item.description:
Apply new branding across the entire Bitesize offer, bringing together the various different courses under one common look and feel.

Included are: Homepage, KS1, KS2, KS3, GCSE, TGAU, 1st Level, 2nd Level, Standard Grade and Higher.

We're looking at applying a banner-and-background-type change, in Barlesque on the SIS stack.

This is estimated as between 45 and 50 days design effort + some development time.

comments.comment: is this still in discovery? What was the issue with Chunk?

They's been commissioned to do design work for KS1 and 1st Level - but
before we decided to rebrand. We've had to change their brief. Call me
if you want more info.

Siobain,

Can you please close this pipeline down as we've decided not to proceed with the project.

Thx, Ali
Closed per above comment

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
12/Sep/11 - Senior stakeholders met to review progress and have decided not to proceed with this project.

Previous updates: 02/Sep/11 - Development team are completing work this week to allow [BITESIZE-348] KS1 Science and [BITESIZE-349] 1st Level with the new Branding.

A review meeting was held with production team to communicate the new Branding and its implementation. Some concerns raised by Editor as to possible adverse affects of launching now. Suggestion was made that we perhaps delay the branding release.

Video conf scheduled for Thu 08/Sep/11 to discuss designs with Snr stakeholders and come to some resolution here.
Bitesize editorial staff are talking to Marketing about a big push around the start of the new school year in September

item.title: [PIPELINE-778] Webwise 2.2.2 release
item.description:
It's a minor release going from 2.2.0 to 2.2.2 (2.2.1 was not released to live).

I've updated the Confluence site page (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Webwise) and releases page (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Releases ) accordingly.

2.2.2 - 2nd wave of new features

Contents of release

New sitemap page
Add link types for blog page link and generic webwise-wide link and allow these to be used in homepage main promo
Allow a reveal tag to be added around words in sitemap section description
Replace barlesque social bookmarking bar with sharetools in article pages
Enable pulse survey on homepage

Load testing:

New sitemap page

Infosec considerations:

None

Monitoring - not changed (as technical approach is same)
Runbook - nothing to add (as technical approach is same)

RPMs

bbc-pal-webwise-2.2.2.3-524031.65.noarch.rpm
bbc-static-webwise-2.2.2.3-524031.65.noarch.rpm

comments.comment:
It's a minor release going from 2.2.0 to 2.2.2 (2.2.1 was not released to live).

Confluence is updated (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Webwise) and releases page (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Releases ) accordingly.
Just moving ready for pipeline

Moved to 'On Radar' as Luke advised: "..it's a minor release, looked at checklist and felt it wasnt BAU as it had an update site map page as well as a survey link added (these should have been in previous)"

Moved to 'Development' without a Tech Review as Luke advised there were no changes to architecture or volumetrics.

Monitoring is incomplete as no snmp data for OID=250 were found on stage or live yet.
Can you please update me when this is done to review your monitoring then?

Cheers
Sarbast

Hi Sarbast,

This is now on Stage and due for live 28/6. Please can you confirm if you need anything carrying out from the developer regarding Monitoring. Thanks

Luke
This is now deployed to live

Luke - could you create a MON ticket and link to this one please. Even if it's just to say "no additional monitoring required" and Sarbast can close it straight off, we need it to keep pipeline informed.
Thank you.

Victoria

I am not seeing the updates in WebWise release 2.2.2 on LIVE.

Luke has now gone on leave for two weeks.

I need confirmation of whether this release has been moved to LIVE as I understand that if this does not happen by Tue 5 July the WebWise site will be impacted by the update to PHP 5.3.

Please can you advise?

Thanks, Zoe

Hi Zoe,

Contact the Change and Release team who can verify if https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/OPS-44385 actually went through to Live. Their email address is "Future Media DD&O Change & Release Management" on Outlook GAL.

T.
Moving this to Production Under Warranty as Luke said it has gone Live. But may need to confirm as per Zoe's comments....

Hi Tara

I have spoken to my developer and it seems to be the case that the Varnish caches on STAGE and LIVE are serving the old versions of the site. For some reason the same caching did not occur on TEST so it was not picked up sooner.

We now need to schedule another WebWise release, please can you advise on who might assist with this in Luke's absence?

Thanks, Zoe

Hi there

Also, could someone advise as to why the Quality Survey works on STAGE but not LIVE?

http://www.stage.bbc.co.uk/webwise/

Thanks, Zoe

Hi there

I have been advised that Webwise 2.2.2 went live on Monday 28th June. However, there are some idiosyncracies with what has been released and I would like some clarification on which files have actually updated.

The release was intended to do the following:

1. Incorporate the relevant update reflecting next week's move to PHP 5.3

  • please confirm that this has happened and Webwise will not break next week.

2. Switch on the Online Quality survey code

  • this is switched on on STAGE and has not been carried over to LIVE
  • please confirm that this code was included in the release

3. Update sitemap links

  • this works on STAGE but not LIVE
  • again please confirm whether this has gone LIVE but is caching or has NOT been deployed.

Many thanks, Zoe

Just thought we can compare 3 ourselves by using pal.live.bbc.co.uk

http://pal.live.bbc.co.uk/webwise/sitemap
vs
http://pal.stage.bbc.co.uk/webwise/sitemap

and the conclusion is DIFFERENT BEHAVIOUR FROM STAGE.

This would imply either the new code hasn't successfully been released from stage to live or there is some extra-weird form of caching only present in the live environment that is affecting the pal.X servers as well as the www.X servers and is responsible for all the differences from stage to live.

The latter seems unlikely because the caching on stage:
http://www.stage.bbc.co.uk/webwise/
vs
http://pal.stage.bbc.co.uk/webwise/
results in a working survey in both cases, but it could just be luck with stage not being used much.
