item.title: [PIPELINE-764] Things To Do: Permanent solution for image uploader to allow more content partners
item.description:
Release of permanent, CIS approved, solution for image uploader to allow the service to support more partners. Partners need to add activities to the site for the summer holidays, which a key opportunity.

Here's links to our confluence space for key documentation

  • https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/File+Handling
  • https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Compliance+summary+for+Things+to+do
item.summary: Things To Do: Permanent solution for image uploader to allow more content partners

comments.comment:
We're replacing PIPELINE-761 with this ticket so that the ticket type is New Feature.

Ready for Pipeline Radar and Tech Review.

We've already seeking CIS approval in CIS-395. Does Pipeline approval need to occur before CIS approval?

Hi Dean,
We need to determine if we need a quick tech review for this:

  • Please could you send me a link to your Arch diagram which clearly shows the difference between your last release and this.
  • Have your voluemtrics changed?

I see you have raised a CIS ticket, but as this is on forge you will need to follow all the steps on the pipeline checklist, or agree with the associated teams if they are not applicable.

It's best to copy the Pipeline Checklist to your wiki space and go through each step.

As this has a tight deadline and I'm on annual leave from Friday for two weeks, please could we move this along as quickly as possible.

Rgds
Siobain

Attaching previously supplied diagram and proposed solution diagram for comparison.

Further information about proposed solution available at: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/File+Handling.

Great Simon, thanks for that.

Dean, please could you send on you list of attendees for a tech review, and I'll arrange a tech review.

Can we please have these attendees:

  • Dean Latchana - TPM
  • Simon Neaves (simon@aerian.com) - Lead Developer
  • Ben Poole (ben.poole@aerian.com) - Senior Developer
  • Andy Max (andy.max@aerian.com) - Senior Developer
  • Tom Broughton - Senior Technical Architect

I'll book that tomorrow. I'm wfh today and it's difficult to see the calendars clearly.

Thanks to you and Simon for getting back to me so quickly.

Rgds,
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

No problem. The documentation on confluence at https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/File+Handling is in our restricted area. Could you let us know if you or anybody else doesn't have access to it that needs it.

Thanks,

Simon.

Thanks Siobian for arranging the tech review.

I'm not sure if you're doing so already, but please also invite Mark Gledhill. He's aware of our infosec situation and our plans.

Hi Siobian,

Taking your advice about creating a copy of the Pipeline checklist in TTDR's confluence space, I've made this page to track this ticket's progress through the process: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Pipeline+checklist+for+PIPELINE-764

Also, regarding volumetrics, these haven't changed from those used for load testing the current live site: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Load+Testing

Thanks,
Dean

Hi Siobian,

Regarding the tech review that is going to be arranged, this morning CIS reviewed CIS-395. Is this CIS review different, or the same, as the tech review?

Thanks,
Dean

Hi all,

Tech review booked for Friday 10am-11am. It's important this isn't pushed out as there's limited pipeline resources for the following two weeks to accomodate any postponement.

Dean, a couple points to note:

  • If it does not already, your wiki space https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/ should have a link to the Arch for this relase, i.e. link to https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/File+Handling i
  • The pipeline checklist to copy to your wiki space is just the actual checklist that's found in section 5 of the area you've copied across. It's no problem you leaving it as it, just rememeber to update the actual checklist table in section 5. If this doesn't make sense we can discuss in the tech review.
  • I think you've now covered off with Tara the differences between the CIS review and the Tech Review, but any questions bjsut let me know

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

Here are responses to your points in the previous comment:

  • The CIS compliance page is a good place to view the current technical architecture, and the architecture we're planning to change: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Compliance+summary+for+Things+to+do. It's the delta between these two states that should be reviewed in the Tech Review meeting.
  • I've updated the project's Pipeline Checklist page to only include the checklist, and removed the bumpf: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Pipeline+checklist+for+PIPELINE-764
  • Regarding infosec approval, I've improved the delta between the current live state of the service (CIS approved in CIS-356) and what we're proposing to CIS (CIS proposal in CIS-395): https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/ttdr/Compliance+summary+for+Things+to+do. Infosec are currently reviewing the proposal.

Thanks,
Dean

Tech review meeting held Fri 24th June, 10am, BC3 C1 M2 (Leaves)
Attendees (London): Dean Latchana (PM), Tom Broughton (N&K TA), Phil Lamond (N&K), Mark Gledhill (Platform Engineering), Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager)
Attendees (on phone from Aerian): Simon Neaves, Ben Poole, Andy Max

NOTES:

  • Dean took us through the Things To Do product:
    o This is an on-line service enabling the BBC to promote activities (that are free or not for profit) which are going on around country, on the back of TV and radio promotions. This forms part of our commitments agreed with the BBC Trust
    o Current service delivered in April 2011: The project team put together an on-line product and signed up some partners. The product is hosted on https://production.bbc.co.uk/.... instead if https://www.bbc.co.uk/..., with partners having certificates. The product team were unable to sign up more partners due to vulnerability in partner admin service. So the April delivery was seen as an interim solution
    o Proposal: Move from //production to //www; remove the need for partners having certificates; facilitate partners adding activities themselves; the plan is to use Uploader
  • Looking at going live 5th July; coding is in full flight (it should have waited for this tech review)
  • Simon took us through the architecture. The arch diagram in the CIS templates, gives a view of the application in context of the wider system. We then went through the key points in the CIS Weakness Review template, followed by walking through the arch attached to the pipeline ticket.
  • Consideration for future development: Tom suggested that ACE may be a solution for ACL in the future. ACE manages groups of users via certificates
  • Platform Eng (Mark) expressed concern that in requesting additional Tomcat memory, the project needs to consider if tech debt should be resolved. It was agreed that a backlog item could be created to look at this in the future. Mark did mention that if you are going to be working with the Olympics that could become a bigger issue
  • Infosec will not change until Tuesday unless it's a must have

PIPELINE ACTIVITES

  • Siobain raised the issue that this ticket was created 'late in the day', and should have been created before dev started. Dean acknowledged this point and Simon from Aerian advised this was based on them not realising it was sufficient to fall into the category to raise a pipeline ticket. We briefly discussed what requires a pipeline ticket and the level of engagement - namely touch on each area (Mon, Load Testing, Runbook, CIS) and if you think it's not required just check with the area responsible
  • CIS: Some found it ambiguous, that the project's objective was to remove the need for partners to have certificates was a little ambiguous
  • RUNBOOK: Think about how failures from Uploader are handled. Tom advised consideration on the timeouts on a post to ZXTMs and how long they last for
  • MONITORING: Need to look at if any additional monitoring is required: Number of uploads coming in versus number of uploads failing; Same on the moderation side; Decide if you have alerts or just have graphs so that you can decide what to do next; Checking for flagpoles Uploader may trigger

ACTIONS
1. DEAN - provide Phil Lamond with access to the restricted area
2. DEAN - put all arch docs on confluence (that are currently attached to the ticket)
3. PROJECT TEAM - Update diagrams to include ACL (moderation is currently controlled by restricting based on email address)

Meeting outcome: Move to DEVELOPMENT
Dean, have you raised a MON ticket for this yet? If so, can you please link it to this ticket, thanks.

Hi Tara,

In MON-129, we have identified a need to improve monitoring on the PAL admins. This is described in the 2nd point in this comment: https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/MON-129?focusedCommentId=493779&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_493779

However the admins aren't frontend services, and receive little traffic, therefore we are planning to address this after the Uploader release (OPS-44807), which requires more urgent attention.

Therefore we feel there isn't a monitoring prerequisite for the uploader release captured in this pipeline ticket.

Thanks,
Dean

As described in today's previous comment, we feel there isn't a monitoring prerequisite for the uploader release (captured in this pipeline ticket).

However, for pipeline checklist purposes, I'm linking to MON-129 to show there's some monitoring improvements which we plan to do after the uploader release.

Hi,

With respect to conversation around loadtesting to destruction, please see:

https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-306?focusedCommentId=539524&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_539524

We have discovered that uploader doesn't have a 'bulk delete' facility. At this stage therefore, we feel that without testing our rollback of data entered into uploader from loadtesting, it is prudent to proceed with standard loadtesting with a view to looking at 'testing to destruction' when the loadtest team are under less pressure, and we have trialed rolling back inputed data on a smaller set.

Please let us know if anybody has any major concerns with this strategy.

Many thanks,

Simon.

Hi,

I've noticed that, although we are due to release to Live on 12th July (OPS-44807), we are not on the BBC Launches outlook calendar (details about this calendar).

I understand this is a requirement of the Pipeline checklist (link to checklist instructions), so is this an oversight, or does this just happen when the deployment is scheduled?

Thanks,
Dean

Simon, regarding your comment, I'm just checking with DDO people here that they are happy with your approach....

Dean, the BBC Launches calendar should be updated by you! It doesn't happen automatically. Please follow instructions at https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/eventman/Event+Management+for+BBC+Online (which is linked from the Pipeline Checklist). And in this ticket please update with a comment asap including dates and estimated volumes on the following (as the detail may factor into the decision on Simon's approach above):

  • Any marketing surrounding your launch (including BBC Homepage promotions)
  • Any on or off air CTA's.
  • Any press releases.
  • Anything else that might generate additional traffic to the site.

Please add this information asap. Thanks,
Tara.
Also, have you updated your runbook for this release? You can get Ops to check it by raising a RBREVIEW ticket. Please link that to this Pipeline ticket.

Thanks for providing the information and prompts.

I've updated the BBC Launches calendar and included links to the related CIS, PIPELINE and OPS tickets.

Responding to your points about any promotion off the back of this launch:

  • There's no marketing surrounding this launch
  • There's no on or off air CTAs
  • There's no press release
  • More traffic will occur on the partner admin system because the implementation of uploader will allow us to open to more partners. This increase in volume is detailed on the Load Testing page. This will be load tested in LOADTEST-306

Thanks,
Dean

Hi,

Just to let you know we've improved the runbook and have raised RBREVIEW-169.

Thanks,

Simon.
Dean, please update your Planned Go-live date which currently reads 20th July, as this ticket is falling off the Pipeline View filters. Thanks, Tara.

Thanks for the prompt Tara. I've pushed-out the go-live date to 28th July (date subject to adjustment depending on load testing & release schedule).

I'll add the new Load Test and release tickets once they've been created.

From LOADTEST-335 :

Thanks Dean.

You can go to live on the following conditions:

1) Editorially you inform partners that they should limit their uploads to 1Mb files max.
2) Programmatically, you limit to 1Mb uploads in your next available release (not necessarily for this go-live if you carry out point 1, but as soon as reasonably possible afterwards).
3) All other aspects of TTD are ready (IS approval, monitoring, runbooks, etc).

I'll copy this comment into your Pipeline ticket too, for completeness.

Regards,
Tara.

Yes, confirmed you are good to go Live.

----Original Message----
From: Dean Latchana
Sent: 27 July 2011 15:27
To: Tara O'Reilly; 'ben.poole@aerian.com'
Cc: Tamsin Stubbs; James Bricknell; Simon Lucy
Subject: RE: LOADTEST-335: Method for load testing with realistic data

The following is also in LOADTEST-335
====

Thanks Tara.

Taking each point in turn:
1) I have just spoken to the editorial lead to ensure that partners should not be allowed to upload files greater than 1mb.
2) In the next release, we will adjust our file upload limit so that the maximum file upload will be 1mb
3) All other aspects in the runbook have been addressed. This includes addressing CIS-395, MON-129 and RBREVIEW-169. I've spoken to Matthew Dellowe about RBREVIEW-169, and have agreed that we will review the runbook for any improvements during the 30 day warranty period once we go Live.

Please confirm we are free to go ahead with the Live deployment tomorrow (OPS-44807).

Regards,
Dean

Great. Many thanks Tara.

I'll now inform the live site team using OPS-44807.

Hi Dean, has the scope of this pipleine ticket now been fully delivered? I notice that there are additional Things To Do changes that have been linked to PIPELINE-691 Things To Do: Maintenance & Business Critical Rollout Phase.

Can you please confirm.

Regards

Stephen

Hi Stephen,

This pipeline of work has been fully delivered now.

PIPELINE-691 includes this work, and other bits of work which are on-going.

Thanks for helping with the ticket housekeeping.

Regards,
Dean

Hi Pipeline,

This is a housekeeping call.

Now that the Product Lifecycle Phase is in Run, and the work for this ticket is causing no issues on live, can we updated the Status to something else?

Status is currently "Staging", which is misleading.

Thanks,
Dean

Moved to Production Under Warranty as this in in live and all erquired tickets (LOADTEST, CIS, MON, RBREVIEW) were raised and closed.

Dean, please update the Actual Go Live date for audit purposes.

Hi Siobain,

I've added the "Actual Go-live date" as requested.

Thanks,
Dean

Hi Siobain,

As this has now been resolved can this ticket be closed?

Cheers
Julian
OTG reps agreed in Pipeline View Meeting Thursday 8th Dec 2011, that this could be closed
Many thanks all.

item.title: [PIPELINE-752] Your Paintings 1.1
item.description:
The ticket comprises the enhancements that are being added on to Your Paintings. Many of these were planned for launch, but had to be descoped. Enhancements included are:

  • Audience curations (Binder)
  • Additional data points from PCF (paintings on private loan, painting aquistion info, etc.)
  • Ability for slideshows to show all of artists' paintings, not just limited set
  • Enhanced artist browsing
  • Enhanced searching
  • Change to "buy print" links to comply with BBC guidelines
  • Indication of artwork without consent to display image
  • iPlayer module on Homepage
  • Sharetools for guided tours

comments.comment: Erik, this still has Nat as project manager and has live date next week. Can you amend to reflect current status
Karen/Erik - can we decide what is going on with this pipeline is it still live?

Hi Karen,

i. Are there any changes to the technical architecture for v1.1 (from v1.0)? If so, the technical architecture diagram for v1.0 https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/yourpaint/Tech+Architecture will need to be updated and added to the wiki
ii. Will the roll out of v1.1 result in an increase in voumetrics
iii. Will you require new Load Testing, Monitoring review, CIS review, RBReview?

Rgds
Siobain

Hey Siobain,

For the most part, this version just includes the addition of a few new features. To answer your questions:

1. I don't believe there is any change to architecture. The one thing I need to check is the addition of Binder to allow users to create their own collections.

2. No, no increase in volumetrics.

3. Load testing - no. Monitoring - no. CIS review - need to check, again to do with user collections. RBReview - no.

I'll follow up on those open questions.

Siobain,

Just confering with the indie devs to determine whether there any any updates needed to the architecture diagram, monitoring, run book, or compliance summary. I'll report back shortly.

In the meantime, this project is very much in the build phase, with continuous commits to INT. The status shuld probably change to Development.

Thanks,
Karen

Hi Karen,

I've discussed this with the OTG teams, and we need to have a tech review for this.

Please advise when you are ready for this, i.e. have the latest architecture uploaded, please point me in the direction of it.

Whilst the number of users to the site may not be changing, the changes in funcitonality may have an impact on load and performance so could you discuss this with tech lead.

Who is your BBC TA for this, all projects with an indie need to have one.

Rgds
Siobain

______________________________________________
From: Siobain Collins
Sent: 19 September 2011 12:32
To: Karen Slavick
Subject: Tech review required for Your Paintings 1.1

Hi Karen,

Per my comment - 15/Sep/11 in https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-752, a tech review is required for this:

In addition to the comment in the ticket, Graham Lyons, representing Frameworks has advised "I'm not really clear on the extent of the architectural changes for PIPELINE-752 so at the very least I think that should be made more clear. I've taken a look at their diagram (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/yourpaint/Tech+Architecture) but I think I'd like to know a bit more about what's going on in PAL, at least.
Per my comment, please advise when you are ready for this, i.e. have the latest architecture uploaded, please point me in the direction of it.

Regards,
Siobain

Almost all of the changes in this version are minor pal changes, such as improvements to the search journey, additional pieces of data for each painting coming in from PCF, a new way to display when we don't have consent to show an image of a painting, addition of the SDA iPlayer module.

The only significant change is the addition of the Binder, which will be used for audience to create their own collections of paintings. The Numiko team is in the process of updating the architecture diagram to include that.

I propose that we have a tech review for Binder, which covers the service layer work (pipeline-748) as well as it's addition to the pal (this ticket0.

karen

Technical Review of Binder for Your Paintings covering PIPELINE-748 (service side) & PIPELINE-752 (pal side):
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-748 Binder for Your Paintings
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-752 Your Paintings 1.1

Arranged for Wed 5th October 2011, 3pm-4pm, BC5 A5 M2 (Che Guevara)
Required attendees: Siobain Collins; Mark Gledhill; Yavor Atanasov; Karen Slavick; Philip Lamond; Robert Lee; Jaron@numiko.com
Optional attendees: FM&T Service Managers; FM&T DD&O Change Management; Christopher Parker

Hi all - ahead of the review, here's an updated TA diagram (crossposted from https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-748)

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/yourpaint/Tech+Architecture

Tech review held Wed 5th Oct, 3pm-4pm, BC5 A5 M2 (Che Guevara)
Attendees: Karen Slavick (TPM), Yavor Atanasov (Platform Eng), Andrew Hutson (Service Mgmt), Jaron (Numiko - Indie), Philip Lamond (S/W Eng Binder), Stephen Hunwick (Pipeline Mgr), Mark Gledhill (Paltform Eng), Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager), and Robert Lee (TA) on the phone from Salford

Technical Review of Your Paintings v1.1 which predominantly is the inclusion of Binder:

  • PIPELINE-752 Your Paintings v1.1
  • PIPELINE-748 Binder for Your Paintings

NOTES

  • Karen took us through the product
    o Your painting 1.1 (PIPELINE-752) comprises enhancements mostly small but one significant piece is audience curation, i.e. where audiences can make their own collection
    o Binder for Your Paintings (PIPELINE-748) is the service layer work to make the Binder a generic product and also doing the work specific to your paintings. Binder is currently used for food, this will be the second customer and then should be used more easily by others in the future, although some additional work post this ticket, will need to be done before any services can utilise Binder
    o There are more paintings coming in (next release will bring it up to 115,00) and will continue to grow but this shouldn't be an issue for a while as Karen believes this was tested to a million so will continue to be sufficient
  • Jaron took us through the Architecture
    o This covers the existence of binder in your paintings
    o SDA used to serve all binder info, which are stored against SDA IDs
    o Users can have multiple binders
    o User logs in using ID and Binder uses SNeS
    o DNA commenting will be used for when a user if you want to annotate your collection, give them context. DNA commenting allows moderation, i.e. any text on the site will go through DNA comments and be monitored
    o Your paintings are not using the private notes which Binder has
  • Caching was discussed and this is an open issue - see actions
    o Andrew asked if personalisation now has an impact on the caching? Jaron advised there's an internal SDA cache and requests through the page will be cached
    o Yavor advised that if a user logs in, that's not cached
    o Logged in users are not cached for their own collection, but viewers of a collection could be cached
    o Sharing URLS, could generate a lot of traffic from say twitter, Jaron thinks these will be cached
    o Mark advised that you need to assume a proportion of users are logged in, as those logged in is a personalised page
  • Mark asked where the Binder will appear?
    o Team advised, there wont be a check on Your Paintings Homepage for any logged in user to see if they have a binder
    o More as you view paintings, if you are logged in then you'll have the option to add the painting you are viewing
  • Volumetrics: Expected peak is 2 users per sec to create a collection
  • Pipeline Activities:
    o LOAD TESTING: Ticket will be raised to test the Binder functionality in Your Paintings. As PIPELINE-752 contains more than just Binder, Siobain advised Karen that if you are not load testing all your changes, you need to get sign off from the load test team that that is ok
    o CIS: The existing Binder and Your Paintings, respective Compliance and Info Security docs need to be updated and reviewed. There should be a separate ticket to review each as they are separate products and will have a life past this work to deliver them together
    o MONITORING: Raise a ticket
    -Binder: Service graphs are generic, but need a Monitoring review
    -Your Paintings: Need to look at if additional monitoring is required. If you make changes, raise a Mon ticket to review this
    -Sarbast in the Monitoring team was unable to attend this tech review, but commented:
    Binder is a SL with inadequate monitoring with regards to thresholds used!
    https://logs.forge.bbc.co.uk/tail/snmp/live/device-app031-snmp/1.3.6.1.4.1.30754.2.1.8213 shows one threshold for 500 errors with warning set to Zero
    This need improvement with more thresholds and kpis to monitor it better
    o OPS: Ensure OPS Change tickets are raised when you are deploying changes (if any of the changes are non-Forge than it should be for FYI only)
    o Event Mgmt - Update for TXs/CTAs

ACTION:
1. MARK wanted to check if the previous Your Paintings ticket was tested up to 250,000 paintings
2. JARON/ROBERT: Review the caching strategy and discuss with Platform Eng (Frameworks), DNA team and Phil (as this should also be looked at for Food Binder)
a. Project team to look at whether the filter requests will be cached
b. Look at ESIs and see if any could be cached - Yavor advised this would involve a more serious architecting of your app
c. Check there's nothing on the homepage that links to Your Binder
d. Where/when does the service check the log in?
e. Look at the caching strategy of the shared urls for both logged in and non logged in users. Up to now, varnish took care of the caching but ID was not being uses, so you may need to look at the PAL layer
f. Will DNA hits be cached?
3. JARON/ROBERT: Let DNA and SNeS know the traffic you're anticipating so if they have requirements they feed them back to Platform Eng. Collectively PSP and Binder need to advise Frameworks of their capacity requirements
4. KAREN: To find % of users who'll create binders

Move to DEVELOPMENT on the condition that actions 2&3 are completed by 19th Oct (else this will be put into INCUBATION). All other actions can be addressed during the development window.

Hi Karen,

I'm a bit confused. When did this launch?

Did you complete all the actions above prior to launch? And I can't see any linked tickets to this ticket for CIS, MON, LOADTEST, RBREVIEW, OPS Change tickets for Stage and Live deploys.

I don't understand. Please advise....

Regards,
Tara.

Hi Tara-

Confusion is uderstandable.

Ok, this ticket comprises a set of work that numiko is doing, which is part of a single contract. Most of it is just bits and pieces, small enhancements that would generally be thought of as BAU. Those are some of the things that have already released.

The only piece of work included with this Pipeline ticket that requires things like CIS review is the addition of Binder, which has not yet gone live. I'm in the process of requestion CIS review for that now, just waiting on a new arch diagram.

I hope that helps to clear it up.

Karen
That comment I had put on Oct 17 to update to launched, which I just deleted, must have been a mistake on my part. Perhaps I confused my pipeline tickets?

From: Siobain Collins <Siobain.Collins@bbc.co.uk>
Date: Thu, 12 Jan 2012 17:20:39 +0000
To: Karen Slavick <Karen.Slavick@bbc.co.uk>
Conversation: Your Paintings
Subject: Your Paintings

Hi Karen,

Please could you take a look at PIPELINE-752 and PIPELINE-748. Seeing as they are coming up for release soon, the associated tickets need to be raised and actions from tech review all closed.

Rgds
Siobain
------ End of Forwarded Message

item.title: [PIPELINE-748] Binder for Your Paintings
item.description:
Features description:
1. Further genericisation of the Binder, so that it can be used for Your Paintings.
2. Retro-fitting recipe binder for the genericisation.
3. Adding the ability for a user to have mulitple binders (this is not really new functionality, it is simply allowing there to be mulitple instances of the binder per user).

There is no change to technical architecture, and there is no change to functionality. The Compliance Summary that was previously approved is still accurate, so we are hoping that another review is not necessary. We also don't believe this would require another tech kick-off.

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/binder/Technical+design

Confluence space needed? No
Jira project needed? No
Product shortcode: Binder
Conf/Jira administrators: n/a

comments.comment:

Please add the link/s for the architecture diagram and the volumetrics to this ticket.

Rgds,
Siobain

Siobain,

Just checking with the software engineer as to whether there any any updates needed to the architecture diagram, monitoring, run book, or compliance summary. I'll report back shortly.

In the meantime, this project is very much in the build phase, with continuous commits to INT. The status should probably chnage to Development?

Architecture diagram: There have been no changes to the technical architecture of Binder.

Run book: It was only signed off around a month ago by platform ops, and nothing has changed since.

CIS: There have been no changes to the Binder service that would require a new CIS review. However, there are aspects to how Your Paintings will use Binder that might. I'll address that in PIPELINE-752.

Can we please get status changes to Development?

Siobain

    o Yavor advised that if a user logs in, that's not cached
    o Logged in users are not cached for their own collection, but viewers of a collection could be cached
    o Sharing URLS, could generate a lot of traffic from say twitter, Jaron thinks these will be cached
    o Mark advised that you need to assume a proportion of users are logged in, as those logged in is a personalised page
  • Mark asked where the Binder will appear?
    o Team advised, there wont be a check on Your Paintings Homepage for any logged in user to see if they have a binder
    o More as you view paintings, if you are logged in then you'll have the option to add the painting you are viewing
  • Volumetrics: Expected peak is 2 users per sec to create a collection
  • Pipeline Activities:
    o LOAD TESTING: Ticket will be raised to test the Binder functionality in Your Paintings. As PIPELINE-752 contains more than just Binder, Siobain advised Karen that if you are not load testing all your changes, you need to get sign off from the load test team that that is ok
    o CIS: The existing Binder and Your Paintings, respective Compliance and Info Security docs need to be updated and reviewed. There should be a separate ticket to review each as they are separate products and will have a life past this work to deliver them together
    o MONITORING: Raise a ticket
    -Binder: Service graphs are generic, but need a Monitoring review
    -Your Paintings: Need to look at if additional monitoring is required. If you make changes, raise a Mon ticket to review this
    -Sarbast in the Monitoring team was unable to attend this tech review, but commented:
    Binder is a SL with inadequate monitoring with regards to thresholds used!
    https://logs.forge.bbc.co.uk/tail/snmp/live/device-app031-snmp/1.3.6.1.4.1.30754.2.1.8213 shows one threshold for 500 errors with warning set to Zero
    This need improvement with more thresholds and kpis to monitor it better
    o OPS: Ensure OPS Change tickets are raised when you are deploying changes (if any of the changes are non-Forge than it should be for FYI only)
    o Event Mgmt - Update for TXs/CTAs

ACTION:
1. MARK wanted to check if the previous Your Paintings ticket was tested up to 250,000 paintings
2. JARON/ROBERT: Review the caching strategy and discuss with Platform Eng (Frameworks), DNA team and Phil (as this should also be looked at for Food Binder)
a. Project team to look at whether the filter requests will be cached
b. Look at ESIs and see if any could be cached - Yavor advised this would involve a more serious architecting of your app
c. Check there's nothing on the homepage that links to Your Binder
d. Where/when does the service check the log in?
e. Look at the caching strategy of the shared urls for both logged in and non logged in users. Up to now, varnish took care of the caching but ID was not being uses, so you may need to look at the PAL layer
f. Will DNA hits be cached?
3. JARON/ROBERT: Let DNA and SNeS know the traffic you're anticipating so if they have requirements they feed them back to Platform Eng. Collectively PSP and Binder need to advise Frameworks of their capacity requirements
4. KAREN: To find % of users who'll create binders

Move to DEVELOPMENT on the condition that actions 2&3 are completed by 19th Oct (else this will be put into INCUBATION). All other actions can be addressed during the development window.

Hi,

Were Actions 2 and 3 completed? Or should this be in INCUBATION?

Regards,
Tara.

item.title: [PIPELINE-747] Binder version 2.0 - refactor
item.description:
Project description:
This is a refactor of the Binder code in order to
1. improve maintainability and increase unit and integration testing.
2. genericize the service so that it can be used for Your Paintings and other future apps
Basically, as a "refactor," it was simply an effort to optimise class structures and add much more test converage. There has been no change to functionality or technical architecture, so we do not believe that we need a tech kick-off or a new round of CIS approval. We believe that this version will perform far better than its predecesor, and we are having it load tested.

Confluence space needed? No
Jira project needed? No
Product shortcode: Binder
Conf/Jira administrators: n/a

comments.comment: Moved to Production Under Warranty as this has gone live. Initially PM didn't think this release required a pipeline ticket, so work progressed without one, so by time the ticket was raised this work had already significantly progressed.
Agreed in Pipeline View meeting Thu 21st July, that this could be moved to In Production (Closed)

customfieldvalues.customfieldvalue:
last updated: 09/06/2011

Release: The refactored version of Binder went live on Thursday!

Issues: When Binder was first deployed, it errored on stage. This was due to 3 incorrect SNeS service endpoints in the property file. Unfortunately, there was no way to test for this on any other environment, so we had no opportunity to catch it. It was necessary to roll back Binder (and the Food app with it), make the fix, and then put in three emergency releases (Binder to stage, Binder and Food to live) all for Thursday afternoon. Not ideal.

Next steps: None. Work continues in PIPELINE-748

item.title: [PIPELINE-731] Add Off By Heart Shakespeare Nomination form to /teachers
item.description:
Off By Heart Shakespeare is a national contest in which school pupils compete to perform the best Shakespeare recital at a series of heats held around the country. They'll be filmed for a BBC Television show.

From Jun 2011, teachers will be asked to nominate up to 3 pupils each to go forward to the national heats.

The BBC Learning team propose that teachers will be able to do these nominations online, by completing a webform. The result will include personal and sensitive information about school pupils.

The webform will manifest itself as a new feature on the /teachers portal.

—

This project has been added the pipeline in order to track CIS and IFLTECH approval before go-live.

—

Further details can be found on the Learning Wiki:

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/learning/Off+By+Heart+Shakespeare
item.summary: Add Off By Heart Shakespeare Nomination form to /teachers

item.title: [PIPELINE-700] CLOSED: Primary Art
item.description:
The new Primary Art site will be a distinctive and engaging Art and Design website, which matches content and required learning outcomes to the four KS2 UK Curricula. This interactive website will guide pupils, and teachers, through the creative process of Art & Design, using both online and offline activities.

There are two main pillars to the Primary Art website concept, described below. Our thinking is that the site should be all about the process of art and being an artist, rather than the history of art: 'My Studio' and 'Artist's Eye'

The hero concept of the Primary Art website is the 'My Studio' feature. This provides children with a space to create and complete activities which all lead to the end point of having created a piece of art. In the studio, there is a 'storeroom' full of materials that they can use as inspiration - videos, pictures, and articles from around the BBC. There is also a special 'artists' eye' tool, which when turned on, allows the child to find secret
content from around the BBC's website and add it to their storeroom. This is designed to start children thinking about looking at the world around them differently, just as an artist does - they see inspiration everywhere, and beauty can be found in unlikely places.

For the content negotiation and views part, marked as 'new for release', I'd point you to our docs in that area. Let me know if you've got any questions:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/frameworks/Content+Negotiation
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/frameworks/Alternate+Views
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/frameworks/Using+DeMI+with+PAL+applications

What sort of caching is going on in the PAL app and what headers does it send out for HTTP caches upstream?

Thanks,
Graham.

Hi Graham,

You're right, the 'cached results' part in the service layer has already been reviewed. The basics of it are that it serves up cached results from the API when a cache key for the particular API hit URL exists. As this review is supposedly just for the mobile web view stuff, I could (should?) have just done the Service Layer as a black box.

Cheers for those docs. We've already been through this a while back and are up to speed with it all. It's all working on Test already and has been for some time. We have just switched off our content negotiation on Live until it's signed off and ready to roll out.

As for PAL caching, this again should be covered from previous reviews. We cache in the model layer also, to help reduce the number of API hits (even though they may serve cached results, it's quicker/better to not hit it).

Hope that helps.

Cheers,
Tom

Hi Graham,

In addition to Tom's response above, you now have access to the volumetrics page.

Let us know if you, or your colleagues, require more information.

Thanks,
Dean

Julian,

I've changed the TPM to you, per your note in PIPELINE-1013.

Just to clarify, the term umbrella ticket is normally used where one 'over-arching' (parent) Pipeline ticket is created to pull together (child) pipeline tickets. In this case, no actual work is associated with the parent ticket, all work carried out is tracked under the child ticket and the parent ticket is solely used to give an over view of the collective.

This ticket PIPELINE-691, rather than being an umbrella ticket is instead a ticket which 'does' track work and deployments. As such I need to talk you through this to confirm what is in scope and out of scope for this ticket.

item.title: [PIPELINE-623] LabUK Data Visualisation Of Class Experiment Results
item.description:
Project description [1]: LabUK new feature
Confluence space needed? No
Jira project needed? No
Product shortcode [2]: LABUK
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: Andy Gritton

The data collected from the Class experiment is being analysed by the partner scientists. This will used by an Indie to develop a compelling data visualisation that will be published in the LabUK results section of the website http://www.bbc.co.uk/labuk/results (Seperate to our experiments)

The exact solution is still being finalised but is likely to be Flash based being driven by static XML. We're trying to ensure the solution only requires us to publish a limited number of static assets to an article page and should not require any Forge deployments.

Normally we would not consider raising a pipeline ticket for publishing a piece of content for the static LabUK site, but because there is a Current Affairs TV Call To Action linked to this Data Visualisation we may need to Load Test the solution to ensure there are no performance issues.
item.summary: LabUK Data Visualisation Of Class Experiment Results

comments.comment: Existing Infosec approval will cover this

Hi Andy,

1. When is the Current Affairs TV CTA for this?
2. Please could you provide the url for the confluence and jira spaces you are using for this project
3. Is this pipeline ticket to track the work being done by the Indie to develop the data visualisation? If so, please could you advise the name of the Indie and advise whether they have developed on forge before?
4. Whilst you are still working on the solution, I'll move this to 'Incubation' in the pipeline. If you inform me, when your design is complete, I'll move this back to 'Radar', at which time we can determine if a Pipeline Tech Kick Off/Review is required (to review arch design and volumetric)

Any questions, you can reach me on IRC #pipeline.

Regards,
Siobain

Hi Siobain

1. CTA will be "sometime" mid July is the best I can currently get from the Editorial team. Development has to be complete around start of June to feed into TV graphics etc.

2. Jira & Confluence are the usual ones for LabUK - https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LABUK and https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/labuk/LabUK+Home

3. No, the Pipeline ticket is only to allow visibility of a LabUK deliverable that is on our Roadmap. The indie (Stamen) will develop outside of Forge and supply a static Flash asset with some XML that we will drop in to our article content using the usual FTP/CMS solutions that we currently use (Flip/Oxygen). There will be no Forge deployment, no RPM's, just us dropping some content into an article page on the existing site.

4. That's fine, when we're further down the road with the indie I can let you know.

I should just stress again, i've only created a "New Feature" Pipeline ticket for this because it's a deliverable that management will want to track.

We already publish Flash/XML into Results pages on our site which is what this effectively will be, it's just that this will be more interesting and informative and we have to plan some load testing against it because of the CTA.

You can see existing Flash/XML that's been published to our Results pages via Flip/FTP here:

http://www.bbc.co.uk/labuk/results/braintestbritain/4_brain_training_games.html

http://www.bbc.co.uk/labuk/results/braintestbritain/games/loop_the_loop.html

I have to move this to On Hold in the pipeline until you are ready for a tech kick off.

Rgds
Siobain Collins
Pipeline Mgr

Hi Siobain

I'm really not sure that there is any benefit in a tech kick off for this work, it's just a piece of Flash content being dropped into to our existing site as previously described above, with no Forge deployments involved.

If you still belive we need a tech kick off then happy to meet at your convenience.

In the meantime the indie are starting to work up the visual concepts with our editorial team and UX.
Project currently on hold, TV team are reviewing the TV programme and when it is likely to be delivered. Editorial expect to get an update later this week.
Based on your last status update on 18/08/2011, this looks like it is back in Feasibility so I am moving this ticket back to that phase. Please move to Ready for Pipeline when you are ready.
This will simply be a series of views added to the LabUK site, to show the overall data from the Class experiement. Hence, i don't believe it will need CIS review.

Applied Works has started development work. It is very early days right now.

item.title: [PIPELINE-622] LabUK: Migrate static content from Flip to iSite
item.description:
Project description [1]: Change to LabUK CMS
Confluence space needed? No
Jira project needed? No
Product shortcode [2]: LABUK
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: Andy Gritton

There are no Infosec/Monitoring dependancies on this, raising as a Pipeline ticket for visibility only.

There will be no changes made to the LabUK product at all, this will just be a swap out of one publishing tool (Flip) with another (-iSite)

Ryan Adams advised (30Jan2012): LabUk were going to move from Flip to Oxygen and then eventually to iSite, but decided to skip the Oxygen middle step and move directly to iSite.
item.summary: LabUK: Migrate static content from Flip to iSite

comments.comment:
Hi Andy,

1. Please could you provide the url for the confluence and jira spaces you are using for this project
2. Is the development associated with this being done in house or by an indie? If the latter please provide their name.
3. Does any load testing need to be done?

Any questions, you can reach me on IRC #pipeline.

Regards,
Siobain

Hi Andy,

There are no Infosec/Monitoring dependancies on this

The document https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/labuk/Compliance+summary+for+LabUK needs to reflect the current end-to-end state of the system, thus if you are intending to use different components then you need to update your documentation to explain what systems you are using, how you are using them, what security risks you have identified and what security risks are known, and what mitigations you have taken against them. If there are changes to the document then these should be outlined in a CIS ticket.

Also this is an opportunity to review other parts of the document to make sure previous actions have been completed and there are no outstanding issues (for example "One FTP password is currently hardcoded to the SIS FTP sever - mid term aim to remove this").

Cheers,

Mark

Hi Siobain

1. Jira & Confluence are the usual ones for LabUK - https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LABUK and https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/labuk/LabUK+Home

2. There is no development. This is just a Pipeline ticket to give visibility of a change of Publishing Tool that we currently use for LabUK and appears on our roadmap, so we've been told to raise Pipeline tickets for all major milestones on our roadmaps

3. No. There is no development or changes to our application.

Thanks

Andy

Hi Mark

No problem updating our architechture documentation when we're done on this.

We will be replacing Flip with Oxygen as part of a wider swap out of Flip to Oxygen which is happening accross Knowledge & Learning (and maybe others). I understand this is the preferred solution from Simon Stevensons team. In our mind we're just replacing an old desktop XML editor with a more modern desktop XML editor and that shouldn't change any of the security risks that may currently exist.

Could you just confirm if all the other teams and projects that have, or are in the process, of swapping Flip for Oxygen should be requiring Infosec approval?

Might be good to talk to Tom Broughton as the Tech Architect for K&L and see if this can get covered off just once.

Ali Craigmile is currently leading the migration from Flip to Oxygen for LabUK and some Learning projects, i've also added him and Tom in as watchers on this ticket.

Cheers

Andy

Hi Andy,

A number of new fields are now mandatory on the Pipeline ticket, partially as a result of the PPG review, the intention is for this fields to assist reporting across FM. As such, please update:

  • Product Owner
  • Product Area - I've selected 'NK Enabler', correct if this is wrong

I'm chatting with Mark later and we'll go through your last comment.

Regards,
Siobain

Hi Andy,

Please could you advise if this has gone to OTAG to agree replacing FLIP with Oxygen?

In addition, please note: InfoSec have questioned that there has been no InfoSec approval sought for 7 notable recent releases:

  • PIPELINE-423: No changes to the way we store/transmit/process data since that approval.
  • PIPELINE-422: We don't think the scope of this work will change our current Infosec approval but we'll review nearer to the time.
  • PIPELINE-421: No changes to the way we store/transmit/process data since that approval.
  • PIPELINE-420: No changes to the way we store/transmit/process data since that approval.
  • PIPELINE-419: For clarity, this is a "New Feature" Pipeline ticket and there are no changes at all that have any impact on our current Infosec approval
  • PIPELINE-622: There are no Infosec/Monitoring dependencies on this
  • PIPELINE-623: Existing Infosec approval will cover this

Are you completely confident that your pre-existing InfoSec approval covers you for all these changes? In particular in relation to this pipeline ticket PIPELINE-622, as you are intending to change your CMS. If you are in any doubt I would encourage you to raise a CIS ticket and discuss with InfoSec.

Regards,
Siobain

Hi Siobain

I really don't know if replacing Flip with Oxygen has been passed by OTAG, or if this is even relevant.

The Technical architect for Knowledge & Learning, Tom Broughton, is a watcher on this ticket and he's over the replacement of Flip with Oxygen accross all Knowledge & Learning sites. He may be able to respond to you when he returns from holiday.

The TPM currently looking after the Flip to Oxygen migration for K&L is Ali Craigmile, he may also be able to respond.

I believe that Simon Stevenson's team are advising to switch from Flip to Oxygen, they may also be able to provide more background why this is the preferred solution.

In the case of LabUK, we are only replacing one desktop XML editor with another. How that XML is created/edited locally by the editorial team seems irrelevant, both desktop apps will publish to the same FTP locations using the same login/passwords. The only material differences i'm aware of are:

  • Flip has it's own version control system, Oxygen will be integrated with SVN
  • Flip is imminently about to be switched off, no longer has FM internal support and requires Pearl to be installed on client machines. Oxygen is commercially available/supported and can easily be installed on the BBC desktop.

Regards Infosec approval, LabUK is an established product and the underlying architechture and data flows have not changed over the period of the Pipeline tickets you refer to.

Pipeline-422 may possibly reduce the complexity of our information flow, and as such we will keep that under review and if there are any changes then we will of course raise a CIS ticket.

I am away on holiday from May 4th to May 23rd, if you have further queries then probably best to speak to Tom Broughton in my absence.

Andy
I spoke to with Simon Stevenson today who agreed to take the Oxygen/SVN solution to OTAG at the next available opportunity on behalf of both Bitesize and LabUK.
I'm moving this to On Hold, until you advise you have received OTAG approaval and are ready for a Pipeline Tech Review. Please asvise as soon as this is ready.
Any update on OTAG approval.

Yes, it was approved. Confirmation from Simon Stevenson:

"There is full approval from OTAG for the oXygen/SVN solution as a migration strategy for Flip content. No more approval is required for the migration of Flip content at OTAG level. Each N&K product should of course be taken through the standard N&K product life cycle as with any other product."

Note from Siobain Collins: See OTAG meeting minutes https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/otag/2011-05-05

Moving back to Radar to arrange Tech Kick Off. Ali please provide the attendees from your side.

From DD&O:
Tara O'Reilly
Mark Gledhill
Siobain

Hi Ali,
I'm moving this to ON HOLD, just until you provide the attendees for the kick off. In addition to the attendees, please could you reference the location for the Arch Design and Volumetrics specific to this delivery, so it's clear in the review what changes your team is making.
Any questions please contact me on IRC #pipeline.
Rgds
Siobain

Ali,

What's the status of this project. We have it as still being On Hold which means we are doing no work to progress it. Are you ready for a tech kick-off? In which case please provide attendees as per Siobain's comment above and we will move this to RADAR.

Also please amend all other project ticket details including new Planned Go-Live Date, thanks.

Tara.

Hi Tara,

Agreed and outline time at the start of August to kick this back off again - we were on hold pending a couple of dependencies (availability of oXygen on the desktop, LabUK not having other big launches on).

Attendees to Tech Kick off will be Ali Craigmile and Sean Carroll. If possible, given that we're both based in Glasgow, can we do this on the phone / as a video conf?

Ali

Tech Review held Thu 4th August 10am-11am, was for Bitesize Flip to Oxygen migration
Meeting minutes at: https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-585?focusedCommentId=570910&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#action_570910
Tech Review for Lab UK needs to held

If you do not require a CIS review, please can you link this to CIS-410 - this way we see that you have asserted no CIS input required (and we get a green CIS light on our reports).

Cheers

Ali,

I'm not sure exactly what changes may need to happen in LabUK as part of this migration. There needs to be a conversation with the LabUK tech team.

Hi Ali,

Is this on hold until the Bitesize Flip to Oxygen Migration has occured? If so I'll move it back to 'Feasibility' in the pipeline for the time being.

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

Ali is currently off on paternity leave, (due to return on Monday). I don't believe the project is on hold, though I believe there are dependancies on infrastructure that the Bitesize Flip to Oxygen migration will put in place. I'd suggest catching up with Ali on Monday to discuss the most appropriate status.

Cheers,

Rob
Ali, please could we catch up on this?

Siobain, Following our discussion yesterday, I've spoken with Karen and
she's agreed to take a lead on this project now. The scope has been changed
to reflect current thinking - and I've updated the due-date to provide a
more reasonable estimate.

Ali

HI Ali, Karen,

If there is any work being done at all this ticket is not just for visibility. Visibility tickets are solely for non code deployments (e.g. a contact negotiation) or as an umbrella ticket.

As it appears there will be a code deployment this will need to go through the pipeline process.

CIS - If you are changing the publishing tool you are using, I would have thought this was a change in Arch and thus you'll need to update your InfoSec
MON - Is there any Monitoring currently on Flip which needs to be removed. Will there be additional monitoring on iSite?
LOAD TESTING - You'll need to raise a load test ticket. If you think that this will not require load testing, state that in your ticket and have the load test team review this
RUN BOOK - I would assume that your Lab UK run book needs to be updated to reflect you are now using a different publishing tool
Have you got sign off from iSite for LabUK being a tenant of their service?

Please could you link your architecture and volumetrics so that I can run through them with Platform Eng and Frameworks to determine if a Tech Review is required.

Rgds
Siobain

------ Forwarded Message

Hey Ali, Karen,

Please could you update ticket https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-622 per my last comment, or if this is ON HOLD just let me know.

Rgds
Siobain

Thanks Karen, for updating your Planned Go Live Date.

Please could you update the description to remove 'for visibility only'.

Are you ready for a tech review? If not - and as you are still in Discovery (Product LifeCycle) - I'll move this back to Feasibility.

Any questions, please give me a shout.
Per my last comment this appears to still be in Feasibility (i.e. Discovery), so I'm going to move this back to Feasibility.
I do not believe that this will need its own CIS review. I have linked the ticket for iSite CIS approval.
Updated Planned Go Live date as requested by Joey and added him as Product Manager

item.title: [PIPELINE-616] Webwise Course Assessment Access
item.description:
Project description: Webwise Course Assessment Access - Small piece of work to restrict access to course assessments via tutor login and daily passcode.
Confluence space needed? No, will used https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/WebWise+Course+2011
Jira project needed? Yes
Product shortcode: wwcourseacc
Conf/Jira administrators: Zoe Breen, Mark Elkins, Tom Broughton

comments.comment:
Tech Kick Off to be booked when Phil advises that the design is ready.
Attendees will be Phil L, Mark Elkins, Tom Broughton, plus DD&O
New Jira project has been set up, with Zoe Breen, Mark Elkins, Tom Broughton as the admins. Please see the notification on JIRA-1921.

Hi Phil,

I'm moving this on hold, just until you advise you are ready for a Tech Kick Off, at which time I'll arrange one with yourself, Mark Elkins, Tom Broughton, and DD&O.

A number of new fields are now mandatory on the Pipeline ticket, partially as a result of the PPG review. As such, please update:
1. Product Owner
2. Product Area - I've selected 'Knowledge and Learning', correct if this is wrong
3. Name of Indie - or if in house, mark 'In House'

Regards,
Siobain

All done. Arch /Logic Flow Diagram with Tom for review. Will advise when this has completed and ready for Tech Review.

Phil
Any update re readiness for Tech Review?

Hi Siobain

I have arranged a catch up meeting between myself, Tom Broughton and
Mark Elkins on Wednesday 18th May at 11am to discuss the logic flow
diagram. You should receive confirmation that the tech arch diagram is
complete around a day or so later. Once we have the TAD in place I will
then prompt you to arrange the tech kick off.

Many thanks

Phil

Hi Luke, Phil,

This is now in RADAR awaiting the Tech Review Meeting. Please could you update your planned go live date.

Tech Review meeting scheduled for Wed 15th June 3pm-4pm, BC3 D5 M3 (Freeview)
Required Attendees: Mark Gledhill; Zoe Breen; Luke Tagg; Tom Broughton; Phil Logie; Siobain Collins
Optional Attendees: Mark Elkins; Tara O'Reilly; Magnus Dahlgren; FM&T Service Managers; FM&T DD&O Change Management

Rgds,
Siobain
Updated Planned Go Live to 18th July 2011. May be brought forward from 18th July 2011 depending on outcome of Tech Kick Off meeting

Tech review postponed as key attendees unavailable.

Luke, please could you check in with Tom and advise if he is able to attend the rescheduled meeting. Pls note I'm out from 27th June for weeks and whilst Tara will cover in my absence, if we can do it this week it would be more convenient.

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Siobain,

Tom has confirmed he is attendingthe Tech Review. See you tommorow

regards

Luke

Resources for meeting:

1. Flow for Webwise Course 2011: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Technical+Design+Webwsie+Course+2011

  • Tech Design for Webwise as a whole: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Technical+design
  • Do not have a technical architecture diagram specifically for Webwise Course 2011

2. Volumetrics: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/webwise/Volumetrics

Tech Review held Wed 22nd June, 4pm-5pm, BC3 D5 M3 (Freeview), not possible to proceed so postponed:

  • Salford attendees - Luke and Zoe - were not able to dial into the conference bridge (appears to be a problem their end as both chair and participants codes did work for London)
  • Mark G, MBM and Siobain were in BC
  • Tom was late dialling in - by which time Mark G had left
  • Despite the pipeline ticket reflecting this was ready for a review, it was not. Tom advised that this hasn't yet been signed off for development due to issues with the Trust in allowing us to do assessments
  • Tom utilised the time with MBM to discuss the possible architectural approach

MEETING OUTCOME: Siobain advised Like, Zoe and Tom that this would be put ON HOLD, until:

  • Business decision finalised on whether we should be doing this (decision expected next week)
  • Architecture to be completed
  • As this has been postponed a number of times, the tech review will not be rescheduled until
    -Tom B has signed off the arch diagram and volumetrics, they are completely ready for review by DD&O and have been uploaded to the wiki space
    -The project team, PM, Tom, and lead developer can all commit to a time slot - I can't call DD&O senior consultants and PMs into another meeting for it to be cancelled as they've just got too much on at the moment
  • If this is ready to schedule before 11th July (whilst I'm on annual leave) contact Tara O'Reilly or Steven Butler to arrange

Following on from a brief chat with Tom - my conerns mainly centre around the fact that this site is firmly dual-stacked (with no real plan to finish the migration from what I can see).

From an InfoSec-y point of view, the single credential per Awarding Body could leave us with too many updates.

There are several ways I can think of for generating and verifying the daily passcode - some of which don't actually involve being stored on disk at all, but involve hashes with shared secrets, and multiplication and modulo arithmetic by primes. Otherwise, we could use KV store for each day code.

Obviously there are illusions of barriers to entry or actual barriers, but that's not really a technical architecture issue.

Cheers

MBM

For info:

From: Ian Myatt (Head of Product, Knowledge & Learning), 06 July 2011 22:45
After much discussion and debate it has been agreed that we can proceed with the restriction/accredition of the webwise assessment. We were absolutely right to raise this as an issue, and it has prompted many useful discussions. I can take you through more background in person, but in a nutshell the agreement is to proceed on the understanding this is a one off tactical solution in order to deliver on promises made externally.
Lets not over engineer the solution, but work out what is the most sensible approach to delivering these specific requirements

From: Tom Broughton, 07 July 2011 11:34
It looks as though we're going to go ahead with the webwise assessment stuff, so a heads up that when Luke is back then he'll be following this one up.
MBM, I know you had some ideas on how to do this really simplified, some pointers would be great!

Another tech review will not be scheduled for this until the full architecture and volumetrics are completed and fully ready for review. Please let me know when this is the case and the ticket can be moved back to 'Radar'.
Is this still on hold? Are the architecture and volumetrics still under discussion? Please advise once they are ready for review.

Yes this is still on hold awaiting resources to complete TAD.

Luke Tagg
Technical Project Manager
BBC Knowledge & Learning

item.title: [PIPELINE-607] Nature UGC Uploader
item.description:
Project description: Possible use of Stream UK's UGC uploader facility as a way of collecting UGC for Springwatch 2011. A version of this is already being used on the News sites. Investigations needed to see if a version of this could be used on Springwatch.
Confluence space needed? no
Jira project needed? no
Product shortcode: natureugc
Conf/Jira administrators: Julian Tovey, Erik Upton, Tom Broughton

Platform = Other as this will be hosted externally by Stream UK. The form is hosted externally by Stream UK; the form will be reached via a link from the 'Spring Watch' site.

comments.comment:
Hi Julian,

I am moving this to RADAR on the Pipeline and I have added Erik Upton and Tom Broughton as watchers.

I have some questions/suggestions:

1. Please could you specifiy the platform/s this is on.

2. You mention the possible use of Stream UK's UGC uploader facility, but there is another Uploader in place across the BBC which should possibly be considered.

3. I would like to have a Pipeline technical kick off meeting for this, in which representatives from DD&O such as Platform Engineering, Frameworks and the Tech Architects could review your planned approach and volumetrics. In order to have this meeting, you would neeed to have a draft design and estimated volumentrics. It would be valuable for the design to be reviewed prior to a decision to go with Stream UK's UGC Uploader. If you send me the attendees from the project team, I can set this meeting up. As your Planned Go Live Date is so soon, I'd like to get this arranged this week if possible.

4. As you have not requested any Jira or Confluence spaces, please could you provide me with
a. the location your docs will be stored in
b. the name of the existing Jira project you are using or advise if you are tracking work via another method?
Please note, the shortcode you have provided does not appear to be in use for any existing Jira or Confluence spaces.

If you have any questions you can update this ticket or contact me on IRC channel #pipeline.

Regards,
Siobain Collins
Pipeline Manager

Hi Siobain

Thank you for this. I was not sure if we needed a pipeline for this as this is service is already being used by the BBC and is only really going to be used to capture video for use on the show. Sorry if this seems a little vague at this stage.

1. This would be using the Stream UK's infrastructure outside of the BBC. At this stage I don't have anymore details on their infrastructure they are using to capture and display video. Their systems would only be used to capture, review and download video. Once downloaded it would be manually downloaded and ingested into the TV playout system. There is a possibility that this content would also be displayed on the web, if so this would be manually downloaded and ingested via iBroadcast.

2. I was not aware of another upload facility in the BBC for capturing UGC content that is in use. Last year we used the Vision Apps Uploader but this is no longer supported. Do you have any details of another service?

3. Let me speak with Tom and Erik about this and get their thoughts on the design and volumetrics. I am not around after Wednesday this week so would probably need to be Monday/Tuesday next week.

4. As Nature UK/Springwatch is part of the earth/nature project we could possibly use their confluence and Jira space. We shouldn't really have much documentation to record outside of any user guides and license agreements, but I will check on this. If we decided that we did want Jira and confluence space can this still be setup?

Kind regards,
Julian

Hi Julian,

Thank you for your speedy response. When you are chatting to Tom please mention to him (if he's not already aware of it) the choice to use Stream UK's UGC uploader facility and I'll run it past Mark G in Platform Engineering.

If you find out tomorrow the design and volumetrics will be ready for the end of this week I can book in a Tech KO for next week, otherwise we'll have to wait until these are available.

Speak to you soon.

Regards,
Siobain

I was not aware of another upload facility in the BBC for capturing UGC content that is in use. Last year we used the Vision Apps Uploader but this is no longer supported. Do you have any details of another service?

The platform has Uploader, which will allow a PAL or Java application to securely POST a file into a temporary repository. Your own admin app can then be used to moderate this content and transfer the approved files to a permanent data store (such as deltaorigin) where they can be presented back to users. We'd need to know more details about the UGC (file types, sizes, expected volumes) but these can be discussed at the Tech Kick Off.

From: Mark Gledhill

Hi Tom, Julian,

Only Connect wish to use a BBC-branded external provider to collect users details, so have a look at https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/CIS-346 to see what they are doing, and look through https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/CIS-338 as Blue Peter needed to host some video externally recently and went through this process for the first time.

I recommend talking to InfoSec (Pete Juzl) and IPC (Rachael Ward) to outline what you want to do, talking to Tim Varley (DD&O Technical Architect) to make sure hes okay with the proposal, and then complete a Third Party Hosting Form (http://guidelines.gateway.bbc.co.uk/dq/thirdparties/isp.shtml) which you can submit via a CIS ticket. But it is important to talk to InfoSec and IPC first to get their guidance.

I dont see a need for a Tech Kick Off, but please upload your Architecture Diagram and Volumetrics to the wiki as soon as possible, read through https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/servmgmt/Event+Management+for+BBC+Online and follow the appropriate steps, and I recommend completing a Run Book so that 24/7 Operations are able to react if any problems are identified.

As you say, if there are already existing systems in use for uploading video then that should make things easier, but these probably didnt follow the processes that are now in place so you may have to do a bit of paperwork this first time round, so do please ask and clarify as things go along and read through the two example tickets above.

Cheers,

Mark

item.title: [PIPELINE-596] Create distinct News stack DNS domains on the content network
item.description:
At present it is not possible to guarantee the distinct routing of requests to the News v6 site (www.bbc.co.uk/news), as requests to www.bbc.co.uk are redirected to either the News, Forge or SIS according to a complex set of ZXTM and/or httpd config rules.

New DNS entrypoints should be set up to allow this, akin to those already set up on the Forge stack (www.live.bbc.co.uk etc). Requests sent to the new entrypoints would be GUARANTEED to be forwarded to the Newswww server farm(s) by the ZXTM routing rules. Note that these must only be referenced by ZXTM and/or httpd configuration and MUST NOT appear in HTTP response output, in accordance with standard operational rules.

There should be a distinct DNS entrypoint per each environment tier e.g. Int / Test / Stage / Live

The domain naming is to be decided but could be the following:

wwwnews.live.bbc.co.uk
wwwnews.stage.bbc.co.uk
wwwnews.test.bbc.co.uk
... etc

Regarding Staging, the existing www.stage.bbc.co.uk domain could be generalized to redirect to the News/Forge/SIS staging domains (and not point exclusively to News). This would forward News requests to wwwnews.stage.bbc.co.uk (using the example naming convention).

-------------

Confluence space needed? No - use existing News httpd space:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/newshttpd/HTTPD+configuration+of+News+Platform

Jira project needed? No - use existing News HTTPD project:
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/NEWSHTTPD
item.summary: Create distinct News stack DNS domains on the content network

item.title: [PIPELINE-585] Bitesize: Flip to Oxygen migration
item.description:
Project description [1]:

FLIP is being used by the Bitesize team to author and publish XML files.

There are two business risks to FLIP that are the drivers behind the migration of Bitesize ro oXygen.

  • FLIP is due to be deprecated in 2011
  • Windows 7 does not support FLIP client.

We had been investigating iSite as a replacement for FLIP. However, iSite cannot handle 'semantically-rich document' content and we have aborted on using isite+electron. An exit strategy from FLIP was sought whilst a new department-wide content delivery platform gradually unfolds. <oXygen/> has been recommended as a commodity replacement for FLIP. <oXygen/>+SVN is supported by the CMS team as a complement for iSite where the content model does not fit withing the subset of XML Schema supported by Alfresco Web Publisher.

Confluence space needed? no - part of the Bitesize programme
Jira project needed? no

migration

Angela MacKinnon commented on PIPELINE-585:
-------------------------------------------

Hi Ali,

If we're due to go live with oxygen in 2 weeks, can you please advise of
training as soon as possible please?

Ange

> Bitesize Flip to Oxygen migration
> ---------------------------------
>
> Key: PIPELINE-585
> URL: https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-585
> Project: Pipeline
> Issue Type: Project
> Reporter: Matt Smith-FM
> Assignee: Ali Craigmile
>
> Project description [1]:
> FLIP is being used by the Bitesize team to author and publish XML
files.
> There are two business risks to FLIP that are the drivers behind the
migration of Bitesize to Forge.
> - FLIP is due to be deprecated in 2011
> - Windows 7 does not support FLIP client.
> We had been investigating iSite as a replacement for FLIP. However,
iSite cannot handle 'semantically-rich document' content and we have
aborted on using isite+electron. An exit strategy from FLIP was sought
whilst a new department-wide content delivery platform gradually
unfolds. <oXygen/> has been recommended as a commodity replacement for
FLIP. <oXygen/>+SVN is supported by the CMS team as a complement for
iSite where the content model does not fit withing the subset of XML
Schema supported by Alfresco Web Publisher.
> Confluence space needed? no - part of the Bitesize programme Jira
> project needed? no

Ali, can you update status please?
Can you also please confirm whether a CIS review is needed. Cheers

Tech review held Thursday 4th August 10am-11am, BC4 A3 M2 (Absolutely Fabulous)
Attendees: Glasgow - Ali Craigmile (TPM) & Sean Carroll (Lead Dev); London - Mark Gledhill (Platfrom Engineering), Sarbast Kefrosh (Monitoring), Andrew Hutson (FM&T Service Manager) & Siobain Collins (Pipeline Manager)

NOTES

  • This project is to move Bitesize from Flip to Oxygen. There are 2 drivers
    (1) Flip is being decommissioned and if there is a problem with Flip, there is no support in place
    (2) Flip is incompatible with Windows 7 which is installed on all the desktops in Salford, so Windows XP is having to be installed on some desktops in Salford as a workaround until this solution comes along
  • We reviewed the architecture https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/bitesize/Architecture. We reviewed the Arch diagram in file 'Bitesize v3 architecture.pdf' (39 kB Ali Craigmile Jul 25, 2011 17:44)
  • Ali confirmed to Mark that this is purely for Old Stack sites
  • HTML, Data and Flash compenents are on the old stack. There will be some html changes and re-branding
  • There have been discussions with Simon Lucy about setting up a new SVN repo for the Production. It was advised that this was recommended/agreed by OTAG - See Action 1
  • Oxygen is a desktop client: xml editor with validation which change xml to html. Doesn't currently tie into SVN
  • The proejct team are using Oygen because:
    -It has really good validation
    -Will soon be a desktop app
    -It's a standard app
    -Siemens can support it
  • The FTP client will be available on desktop, it;ll be something like Filezilla
  • PIPELINE
    -LOADTEST: TBD (not discussed during tech review)
    -CIS: TBA (not discussed during tech review)
    -MONITORING: There is currently no monitoring. The project team intend to include basic monitoring. They need to talk to Stuart Lawson's PST team for HP OpenView monitoring. URL monitoring is being added, project team to raise a MON ticket for this Zenoss (URL) monitoring to be reviewed, and link MON ticket to this Pipeline ticket
    -RUNBOOK: Required (not discussed during tech review)
  • Plan to launch in Sep, but no specific date yet
  • This project is seen as an interim solution - the use of SVN for this project is seen as a workaround until all the elements can be migrated to Forge. The forward strategy is to get things into iSite using a PAL app
  • Mark advised that components like Quiz Engine are not supported
  • Note TA Tom Borughton is moving to Homepage, but the team still need to ensure they have support from a TA

ACTIONS

  • 1. ALI to ensure a Pipeline ticket is raised for the project to set up an SVN that developers can use. This needs an owner, may be Simon Stevenson. Link new pipeline ticket to this pipeline ticket.
  • 2. PROJECT TEAM to update the Arch Diagram with
    -Previewing on xDev, refelect that some staging on old stack to xDev
    -Rename Query Engine to Quiz Engine
    -Show the demarcation between Forge and Old Stack
  • 3. ALI to get sign off of the Arch Diagram from an N&K TA
  • 4. ALI to talk to Fiona Batson (Service Mgmt Team) about a downloads staging server
  • 5. PROJECT TEAM to ensure that they configure Oxygen to use Desktop certs to access the repo (Mark specified this as a requirement)
  • 6. SEAN has an action from Ian Myatt to see if Quiz Engine is going in to Forge; check with Simon Stevenson
  • 7. SIOBAIN to see if there is a pipeline ticket from Childrens to migrate components like Quiz Engine to Forge

MEETING OUTCOME: Move to INCUBATION pending

-Pipeline ticket with PM assiged for SVN
Ali to advise when these two point shave been addressed, ideally we will re-review this in a week
Ali, I'm updating the planned go live date for this to reflect that you expect it to go live in Sep. Please reflect update with the date/approx date in Sep you expect this to go live.
Ali, can you please give us an update on where we are with the migration to oxygen? We have team members on leave over the next few weeks and are keen to get training scheduled as soon as possible.

Hi Ange,

We'll have a definite date for training for production and editorial staff as soon as we know that oXygen XML Author is available on the BBC Desktop.

IT haven't given me a date for this yet.

I doubt it will be available until w/c 19/Sep at the easliest (but it could be much later than that).

Once they respond, check there are no inter-dependencies.
