item.title: [PIPELINE-572] Migrate PAVE to supported hosting platform
item.description:
PAVE is an internal production tool with a small userbase of about ten users that allows editorial staff to publish metadata about archive programmes to PIPs. It is currently hosted on the old Vision *.wc servers in White City. We need to move it to supported hosting as this environment is only lightly managed and in the process of being decommissioned.

The application is written in modern Perl using the Mojolicious framework and DBIx::Class and uses two MySQL databases. It also writes back to PIPs.

As there is currently no significant development resource available to maintain this application, yet it is a key part of publishing archive to BBC Online, we need to find an alternative, supported hosting arrangement and migrate the application across.

Product owner: Jonathan Tweed
Tech lead: Jonathan Tweed
Development team: none
item.summary: Migrate PAVE to supported hosting platform

comments.comment:
Hi Jonathan,

I'm moving this to 'On Hold' in the Pipeline process for now, pending confirmation of a Planned Go Live date.

Please could you attach to this ticket an arch diagram (current & proposed) for this application/tool,includes any/all dependencies on or interactions with other platforms/services/applications. This will help the DD&O team assess our level of engagement in the project and determine if there is a need for a Pipeline Technical review.

Please could you also add to the Pipeline description:

  • Product Owner
  • BBC Tech Lead
  • BBC Tech Arch (if there is one)
  • Development team i.e. in-house or Indie (please provide Indie name).

Thank you.

Regards,
Siobain

Hi

I've updated the description as requested and added technical architecture diagram. I've not added a proposed technical architecture as we're not proposing to change anything, just move it to alternative hosting. I can't obviously provide details of that as that's what we're asking you to help us determine.

I think we do need a face to face discussion, as we're asking for DD&O to propose alternative hosting arrangements for an existing application. I'm not sure what options you provide there, if any. We do need a solution though, as the *.wc servers are being decommissioned.

Thanks
Jonathan
Changing back to Radar to make sure someone picks this up again.

Hi Jonathan,

I'm going to ask Babs Oyediran (DD&O Program Manager) for some guidance on how to progress this.

Thanks,
Siobain

Hi Jonathan,

You are listed above, as the Product Owner for this. Will you remain the product owner post deployment?

Regards
Siobain

Hi Siobain

I'm actually leaving the BBC at the beginning of May, but will be handing over to someone else before then who will continue to oversee PAVE. If we get it up before then, then yes.

Thanks
Jonathan
Just an update to note that I will be handing this over to Tom Broughton.

Hi Tom. Please could you take a look at this and advise:

1. If you are ready for a tech review - if so please send on attendees
2. name of PM, name of product Owner
3. go live date

Rgds
Siobain

Jonathan, Tom,

Will Tom B be the PM for this?

Regards,
Siobain
I'm moving this to ON HOLD in the Pipeline, until you advise you are ready for a Pipeline Tech Review (re: my comment 26/Apr/11)
Tom, should this project remain on hold?
Follow up email sent to Tom

Request from Stephen Butler as to what's happening with this.

Assigning to you Ian as Stephen's point of contact from now on.

t

Closing based on conversation between Marina and Ian:

===========
From: Ian Myatt
Sent: 30 September 2011 11:12
To: Stephen Butler
Subject: RE: FW: [Jira] Assigned: (PIPELINE-572) Migrate PAVE to supported hosting platform

Yep

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
From: Stephen Butler
Sent: 30 September 2011 10:22
To: Ian Myatt
Subject: RE: FW: [Jira] Assigned: (PIPELINE-572) Migrate PAVE to supported hosting platform

Are you happy for me to close this ticket then?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
From: Marina Kalkanis marina.kalkanis@bbc.co.uk
Sent: 30 September 2011 09:16
To: Ian Myatt
Cc: Dan Taylor; Matthew Browning
Subject: Re: FW: [Jira] Assigned: (PIPELINE-572) Migrate PAVE to supported hosting platform

Matt and I have briefly discussed this. The current workflow for Archive that uses PAVE is very convoluted and is the multi tool approach that we are aiming to replace with iBroadcast. So Matt will look at how this can be replaced with simpler workflow in iBroadcast.

I'd recommend not moving PAVE to Forge and we'll start the integration between iBroadcast and EM3

M

I think that closing this is a bit premature. Whilst this sits on legacy hardware we have a risk to the business. The ticket was to ensure actual migration. At the moment we an agreement to do it. When should I be aiming to decommission the existing site? End of the year?

Simon Stevenson
Head of Content Management Systems, News and Knowledge
Discipline Lead - BBC N&K Software Engineering

BBC Future Media
Room BC4 B4 Broadcast Centre
201 Wood Lane
London W12 7TS
M: 07714 956690

I understand you'd rather not have to support legacy hosts but I don't
believe PAVE has a development team that can migrate this product onto
Forge. I'm also not sure it is sensible to do that as the process will
be painful and the product is not strategic.

M
Agree that it shouldn't move to standalone on Forge. Happy to hear it's going to iBroadcast - this was always the right idea. Just questioning closing this ticket until that is done.
Ticket re-opened. If there is FM&T work being carried ot (Forge and Non-Forge) then let's keep this ticket open and track it through the pipeline.

So....what's the current status? Who owns this ticket? Can they please do a general update on the ticket fields so we can track this project more accurately through Pipeline.

I can't tell if we should have a tech review to get clarity on all the above...happy to discuss with PM/Product Mgr.

Thanks,
Tara.
Had a chat with Tom, who thinks maybe Simon Stevenson and Ian Myatt could decide ownership for this.

Sorry, but I don't believe I am an appropriate owner for this as I have no power to make this migration happen. The migration described above will be to ibroadcast so it is there that the work will have to be done. Marina can maybe advise on owner.

OK, so reading through all of the above, we are getting stuck in a rut...

It strikes me that there are three pieces of work here (correct me if I'm wrong), and they might all have different owners or possibly the same one:

1) Development on iBroadcast to implement the function that PAVE currently provides.
2) Migration of product users of PAVE to use iBroadcast when ready.
3) Decommission and shut down of PAVE.

I propose that once the above list has been amended, accepted and ownership assigned, that this ticket be closed down and new tickets are raised to represent each stream of work. Do you concur?

Regards,
Tara.
I am very happy to own subtask 3.

I recommend you shut this ticket. Development work on iBroadcast is tracked through the iBroadcast roadmap and each release is accompanied by an iBroadcast pipeline ticket. Migration of users of PAVE to use iBroadcast isn't an OTG pipeline process.

I think the three tasks Tara identifies are correct (regardless of where/how they are tracked).

1 is a dependency of 2 which is a dependency of 3.

None of this is currently scheduled as far as I'm aware.

Thanks for responses so far.

I'm happy so long as someone owns each piece of work, and that work is tracked somewhere. Looking at the three pieces:

1) "Development on iBroadcast to implement the function that PAVE currently provides"

  • Owned by iBroadcast Team
  • Tracked in iBroadcast roadmap and within iBroadcast pipeline tickets

2) "Migration of product users of PAVE to use iBroadcast when ready"

  • Owned by ??
  • Tracked where??

3) "Decommission and shut down of PAVE"

  • Owned by Simon Stevenson
  • Tracked where??

Once the above is complete, I would be happy to shut down this ticket.

Regards,
Tara.

Simon, Marina,

Any advance on my comment above please? I'd quite like to close this down but need to know the work is being picked up and tracked somewhere else, therefore need some of the "??" to be filled in.

Thanks,
Tara.

Assigned to Simon Stevenson.
Simon,Marina, please update per Tara's last comment.

I'm not sure what further comment I can make here. I've agreed to own the last piece but I cannot move forward on that until the first 2 parts are completed. I am also powerless to progress those. Making me the ticket assignee is fine if you understand this. I'd also say it's pointless but I'm happy to live with it.

The problem this ticket has had since it's inception is that no one in FM owns PAVE. There is no FM product owner. There are owners for the legacy infrastructure it sits on (me) and there is an owner for the target infrastructure (Marina) but no one to own the actual product. 8 watchers and about 28 comments later, I don't think that has changed.

I suggest if you need to progress this, you either close the ticket as their is no one to own it or mark it as on-hold. Keeping this ticket going is not changing the situation.

Regards.
'If' a tech review is required this will not required Frameworks.
Siobain to chat to Sabina to see what work iBroadcast are doing for this.

I reckon this ticket should be closed "won't fix".

The ticket itself refers to a change to the hosting of PAVE, an action which, apparently, no one has the appetite to undertake.

The idea Marina brings up about EM3 as an input to iBroadcast 2.x is true enough but not relevant in the context of this ticket.

MB

Email to Sabina, 24 Nov 2011: Please could you advise if iBroadcast are doing any work for the project https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-572. If so what is the extent of work?

Email to Tom 24 Nov 2011: Please could you advise if you are the PM for this?

As this date has passed April 2011 I'm inserting a notional planned go live date. Please could someone on the project team amend this.

Siobain to arrange a tech review or this and invite Platform Eng (Frameworks not required).

Moving to On Hold for 2 reasons:

1. Tom Broughton advised he's not the TPM for this
2. Ian Myatt advised "[I] think it was agreed that this should live with the POD team - although technically they're reponsible for deliverying the supported solution of the requirement that PAVE currently adresses - they're not responsible for the migration of PAVE per se. As no one is in any position to migrate until the new solution is in place."
I second the motion from MB that this ticket is closed
Ticket closed per direction from Ian Myatt.

item.title: [PIPELINE-541] Food Binder
item.description:
Project description: A place for users to save their favourite recipes.
Confluence space needed? no : will use the Food Confluence space : https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/food/Food
Jira project needed? no : will use the Food jira space.
Product shortcode: binder_foo
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: not required as using Food.

comments.comment: Hi Erick. Please would you edit this ticket for the 'Wiki' field, and insert the URL for the food confluence space. Thanks
Done
Updated the Go-Live date as previous date was during the code freeze.
Hi Erik. Do you think this needs a Pipeline Tech Kick Off meeting with Platform Engineering? Are there any changes to Arch or significant code/capacity/traffic changes?
Tech KO to be booked.

Hi James and Siobain,

Apols for not answering sooner - it's been mental over here!

I've added Karen Slavick, Tom Broughton, Phil Lamond and Rory Devane as watchers to this.

Guys, does the Food Binder need to go to Tech Kick-Off in your opinion?

Siobhan has asked "Are there any changes to Arch or significant code/capacity/traffic changes?"

I'm not the expert, but my take is as follows :

Finder Binder - a reusable tool built by the Food team, but significant enough to have it's own Pipeline : https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-132

Food Binder - the only site using the Finder Binder service, indeed it was built to support Food Binder initially. It is a significant new feature to the Food site, thus deserving of a Pipeline of it's own (https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-541). However there are not that substantial code changes in the Food PAL and SL associated with this. #

Saying that, the PAL end points will need to be load testing in conjunction with the Binder SL on the 5th April(https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-147) - Karen Slavick is going to put this request in today as a separate Load Test, but in reality it is part and parcel of the same tests.

Food Binder is a PAL front end bolted onto Finder Binder (https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-132), and as such it's been identified in the Infosec that the Food Binder probably needs to be reviewed by InfoSec separately (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/binder/CIS+Software+weakness+review+for+Finder+Binder)

We also need to ensure we have monitoring set up appropriately for both too.

All the best,

Erik
If theres no objections we should have a kick off. I'll book an hour but it'll probably be done in 30mins. Please advise the key participants from the project team.

A kick-off for this is unnecessary due to the architecture having been covered in PIPELINE-132 (Finder Binder). The PAL integration here is an addition to the existing Food PAL application that will make use of the Binder Service.

Updating go live date.

This is because of the change restriction / freeze period and the need to still deliver monitoring, runbook and quality code.

Aiming to release mobile version of Food Recipe binder with the desktop version too.

Regards,
Siobain

regards,

Rory

Sarbast

item.title: [PIPELINE-540] Knowledge Newsroom Pilot
item.description:
Project description [1]: A trial to move the Nature content into CPS. This is a pilot for the Knowledge Newsroom strategy.
Confluence space needed? No - will be using the EARTH Confluence space.
Jira project needed? No - will be using the EARTH Jira space (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/earth/EARTH)
Product shortcode [2]: newsroom_nat
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: Not required. The EARTH Conf/Jira users are all that are needed.

comments.comment: Update with a shortcode, if it is relevent (might not be as we're using Earth anyways).

Hiya,
Could you include the Earth conf space so we can include it in the ticket?
Thanks.
Hi Erik. Please could you advise does this have any interaction with the apps on the Forge Platform?

Hi Siobain,

This is CPS only. There are includes in the pages that link to the Wildlife Finder on the Forge, but there are no other interactions that spring to mind.

I've added Tom Scott (Product Owner of Earth / Nature), Al Duggin (Web Dev) and Julian Tovey (TPM) who may know more.

Tom, do you expect to see any significant increase in traffic to Wildlife Finder off the back of the Nature site being in CPS?

Cheers,

Erik

There are already lots of cross linking from CPS pages to Wildlife Finder - I expect some increase in traffic to the Forge pages following the relaunch but not significant and certainly within normal limits.
Tamsin, please could you advise if this needs a Load Test ticket.

In my opinion there will be no need to loadtest this.

It's basically a reskinning of Earth News (e.g. http://news.bbc.co.uk/earth/hi/earth_news/newsid_9418000/9418131.stm) something that already exists on News and already is published by CPS.

Therefore the pages will be able to withstand News loads. No problems there.

There are a couple of includes being brought into the page from the Earth / Wildlife Finder service on forge. These will be heavily cached to reduce any problems.

However there shouldn't be any cause for concern. The Earth PAL has been successfully loadtested to 100 SU. Average Earth News traffic is around 250,000 Unique Users with the most popular story ever (the new Giant Rat species found in a Volcano somewhere) was around 750,000 UU. New stories don't spike in the way TX spikes occur (they spread out over 3 days then fade away, with little spikes over lunchtime).

Any include being brought into the page from the Earth / Wildlife finder service can easily be turned off in the CPS admin at a moments notice if there was a rare issue.

All of this suggests to me that there's no need for loadtesting.

Kind regards,

Erik

I agree that this won't need load testing.

Tams
Thanks Tamsin!
Erik, you may need to raise a CIS ticket for this to show data flows between platforms, editorial access points, etc. I can't seen anything in CIS?...

Hi Tara,

Apologies, not 100% clear on what we need to do. Are you saying that

1. we should update https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/CIS-61 (original Earth CIS ticket?)
2. we should update the architecture diagram (https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Architectural+Overview)
3. something else?

Essentially though, there's nothing new here for CIS to assess in my opinion.

The Knowledge Newsroom Pilot is really just updating the Earth News template in the News CPS. This involves a few configuration tweaks and a new CSS skin. Admin of pages published by CPS are, I assume, covered elsewhere by CPS CIS tickets. We're not extending CPS in any way here.

Meanwhile Wildlife Finder will / has been skinned to have the same look and feel for a consistent Nature site.

As said in a previous comment there are some static includes from the Wildlife Finder forge app that are being pulled into the CPS pages. Have a look at the design for reference (they're all in the right hand nav) : http://idenet.national.core.bbc.co.uk/design/knowledge/Nature/Nature_Home/jpeg/nature_home_v1.jpg

1. an include showing the most popular clips
2. a search field that takes a user to the search results for wildlife finder
3. video collections

1 and 3 are administered with Earth admin. There's no data flow going on. For all 3 these includes are published through the Earth admin as static files brought into the CPS published pages.

These includes have been coded defensively, so that if there's a 404 / 500 error, the error templates for them are empty so they won't be seen during the user's experience of the cps pages.

Hope that helps,

Erik

Hi Erik,

I spoke with Babs Oyediran who is a DD&O PM for N&K and he advised a Tech Kick Off is not required. Therefore I am moving this to Development, in the pipeline.

Please could you ensure that the pipeline steps from the Pipeline Checklist https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Pipeline+Checklist which are applicable to your delivery have been completed. I've looked at them and believe:

COMPLETED or N/A

  • Raise a Pipeline Jira ticket - done
  • Jira and Confluence spaces created - not required
  • Service Catalogue item created - n/a
  • Tech Kick Off - Babs Oyediran advised not required
  • Become familiar and log on to IRC on #pipeline channel - this is more for info, you can reach me on this IRC channel
  • Request Load Testing - n/a not on Forge
  • Raise OPS ticket to release to Stage environment - n/a not on Forge

OPEN ... please action any of these which are applicable

  • Add to Event management calendar (if applicable)
  • Provide Volumetrics in project confluence space
  • Infosec - You can reach Tara O'Reilly on IRC channel #pipeline to close of
  • Complete monitoring
  • Complete/udpate run book and email Matt Dellowe to review
  • Advise Ops in advance, of your planned release to Live

As this moves to Development, I will not be reviewing this ticket until it's ready to go live, so please ensure any tasks which arising from the OPEN bullet points are actioned.

Any questions feel free to contact me on IRC channel '#pipeline'

Regards,
Siobain Collins
Pipeline Manager

Hi Siobhan,

Thanks for that.

Ok, trying to cover off the OPEN stuff.

  • Event management Calendar - n/a
  • Volumetrics - see https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Volumetrics
  • Infosec - waiting on Tara to get back to me on the comment above.
  • Complete monitoring - will look into it
  • Complete runbook - will look into it
  • Planned release to live - the wildlife finder includes described are already live. The CPS pages are not yet linking to these though.

Cheers,

Erik

Update on the Infosec thread, after a quick chat with Mark Gledhill:

If its basically a re-skinning of Earth News, something that already exists on News and already is published by CPS and involves just updating the Earth News template in the News CPS with a few configuration tweaks and a new CSS skin, then this implies InfoSec approval is not required as this is a re-skin of an existing service.

Erik said there are a couple of includes being brought into the page from the Earth / Wildlife Finder service on forge and so Mark Gledhill checked the existing CIS documentation for Earth / Wildlife Finder but it appears to be quite old, see https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/CIS-61 and https://repo.dev.bbc.co.uk/services/earth/trunk/docs/Architecture.png. Therefore, we recommend that https://repo.dev.bbc.co.uk/services/earth/trunk/docs/Architecture.png and https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/Earth/Run+Book are updated to reflect the fact that includes from Earth / Wildlife Finder are being used by CPS pages, otherwise theres no obvious documentation of this interaction without looking through tickets in the project JIRA space.

Erik said Admin of pages published by CPS are, I assume, covered elsewhere by CPS CIS tickets...not necessarily. However, if were just talking about a re-skin here, we would assume that little or no documentation would need to be updated.

So, you don't need to go through formal InfoSec approval, but can you update documentation as requested above? Thanks.

Hi Tara,

Thanks for looking into this. Will get those those docs updated.

All the best,

Erik
Hi Erik, please could you update the Planned Go Live Date on this.

Hi Erik,

Is there any mon ticket to review the monitoring for this? Has there been any work on setting up monitoring for this please? Or can it use any already raised mon tickets such as mon-400 ? Otherwise please raise one and assign to me to review it asap.

Regards
Sarbast
Erik. Please update Planned Go Live Date.
Hi Erik, did this go live 13th May?
Moving to ON HOLD until a new Planned Go Live Date is provided.

Hi Siobain,

This did go live on the 13th.

I am just going to check with Erik to see if anything is needed.

Kind regards
Julian

Hi Siobain,

I can confirm that this went live on the 13th May.
I have updated the go-live date and changed the status from build to run.

Hope that is okay.

Kind regards,
Julian

Agreed in DD&O Pipeline View meeting on 07/07/2011, that this product is stable on live and this ticket can be closed.

Project team to ensure they follow up any open linked tickets.

item.title: [PIPELINE-531] SDA 2.0
item.description:
Project description: This is the rebuild of the admin tool. It is intended to accomplish the following:

1. Make it possible for SDA to serve a domain with a large data set (launch partner is Your Paintings)
2. Add functionality that would make it a much easier-to-use tool for all users
3. Build it fresh without the numerous bugs of the current tool

Confluence space needed? no
Jira project needed? no

comments.comment:
Hi Karen,
I see the date has shifted closer - would like to get a kick off sorted. Who can I invite from your side?

Hey James,

You should invite me and Mike Clarke, at clarkemjc@gmail.com.

Just to give you a heads' up, this should be relatively easy. It is simply a rebuild of the admin interface for SDA. Basically, we needed to add in functionality like search (this is for editorial folk, not audience), and the old tool was so horribly buggy, it made sense to just build it nice and new and clean.

Mike's on holiday this week, but next week should be fine for us.

Thanks,
Karen

Sure no probs - I'll get an invite out for next week.
Should I invite Tom B too?
No need. He's super busy, and Mike certainly knows more about SDA than anyone.
Tech KO booked for 28th March.

In order to get versions synced with Maven, we need to bump SDA to version 2.0, rather than 1.0.

I suppose we can also argue that the version that has been live all this time should have been 1.0 in the first place.

Tech Kick Off held on 28th March 2011. Attendees were:
Mark Gledhill, Karen Slavick, Mike Clarke, Andrew Hutson, Siobain Collins and James Burton.

Mark Gledhill gave the following feedback:

The release is effectively an enhanced admin interface to allow batch approvals and search, and a general makeover to the admin interface. There are no changes to the underlying service application, and so the fact that the product is moving from 0.3 to 1.0 is to represent to users the fact the admin interface is much-improved.

I explained that loadtesting (with a live data set and simulated live traffic calling the API) is critical because there have been live incidents in the past where a search box in an admin tool has locked up a live database and hence had knock-on effects across bbc.co.uk. Also loadtesting with a large dataset will be required anyway as part of the loadtesting for Your Paintings as its dataset gradually expands.

The project believes InfoSec approval is not required and so will raise a CIS ticket outlining the changes in order for InfoSec to review and request further information if required. The Your Paintings project will separately need to make sure that it is keeping its InfoSec documentation up-to-date as the project evolves.

Andrew explained that 24/7 Operations may require access to the admin interface in order to make emergency editorial changes. Question for Service Management is this a requirement going forward for admin apps? If so then we can mention this at future kick-offs and point teams at Service Management for further details (about the required training, cert access, admin app documentation, etc).

There are no outstanding questions or issues, and the development is nearly complete, so I am happy for this to proceed into Development.

From: Andrew Hutson
Sent: 29 March 2011 12:16
To: Mark Gledhill; Siobain Collins; James Burton
Cc: Simon Lucy
Subject: RE: SDA 1.0 | Tech Kick Off | Notes

Mark,
Ive talked to Brett about operational access to the admin interface. Hes going to have a think and get back to me.
Andrew

Hi Karen,
Could you update your Planned Go LIVE date as your OPS tickets indicate

Release to STAGE OPS-38281 11th April
Release to LIVE OPS-38283 9th May

Thanks,
Siobain
Changing go-live date. We decided to let the Your Paintings team decorate the content on Stage and the roll that data up to the live datatbase, rather than release the new admin tool quickly.

Hi Karen.
Please raise a ticket for your Monitoring and contact Matt Dellowe to review your runbook.
If you've already completed these tasks, please can you link the associated tickets to this.
Many thanks,
Siobain
This does not need monitoring review. SDA had monitoring reviewed in the past. This is just a new face on the admin tool.

Moving this to On HOLD until a new planned go live date is assigned.
If this has gone live please advise and update the Actual Go Live date.

Karen,

This ticket is woefully out of date - isn't this the release to support Your Paintings recently? In which case I should move this to Production Under Warranty once you've confirmed it is.

Please update your Planned/Actual go-Live dates and other details in this ticket, thanks.

Tara.

Tara,

I don't agree that it is out-of-date. To me, this ticket covers the initial release of v 2.0 for Your Paintings, as well as the ongoing work, getting it the new admin tool into a state for all SDA editorial folk to start using. Please keep in mind, we also have to use these pipeline tickets as the only means by which we report up weekly, so I keep this ticket active for those purposes, until the the new admin tool is complete.

I believe that the planned and go-live dates are correct. That is, in fact, when it first went live.

It probably is appropriate to move it into Under warranty, though, from the Ops perspective.

Moving this to Production Under Warranty for the SDA2.0 release. Did your admin tool go live? If not please raise a new Pipeline ticket to track it. It is not appropriate to use this ticket as it is in Production and therefore not on our search filters.

Tara--

I think we chatted about this before. I need to keep this ticket alive for the purposes of upward reporting.

Karen
Please close this ticket
Agreed in Pipeline View meeting Thu 01 Sep 2011 that this ticket could be closed.

item.title: [PIPELINE-442] Your Paintings Public Launch
item.description:
Your Paintings is a BBC partnership with the Public Catalogue Foundation - "Discover the 200,000 oil paintings you own, the stories behind them and where to see them for real.

Product shortcode [2]: yourpaint

This development is being done by Indies and In House. Numiko is the main indie; Keep Thinking (for the API); others - yet to be determined; plus some internal development.

comments.comment: Roadmap can be found here: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/yourpaint/Product+Roadmap

Technical Kick Off held Mon 14 March 2011, 3PM (BC3 Leaves)
Attended by Tom Broughton, Nat Smith, Jaron Ghani (Numiko), Mark Gledhill, Siobain Collins

Overview:
Your Paintings is currently live with 1,000 images. The Your Paintings project is to increase the number of painting to 200,000 over the next few months. There may be a 'One Show' transmission May 2011 and there maybe spike events associated to cultural/arts events (these all need to be added to the Events Calendar).

Pipeline ticket 442 will henceforth be used to track the first delivery, currently scheduled for 31 March 2001. Nat to raise new Pipeline project tickets for subsequent deliveries Apr-Jul.

March delivery:

  • Will remain a private Beta, it will not be public facing
  • Will scale up from 1,000 images to 75,000 images (i.e. 25,000 pictures in 3 versions)
  • Will need to look at naming convention of image
  • Will resolve some of the API issues

Once MONITORING is in place, project can look at the thresholds in Zenoss

LOAD TESTING is required to test the sych tool and SDA to try to mitigate the issue of the synchronisation process hitting the http response limit.

There is an architectural concern due to the restriction that you can only have 1,000 images per directory on the download server.

This March delivery has a dependency on the Siemen's CDS (Consolidated Download Service) upgrade. After this meeting, Fiona advised Siobain that there is no Pipeline/Jira ticket for this as it's managed separately as BAU. Fiona Batson advised a delivery date should be known by 18 March. Nat will need to re-evaluate the approach if the CDS upgrade is too late for the Your Painting March delivery.

Indies:

  • Numiko
  • Keep Thinking (for the API)
  • Others yet to be determined
    Plus some internal development. Nat was advised that as the PM he's responsible for co-ordinating the Indie activities which feed into the Pipeline, i.e. Load Testing, Monitoring, Runbook, etc. and communications/escalations need to come from him.

ACTIONS:
1. NAT SMITH - Set correct 'Plaaned Go Live Date' for PIPELINE-442, if 1st delivery can be moved from 31 MArch 2011 to 4th April 2011 (as 40 other projects are currently scheduled for 31st March 2011)
2. NAT SMITH - Raise a Pipeline Project ticket for each of the scheduled deliveries (e.g. April, May, etc.) and link existing Monitoring, plus Load Test and Ops tickets
3. NAT SMITH - Reassign Pipeline feature tickets (which were raised following a request from Matt Shearer) to the appropriate Pipeline project ticket
4. NAT SMITH - Determine if there is any impact to the March delivery of Your Paintings as a result of the CDS delivery date (which should be defined by 18 march)
5. NAT SMITH - Ensure all transmissions and CTAs are on the Event Calendar
6. SIOBAIN - confirm if The PM is responsible for raising the OPS tickets for promotions to STAGE and LIVE need to be owned by the PM, or whether Indie's PM (Conran) can raise these and if so, if they need Nat to be the Reporter?

MEETING OUTCOME:

  • Move March Delivery to Dev
  • Based on the information communicated at the kick off, InfoSec approval is not required for the March delivery

NOTES FOR APRIL/MAY DELIVERY:

  • The April/May release includes the ability for each user to create a folder of paintings that they like and then share this folder with other users. I presume they will be able to chose the title of their folder and that, as this will be available publicly, the titles of the folders will need to be moderated (somehow).
  • Tom Broughton to advise Nat if you cannot access the Business Requirements/User Journey's which are required to determine if we use existing Architecture (Binder) for April/May deliveries. Nat/Jaron to arrange a meeting with Tom B to discuss arch (Binder) for Apr/May deliveries.
  • April and May releases should be put into Incubation as the architecture needs to be agreed and finalised. Once architecture has been decided by the team we will need another Pipeline tech review.

Hi Nat.
Please could you update your actions 1-5 from the Tech Kick Off Meeting.
W.r.t. Action 6, Darren Stocking in Change Mgmt advised the Indie PM can raise the Ops tickets for STAGE and LIVE and reassign to the BBC TPM if they have forge certs.

Hi Siobain,
Yep will do.

Thanks
Nat

IMPORTANT NOTE:

Nat,

Please could you provide the current planned go live date for the first delivery. The DDO Tech Archs need to know so they can determine your options:

  • existing arch
  • CDS upgrade - which I don't think will be in time for 1st week of april
  • other

If you want this progressed week commencing 28th March, please provide the following for EACH of your delvieries to live:
Planned Go Live Date
Capacity requirements
W.r.t - 5, Sarah Maycock has entered all the events in the event calendar.
Please could you let us know those dates also. Thanks.

Hi Nat,

Please could you answer the comment 25 March. Tim Varley asked to looked at this over a week ago but needs this information from you.

Regards
Sioabin

Hi Siobain,
I have met with Craig Taylor and Mark Gledhill.

The issues around CDS are resolved.

We have an image hosting plan.

Thanks
Nat

Hi Nat,

Are you still planning phased deliveries that we spoke about in the Tech Kick Off meeting or just a single release 31 May?

Regards,
Siobain

Hi Nat,

Please could you respond to my comment 14/Apr. I'm a little concerned about this ticket because, when we had the Tech Review 14th March, the approach discussed and agreed was that

  • PIPELINE-442 (this ticket) would represent the first phase of your delivery earmarked for 31 March
  • You agreed to raise subsequent tickets for each phase each month until the go live end of May.

This ticket, PIPELINE-442 was moved to 'Development' on the Pipeline, on the premise that it pertained solely to the March delviery and InfoSec deemeed not necessary solely for the March delivery.

The notes from the Tech Review meeting (above) show, that the the architecture needs to be agreed and finalised for the April and May deliveries.

As your approach looks to have deviated from what was discussed at the kick off, please could you comment this ticket:
1. Outlining the delivery content which is being delivered and represented by this Pipeline ticket
2. Specifying the functionality - if any - which will form a subsequent delivery

Please could you do this as soon as possible so that DD&O can review.

Rgds,
Siobain

Nat, Sarah,

I'm moving this to ON HOLD as there has been no engagement or response to the comments I've made, so I have no idea how this is progressing along the pipeline.

Please could you rectify this and get in touch with me.

Siobain

Nat,

You haven't responded to me in the raised mon-392 yet. Therefore I have linked that to this ticket so you will not forget to reply to me. Your mon ticket will also be onhold if this is.

Sarbast

Hi Siobain,

Sorry for not getting back to you, I have been helping the PCF deliver the content (images and data) to the BBC.
The project status is amber because of that.

We decided to keep the PIPELINE-442 ticket for this delivery, as there are no architectural changes that require a tech review.
Nor are there any additional features that require infosec approval.

>1. Outlining the delivery content which is being delivered and represented by this Pipeline ticket

This version scales the existing beta site to 75,000 paintings.

>2. Specifying the functionality - if any - which will form a subsequent delivery

It includes two new page templates, "Galleries" and "Guided Tours"
It also includes design revisions to the existing pages based on expert testing feedback.

Please take this ticket off hold.

Thanks
Nat

Hi Sarbast,

I passed the questions to Mon ticket mon-392 over to the 3rd Party supplier (Numiko) when you raised them.

I will chase them in due course, but Monitoring is currently low down on the priorities list, due to the unexpected issues with content delivery.

Monitoring may have to be addressed in a patch release, I have a patch release booked for the 16th June. Let me know if that will be a problem.

Thanks
Nat
Soft launch date delayed due to data issues.

Two meetings were held today to discuss this project:

  • Chat with Nat and Erik at Super Surgery Tue 7th June 2pm to see the current status of the project and review the notes taken in the Technical Kick Off held Mon 14 March 2011
  • Meeting held BC3 A6 Coffee Hub, Tom Brought, Nat Smith; Erik Upton; Foluso Aloko; Mark Gledhill; Siobain Collins

NOTES from 1st mtg
Due to the late delivery of images to the BBC, there were not incremental deliveries of this project from March, as had been discussed in the Kick Off
As a result, PIPELINE-442 now represents the June delivery with
4 versions of 75,000 images - total 300,000 files
This is no longer a private beta launch but a public launch, available from 16th June, but not expected to have high traffic until the promos 23rd June
Following the initial 75,00 unique images for June 2011, there will be 12,000 additional unique images delivered each month. So it will take until 2013 for the full content to be available, i.e 200,000 unique images (with 4 versions of each, totalling 800,000 images).
Nat advised InfoSec is covered by previous approval
Naming convention of image is resolved with all image filenames now in lower case
There is no longer a dependency on the Siemen's CDS (Consolidated Download Service) upgrade as it has been agreed that Your Paintings will be on Delta Origin. As a result the capacity issues with CDS discussed in the kick off meeting are no longer applicable
Images come off deltaorigin and proxed through from static bbc.co.uk
The April/May discussed where each user creates a folder of paintings that they like and then share - this will be covered by Binder in the July delivery

NOTES from 2nd mtg
Deep Zoom (applicable to approximately 10% of the pictures) will be part of July release, unless Nat and Erik can obtain agreement from Craig that is can go into the June release
Tom B expressed some concerns about the quality of data but as this is externally provided to use there is probably not much we can do
Mark agreed to leave audio slide show on delta origin rather than downloads

ACTIONS
From Tech Kick off
1. CLOSED - Planned Go Live date is 16th June
2. CLOSED - No longer applicable to raise ticket for incremental deliveries; tickets for ancillary task (monitoring, load testing, etc) have been raised and are now linked
3. CLOSED - Wrongly linked pipeline tickets are now unlinked
4. CLOSED - Not longer applicable as Nat advised that Craig Taylor agreed to use Delta Origin instead of the CDS
4. CLOSED - Nat updated the Svc Mgmt calendar
5. CLOSED - Darren advised it's ok for indie TPM or developer to raise OPS tickets for promotions to STAGE and LIVE

From 1st mtg today
6. NAT to raise a new pipeline ticket to track the mid-July delivery which includes Binder (which will need updated tech Arch diagram, a tech review, InfoSec, etc.)
7. will be raised to track the subsequent release which will b
8. NAT to follow up with Numiko, to update monitoring
9. NAT and ERIK to review the results of load testing that was done and ensure there were 100 'simultaneous' requests and that filters were load tested (as with SDA)
10. NAT to ensure load testing of the sych tool and SDA has been done to try to mitigate the issue of the synchronisation process hitting the http response limit.

From 2nd mtg today
11. NAT to ensure the cache headers are set and working correctly
12. TOM to update the arch diagram to change static.bbc.co.uk to static.bbci.co.uk and add a key to the diagram
13. NAT/TOM update wiki and Runbook with Tom's diagram (replace older version)
14. NAT to check the proxy and cache for audio slide show

MEETING OUTCOME: Move back to DEVELOPMENT (agreed in 2nd mtg)
ACTION 6 CLOSED: NAT raised PIPELINE-752 to track delivery mid-July delivery which includes Binder
ACTION 9 CLOSED; Erik and I have reviewed the load testing, as we have decided to book load testing for both the SDA service layer and the Your Paintings PAL.
Here is the SDA load testing ticket.
Link to load test of SDA

I have linked to the SDA and PAL load testing ticket.
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-284
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/LOADTEST-285

comment 12 and 13: complete https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/yourpaint/Tech+Architecture

Siobain, there's another action for Nat/Numiko and that's to update the runbook with appropriate content update.
This looks like this is going live imminently, so I'm moving this to a Staging status. Please advise if otherwise.
Hi Nat, if the go live date has slipped, please reflect it in this ticket.

NB:
Due to the commitments this project has made (to editorial, etc) and the press launch which has a fixed date, we (DD&O) are endevouring to assist as much as we can. However, there are some fundamental tasks that are blocking this project, which the project team need to resolve if they hope to meet their date:

LOADTEST - Please see LoadTest ticket for more information but in brief:
-Project team need to determine their endpoints and have Tom Broughton sign them off BEFORE it's possible to LoadTest this - i.e. this cannot be scripted without endpoints

item.title: [PIPELINE-440] CLOSED: Primary Geography
item.description:
Project description [1]: Project to consolidate the disparate Primary Geography content into an exciting, engaging and effective new site on the Forge platform.
Confluence space needed? yes
Jira project needed? yes
Product shortcode [2]: primgeog
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: Paul Owens, Luke Tagg

comments.comment: Jira and confluence spaces requested.

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/primgeog/Primary+Geography
https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PRIMGEOG

Your new project space is now ready:

You are a space/project administrator for this project.

In Confluence:

  • the space has been added to the 'news' and 'knowledge' "teams", visible here: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/dashboard.action?spacesSelectedTab=team You can remove these "team" designations or create additional "teams", using Browse > Space Admin > Space labels > Team labels.
  • the product has been classified as "Forge" and will now appear on the appropriate 'product' page; see the Products drop-down on the black top nav.

In Jira:

  • the project has been set up using the Agile config. If you wish to change this, please tell us before you start creating tickets.
  • the project was NOT assigned to the any category, visible in the left nav here: https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/secure/BrowseProjects.jspa?selectedCategory=all

Please advise us which category to use - see https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/jira/Project+Categories+in+Jira

As a Jira/Confluence admin you have the power to add/remove people from this project/space.
Please read the FAQs

  • Jira Admin: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/jira/Jira+FAQ
  • Confluence Space Admin: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/confluence/Confluence+Space+Administrator+tasks

Do not change the default permissions for the group "confluence-users". If you want people in your group to be able to delete pages and attachments, you must grant them those permissions individually.

Additional guidance notes on usage are at:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Jira
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Confluence

We also have a mailing list for users of the Forge workflow tools (Confluence, Jira & Greenhopper).
We invite you to join if you haven't already done so:
https://lists.forge.bbc.co.uk/mailman/listinfo/workflow-tools

Any problems using the space, please let me or any member of the doc team know (it's helpful if you could raise a ticket in Jira (JIRA) or Documentation (DOCU) projects). Pipeline queries should still go to Tara, James or Siobain. Note: even if you are not building your product on Forge, if your new application depends on Forge-built products such as Identity you should discuss your design with the Pipeline group to avoid delays at launch.

cheers
Kathleen

item.title: [PIPELINE-439] History: Royal Weddings
item.description:
Project description: This microsite explores the history of royal weddings in the UK. It is simply a new set of resources that will be added on the History domain in SDA.
Confluence space needed? no
Jira project needed? no

NOTE: Technically, this is just a couple of additional features in the History pal app. These features are already done in HPE, there is no new development happening. Therefore, load testing and CIS approval should not be necessary.

comments.comment:
Have these feature already been tested for the HPE release?
You'll need to reference the infosec approval for this and also raise a load test ticket so the team are aware of this release too.

To be honest, James, this is extremely minor work that would not in the past have warranted a pipeline ticket. The only reason that I have created one is that these pages are significant from a BUSINESS perspective, and PIpeline tickets are now the means by which upper management keep track of projects.

You'll still need to reference the infosec approval as this is a change in functionality to the History pal app. This shouldn't be an issue if its already been signed off for HPE.
Also, as this History release is for the Royal Wedding it may see increased traffic, so we'll need to make sure Load Test are happy with proposed volumes..
I am linking the InfoSec ticket from Human Planet Explorer.

Hi Karen,
Just so there isn't any confusion when it comes to infosec approval, please can you raise a CIS ticket specifically for History and reference in that ticket the approval gained for this functionality change.
It would just make everything clear what approval is gained for what application as HPE is a different app from History even though it uses the same architecture.
Thanks...
According to the OPS ticket, this was promoted to Live 14th March
Move to closed as has been in 'Production Under Warranty' for >1 month, no issues noted on ticket.

item.description:

Newsletter: http://www.test.bbc.co.uk/webwise/newsletter/

  • Load testing - TBD
  • Monitoring - not changed (as technical approach is same)
  • Runbook - nothing to add (as technical approach is same)

comments.comment:
Phil,
Is this a duplicate ticket of PIPELINE-413?
No this is different. 413 is a new course. This is an AV page etc. They are being released at different times (this one first).

Hi James

No, I discussed this with Siobain yesterday, I believe this is release
2.1 which is the second phase of the forge migration which is a separate
piece of work from the Webwise Course.

Webwise Forge Migration is now live and was Pipeline 187.

I think the confluence/pipeline entries/tickets are a bit confusing so I
will need to check with Zoe and John Alden as Confluence states release
2.0 is live yet Manish notes says that Phase 2 should kick off post
Phase 1 launch which would be pipeline 187. This could be a handover
miscommuncation, I will need to check with Zoe and John.

Regards

Phil

Just to confirm:

Version 2.0 is live on forge (version 1.0 was the old stack release of webwise).

The forge phase 2 thing (which would be version 3.0 I guess) was an intention to move webwise content management to isite, but it has since emerged that iSite is not up to the job so I suspect forge phase 2 will never actually happen.

So release 2.1 should NOT be quoted as a forge migration phase 2 but just as an additional enhancement to version 2.0 live service currently on Forge.

Important note with respect to Webwise versioning/phased deliveries (from mails between Phil Logie and John Alden):

Webwise - Release 2.1 PIPELINE-436 Due 16th March
======================================================
PIPELINE-187 covered the migration of Webwise from Old Stack to Forge.
PIPELINE-436 covers some features not included in 187, which now need to be migrated to Forge.

Webwise PCourse PIPELINE-413 Due 19th April
====================================================
PIPELINE-413 is an enhancement to the Webwise site and more specifically to the Webwise courses. This commission is for a new version of the course and online accreditation.

Hi John, Phil,

Please could you briefly summarise the development which is covered by this ticket. Probably don't need a Tech KO but needs to be run past Platform Eng for their visibility.

Remaining Pipeline Actions:
1. I would expect you need to raise a new Load Test ticket, can reference LOADTEST-94 which was used for PIPELINE-187. You can decide with the Load Test team the extend of testing required.
2. Run book for Webwise to be updated or if not required please add a note to this ticket.
3. Monitoring ticket to be raised or if not required please add a note to this ticket.
4. Please raise an Infosec ticket. Infosec probably not needed but this will open the conversation and give the Infosec team the opportunity to see if it is/isn't needed.

On Friday 4th March, John Alden wrote:

Hi Phil

The 2.1 build of webwise (containing new newsletter and AV page and link to the new Blog) is on the forge test environment:

https://www.test.bbc.co.uk/webwise/

awaiting editorial feedback such as any last wording tweaks and Tarik preparing populating the XML document for the AV page.

Apparently Zoe is away until Tuesday so I doubt much more will happen until then.

Once shes fed back any last tweaks, weve implemented these and shes approved we can give you the RPM version numbers for the forge release.

Regards,

John

Just checking if this should have a tech review?
If there any architectural dependencies and expected increases in traffic which require a tech review with Platform Eng or any DD&O representative, please advise.
Otherwise I'll move it out of Incubation.

Email thread:

Phil Logie to John Alden (11 March 2011 13:18)
...just a quick mail to gauge where we are with this piece of work in the forge process. I raised a load test ticket last week, will we need to raise any additional tickets at this stage as I am unsure as to how full a forge process we need to follow for a release of this kind?

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Were all ready to go.
Weve done Zoes last tweaks today so the RPM numbers Zoe has just sent you should be ready for the release to the forge stage environment.
Id assume this would be a minor forge release process.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Phil Logie to Siobain Collins (11 March 2011 15:26)
Looks as we are now ready to progress this to Stage, John has mentioned that his will be a 'minor' forge release process. I will raise an ops stage ticket now if it is appropriate?

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Phil, go ahead and raise your OPS ticket for STAGE

Phil/John, please update this pipeline ticket stating:

Load testing required - Yes/No?
Monitoring inserted/updated - Yes/No?
Runbook created/updated - Yes/No?
InfoSec required - Yes/No?

I don't have permission to edit the ticket, so I'll have to give you the info in a comment:

  • Load testing - not vital (identical technical approach == similar performance) but if you like you could load test the new AV and newsletter pages. Your call.
    • AV page: http://www.test.bbc.co.uk/webwise/video-and-audio/
    • Newsletter: http://www.test.bbc.co.uk/webwise/newsletter/
  • Monitoring - not changed (as technical approach is same)
  • Runbook - nothing to add (as technical approach is same)

Tamsin.stubbs@bbc.co.uk

item.title: [PIPELINE-431] First Click Friends - an enhancement to the BBC Connect First Click website
item.description:
Project description [1]: A further enhancement to the BBC Connect First Click service (brief to follow).
Confluence space needed? no
Jira project needed? no
Product shortcode [2]: n/a old stack
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: None

In house development (Lead Dev Rob Kerr)
item.summary: First Click Friends - an enhancement to the BBC Connect First Click website

comments.comment: Awaiting full brief from the BBC Connect team

Project Brief from Ann Hutchings (BBC Producer): The First Click Friends website will be part of BBC Connect, providing an easy guide to helping a friend, relative or neighbour get online. It will support the volunteer, providing a portal for the best learning material from the BBC and its key partners. The site will use the First Click friends template and consist of approximately 10 pages (using 3 different template designs).

Phil L has requested additional info, e.g. how they are going to provide the solution, just a couple lines, e.g. we are adding a new application, or enhancing an existing application and where their end points are. Could you also check it's on SIS, James thought BBC Connect was on Forge.

Updated brief received from Ann Hutchings (BBC Producer):

Following on from the First Click campaign of getting people online and the related website (providing resources for people to learn about computers and build their confidence online). First Click Friends is aimed at volunteers to teach their friends and family how to get online. The website will provide a set of teaching resources for the volunteer, including links to the best learning material from the BBC and its key partners.

The site (of approximately 10 pages) will sit under Connect, and use the First Click templates. It will include two learning resource packs for the volunteer to print out and teach step-by-step, video case-studies to inspire the beginner and a set of articles to help aid the volunteer.

Ann Hutchings has requested the following:

We would like to have the new URL http://www.bbc.co.uk/firstclickfriends

and then create a redirect to where the site will sit at - http://www.bbc.co.uk/connect/campaigns/firstclickfriends.shtml

currently for first click we have:

http://www.bbc.co.uk/firstclick

and

http://www.bbc.co.uk/connect/campaigns/first_click.shtml
Please could you confirm if this is on Old Stack, as BBC Connect resides on Forge per Pipeline ticket 26 https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-26
Please could we see an arch diagram for this to understand the relationship between this project on old stack and BBC Connect which resides on Forge.
Ticket on hold, awaiting feedback from arch design discussion.

Additional information request forwarded to First Click Friends editorial team to clarify why this service needs to be hosted on the old stack. Tom Broughton(TA)providing assistance in putting together an arch diargram (Tom's questions below, answers from editorial):

Q: Can you explain in more detail why this has been developed for old stack?
A: First click and first click friends were too complex for the Forge templates.
Connect will be on Forge

Q: Also, can you give me a brief on the feature set of firstclickfriends, it's shelf life etc?
A: Indefinitely.

Q: What is the current stage of the project too?
A: The design phase has finished and ready for build.
Please advise if any updates been received re: Arch Design

Tom Broughton attended a dev review meeting yesterday, he confirmed that the reasoning for First Click Friends to remain on old stack as per First Click parent site is acceptable for this release. We are looking to migrate First Click to forge post launch and will be advised by editorial as to when this is likely to be scheduled as a piece of work.
Tech review was deemed not required as this was an extension of First Click
Thought this went live 27th April, but there was a miscommunication and it's now due to go live Thu 5th May.

Agreed in DD&O Pipeline View meeting 16Jun, that this can be closed.
Project team to ensure they follow up any open linked tickets.

Siobain

Karen Slavick is now the TPM on LabUK, I have moved to CPS.

Cheers

Andy

Hi Karen,

Siobain

Hi Karen,

Please could you address the previous comment.
If this hasn't gone live yet then please correct the Planned Go Live Date, else it falls off our reports.
Once it does go live, please populate the 'Actual Go Live Date'

Siobain,

Just opened a monitoring review ticket. Although, since everything was for the most part copied over from v1 to v2, I'm hoping it will be an easy one.

Hi Karen,
As 'OPS-46400 LabUK Release (Belfast) To LIVE' got rolled back, is this only live after it goes up again or is it not integral to the core.
Rgds
Siobain

Siobain,

To answer your last question, v2 was indeed rolled back to v1 on live because of errors and blank pages. Thus, it has still not gone live.

We are hoping we've fixed the issues, and will be live early next week (around 20 Sep).

Thanks,
Karen

Siobain,

Just confirming with the team whether there are any updates needed to the architecture diagram, monitoring, run book, or compliance summary. I don't expect that there are, but want to be 100% sure.

Thanks,
Karen

If architecture diagram, monitoring, run book, CIS are n/a I need a statement why.
In particular 247 are interested in knowing what has changed.

Karen confirmed this has gone live, however, there are problems with Rate Limiting.
This probably should have had a tech review at the start as it's a major release, which would imply there have been significant changes, even though (based on the project team advising CIS re-approval not required) it would appear there were no changes to arch.

Karen has arranged a meeting scheduled for 04 October 2011 15:30-16:30, BC4 B3 M2 Alan Partridge/dial in
Attendees: Karen Slavick; Tamsin Stubbs; Mark Gledhill; Siobain Collins; Mark Landeryou; Andrew Hutson; Ryan Adams; Robert Lee
I requested Karen also include: Yavor Atanasov (Frameworks as this is a PAL app); FM&T Service Managers; FM&T DD&O Change Management; Christopher Parker (DBA Team Lead), Stephen Hunwick

ACTIONS:
1. LOAD TESTING is currently RED - due to rate limiting issues
2. MONITORING is currently RED - this needs to be addressed
3. RUN BOOK - if it needs to be updated then this needs to be actions and a RBREVIEW ticket raised
Agreed in OTG Pipeline View meeting (Thursday 15th Dec 2011) that this could be moved to Production Under Warranty

item.description:

This commission is for a new version of the course which maps to current ITQ requirements. Potentially, a learner will be able to build up credits towards anm Award based on the modules in the course. The ITQ allows the learner to create a personal pathway of study which earns the learner an award, i.e. online accreditation.

Development by DESQ (Indie). DESQ PM Liz Wheat.

On 6th April Steve Yates provided the following tech update:

Hi Tom

Based on your feedback, Ive revamped the TAD based on Phils enquiries and responses as you requested. Though the core technology is similar, there are some major differences between the projects so I havent transferred all of the tech.

A few key points I want to make you aware of:

The existing Webwise system is storing all data, xml, templates, mp3s, Swfs, images on ExtDev in a single folder. I am assuming that you are expecting us to use the static/downloads for storage for the Webwise course. I dont know if there will be any implications on how the old systems works and whether it is desirable to have two parts of the website working in different ways. I dont have enough visibility or knowledge of the existing Webwise system to currently make a judgment on this. I am flagging this as an assumption on my part based on the limited information I have.

Items in orange are tech that we have been requested by the BBC to use but have not been supplied or havent been given access to. Hence the detail is limited.

As a gross generalisation, we are delivering the items in the central box whilst suggesting compliance to the BBC services in the surrounding boxes.

With respect to editorial references :

o The Assessment Access Control it is required that tutors can be given a username and password for the assessment site (this is a separate site working with the same technological base) and learners are given a daily password to access the site. The control of this is the responsibility of the BBC. The exact nature of this technology is still to be confirmed by the BBC.

o GAPI and BBC iD the specification requires that learners can log in using a BBC iD and have their progress saved. We have been suggested the GAPI to achieve this but are still waiting on authorisation to use it.

o The existing WebWise site and publishing system we have been informed that our development needs to integrate into the existing WebWise site and hence needs to be implemented using the existing PHP based XSLT publishing system. We are still waiting on access to this system.

o EMP the WebWise course contains 17 standalone animation videos that that will be played through the standard EMP.

o Flash elements

Profiling tool we are using a heavily modified version of the Quiz Profiling tool to deliver the assessment site and the quiz elements of the main WebWise course.

Interactive Swfs these contain the main body of the content of the course and are played through a purpose built Flash engine.

Progress bar Swfs these will report the users progress, if they are logged in with a BBC iD.

Shell Swf is a proposed invisible Swf embedded in the page to centralise and minimise traffic with the GAPI by managing page Swfs via Flash local connection.

Hope this is what you are looking for in terms of the TAD. Please let me know if you need further information.

Cheers

Steve

Technical Kick Off Meeting held Friday 8th April 10am-11am (BC4 B2 M1)

Attendees:

  • On site: Nick Kampa, Zoe Breen, Mark Elkins, Phil Logie, Paul Merry, Mark Gledhill, Tom Broughton, Siobain Collins
  • Off site from DESQ: Steve Yates, Liz Wheat, Phil Nichols (assisting as working on La Mappa Misteriosa)

PIPELINE NOTES
======
Steve Yates presented the Tech Architecture
Existing phase 1 is fairly static html, videos (some of them interactive)
This is the second phase. This will redevelop some of the existing content for the legacy online course. There will be four courses and four assessments. They will sit on Forge and be within editorial's new site's architecture. Videos will be uploaded through iBroadcast.
Architectural model is very similar to La Mappa (PIPELINE-393)
The Profiling tool PIPELINE-583 (being developed by Aerian) is a dependency for this (and for La Mappa) - now linked
This will use Games Grid and BBC ID
This will be for adults, the app is not intended for use by Under 18s.
Tom and Mark G were concerned with information about changes coming down the line to xml and iSite - PIPELINE-585 is already tracking this work so I haven't raised an action for Tom and Mark to investigate further

PIPELINE STEPS
==============
VOLUMETRICS: These are required for Load testing. Think of the 'user journeys', the number of people using this at a given time in terms of 'hits per second'. The volumetrics for the courses and assessment should be treated as distinct.
CTA/TXs: None are known at this time, but Mark and Zoe advised to ensure the Events Calendar is updated if these occur and the volumetrics are clear on whether the represent increases as a result of a promotion.
CIS: The diagram will need to be updated to show systems, networks, authentication
MONITORING: Will need to be built into the application for this application and dependent apps
RUNBOOK: Will need to be written or updated to advise 24x7 OPS how to respond to triggers flagged by monitoring

ACTIONS
========
1. EDITORIAL and PHIL L to update the Confluence space with the volumetrics and raise a Load Test ticket to discuss the Load Testing
2. PHIL L to ensure that - as an existing confluence space is being used which catered for Phase 1 - that all the information and diagrams pertaining to this phase are easily distinguishable. In addition please include a brief road map to show what went in Phase 1, what is being delivered as part of Phase 2, what is post phase 2 or out of scope
3. PHIL L to organise a discussion between DESQ and Monitoring, to determine the KPIs and Alerts
4. PHIL L to request Webwise as a tennant on Games Grid
5. PHIL L to advise BBC ID Webwise will use their service
6. MARK E to determine the requirements for the daily log. TOM and MARK G to review the requirements, propose a solution and advise if should be part of this delivery or can/should be de-coupled (and have it's own pipeline ticket)
7. DESQ and PHIL L to ensure the architecture diagram shows all the components that are part of this solution and it's clear (i.e. easy to distinguish) what components DESQ are delivering
8. PHIL L to book a meeting between DESQ, Tom and Editorial to decide how the solution will integrate with the publishing system

MEETING OUTCOME: Move to Development (Tom B confirmed this 12/04/2011)

Hi Phil,
I would like to arrange a Tech Kick Off. Please could you advise:

  • When you would like this/when will you be ready for this
  • Who needs to come
    Regards,
    Siobain

Hi Siobain, I will check with our producer, Nick West, for this project. Nick is on holiday today so we will
get back to you tomorrow, if that is OK?

What format do these usually take e.g. Conf. call, web cast, face-to-face meeting in London?

What sort of agenda can we expect? We would really like some tech guidance and advice on the structure of our current test site if possible?

FYI we are running another project on The Platform for the BBC Webwise team, it would be good to share any generic info with them as well as part of this process?

Thanks,

Phil Nichols
Senior Developer
DESQ
The Workstation
15 Paternoster Row, Sheffield, S1 2BX, UK
T: +44(0)114 221 0205
F: +44(0)114 221 0205
E: philnichols@desq.co.uk
W: www.desq.co.uk

Hi - thats absolutely fine.
The meeting usually takes place face to face here in White City. If, however, not everyone needed to input can make it to London we can have a conf call aswell.

Below is the usual agenda covered in a tech kick off...

  • Architectural set-up (current and proposed)
  • System and application set-up (current and proposed)
  • Data flows
  • Expected usage of services/applications
  • Volumetrics
  • Monitoring for Ops
  • Load Testing
  • CIS approval

Thanks.

Hi, that agenda looks great, these are exactly the sort of issues I would like cover.

Thanks.

I have booked the 'PIPELINE' Tech Kick Off for Wed 23rd Feb 11am-12noon. Phil Logie will attend as Tech PM to represent the project and we can call DESQ on the phone if they would like to listen in or if we have questions.

The objective of the Pipeline Kick Offs are to initiate the Pipeline process; see how the project design fits into the Forge arch; determine if there are any volumetric concerns or h/w reqs.

I have spoken with Phil (Logie) and he will arrange a separate meeting with DESQ and Jose to discuss the lower level detail, as those are more applicable to the project team.

Regards,
Siobain
Pipeline Manager
Karen Drake wrote (17/2/2011): I will be unable to attend this meeting as it clashes with another I will review the pipeline ticket to understand the Service Management requirement.

Pipeline Tech Kick Off Held: 23 Feb 11am (Blackadder)
Attended by: Phil Logie, Stephen Butler, James Burton, Mark Gledhill, Nick Kampa, Siobain Collins, Phil Nichols (on phone for part of mtg)

Notes:
OTAG - Not required
Load Testing & Monitoring - Phil L to raise tickets
Infosec - Phil L & DESQ to start putting info into Infosec template, then raise ticket
Volumetrics - To be documented in confluence space (Jose may have this info)
Runbook - DESQ to start working on
DESQ to contact Frameworks team re: Burlesque

Actions
1. Mark asked for clarification where SLL sits (Owner: Phil L & DESQ)
2. Mark advised XML issue needed to be resolved (Owner: Phil L & DESQ)
3. Nick asked who will support this post launch (Owner Phil L & Stephen)
4. Product owner to be identified (it was suggested that it could possibly be Dominik von Malais) (Owner Phil L & Stephen)

Meeting outcome: Move to 'Incubation' (pipeline terminology) for a week to allow discussions between DESQ and Frameworks team.

Further comments from the kick off from Mark Gledhill:

  • Flash application that retrieves overall game data from GamesGrid API
  • The project will use BBCiD to identify users and then stores user game state back into the GamesGrid API

A few questions arose from the high-level architecture overview:

  • There was some complexity and confusion about how different Flash components are going to be integrated the project team should resolve this and feed back on the proposed solution
  • Server side includes are not available on the platform so, in order to put a standard banner and links on all project pages, the project should talk to the Frameworks team to discuss the best approach for this, for example such as using http://www.live.bbc.co.uk/frameworks/bbcmodule/
  • Although the PAL project doesn't have a data store, the MVC framework should still be used for the View and Controller components for consistency in the PAL. There has been some prototyping already using straight PHP, although I strongly recommend the project talks to Frameworks in order to best understand how to use http://www.live.bbc.co.uk/frameworks/spectrum/
  • There is likely to be a subsequent phase (including migrate to own KV namespace) of the project, although that is out of scope for now and should be covered by a separate pipeline ticket.

I was concerned about the timescales (end of March) given that it is late February, development hasn't started yet and the project is being developed by an indie new to the platform. We explained the various mechanisms that assistance can be obtained (wiki, IRC, mailing lists, etc).

The project should remain in Incubation while the technical architecture diagrams are completed and while the project has further discussions with Frameworks.

Notes from Phil Nichols (Senior Developer, DESQ)

Hi Phil, thanks for the conference call yesterday, here are my summary notes with an update on our outstanding tech issues list.

BBC Tech kick off conf call summary:
Date: 23/02/11
Time: 11:30

Certificates:

Phil N confirmed that the DESQ team have correct certificates to access Confluence etc.

Review of tech architecture diagram:

BBC team confirmed that the supplied TAD diagram is what is required at this point.

Questions about aspects of the diagram:

BBC team asked what the XML files referenced on the diagram are. Phil N explained that these are assets for the Profiling Tool. They are currently stored on Extdev so that Languages team can update and add quiz content.

Phil N explained that these files will need to be moved to another suitable location before the site goes live.

Reference to SSIs. Phil N explained that these were to highlight the question of how to implement the common header elements of the site: masthead , sub nav etc. Phil L explained that these might best be placed using the Barlesque framework.

Action: Phil N to investigate further.

KV Store / GAPI:

Phil N explained GAPI model used and how we plan to amalgamate all of the data from the Profiling Tool quizzes from the 12 episode pages.

BBC team asked what the plan was for future KV storage. Phil N Explained that to his knowledge this would not be part of this delivery but would be part of a new implementation further down the line when the Languages team had developed their own API to the KV store.

The Platform / Pipeline:

Phil N asked if the proposed site structure seemed OK. Phil L said yes it was. Any specific questions about this should be raised via IRC with the Frameworks team.

Siobhan explained that we need to set up a run book for load testing.

Action: Phil N to investigate run book requirements further on Confluence. Should be minimal though as the Italian site is essentially a client side technology site.

General:

Phil L asked for an update on our tech issues list:

Action: Phil N to send on to Phil L see below.

Update for Phil Logie on tech issues (in red):

1. Profiling tool GAPI storage:

We are looking at amending the Profiling tool to store data within the same GAPI location as our progress data. We will need approval of the amends we propose making before doing the work see the email Nick West sent earlier.

Desq have provided Jos with requirements. Jos to contact internal BBC team / external agency to update profiling tool so that we can store data in one GAPI store.

We need definite approval for the GAPI store.

Awaiting formal approval.

2. GAPI storage size:

If we are storing our data and 12 profiling tool results we will need to check with the GAPI team that we have enough storage space we believe we only have 200 characters. We will not be storing much info, but if we multiply the information the profiling tool will store by 13 (to include our episode date also) then we might be hitting our limit?

Note that the 200 character limit was set before we know we had seen the profiling tool and knew that we had to store the data from that also (12 times).

FYI the Profiling tool GAPI JSON string looks like this for one profiling tool results set for an episode:

{"operation":"fetch","success":true,"value":{"dummy_b":"{\"b\":\"0.20\",\"b_r\":\"0.20\",\"b_w\":\"0.20\",\"b_l\":\"0.2\",\"b_s\":\"0.20\"}","dummy_pb":"{\"pb\":\"0.1\",\"pb_r\":\"0.1\",\"pb_w\":\"0.1\",\"pb_l\":\"0.1\",\"pb_s\":\"0.1\"}","dummy_i":"{\"i\":\"0.1\",\"i_r\":\"0.1\",\"i_w\":\"0.1\",\"i_l\":\"0.1\",\"i_s\":\"0.1\"}","dummy_a":"{\"a\":\"0.1\",\"a_r\":\"0.1\",\"a_w\":\"0.1\",\"a_l\":\"0.1\",\"a_s\":\"0.1\"}","dummy_last_level":"b"},"resources":[]}

This still might be an issue.

On Weds 9th March Phil Nichols (DESQ) wrote:

Hi Phil, I am just updating our tech architectural diagram after last week's discussion. I have a question relating to this and to a question I raised at the meeting.

We have a few SWFs embedded in various pages that rely on assets embedded within them.

The SWF files need to pull in external XML, MP3, JPG, PNG etc. files from various places in order to work.

We cannot host these assets locally to the HTML file they are in and will need to store them on an external server(s).

I have a proposition that should cover the ease of editing whilst keeping the cost of developing the resources down, and provide a config for moving the assets at a later date.

We would like to get this authorized before I add this to our technical diagram.

The plan would be to store all of the assets somewhere on http://www.bbc.co.uk. And store all of the assets in one directory and have sub directories relative to each other in this location. This would directly reflect the current assets structure we are using now.

See the attached image that illustrates our current structure.

We can then tell the SWF file that all the assets should be prepended with an absolute URL e.g:
http://www.bbc.co.uk/languages/italian/lamappamisteriosa/assets. This location will be stored in a config XML file that can be easily amended at a later date.

The structure of these assets needs to be very intuitive and easy to edit as we will not be populating the content, this will be done by BBC staff. Keeping all the files together means that the resources should be easy to navigate and edit for content editors.

We can set up initially on ExtDev for now and allow the editing here as we are doing for the Profiling tool and move the directory to the live URL and switch the URL later.

Would you be able to confirm that this scenario is OK as it does affect the way we build our resources.

This scenario very similar to the one currently employed by the Profiling Tool assets which will also need to be considered and hosting details / structure agreed.

Thanks,

Phil Nichols
Senior Developer
DESQ

Posting an email from Jose Deniz to Tom Broughton on asset storage proposal for La Mappa Misteriosa:

From: Jose Deniz jose.deniz@bbc.co.uk
Sent: 24 March 2011 12:41
To: Tom Broughton; Phil Nichols; Phil Logie; Tom Yandell
Cc: Nick West; Ryan Gibson; Steve Yates; Liz Wheat
Subject: RE: La Mappa Technical Architecture Diagram

From experience and despite exhaustive content testing, there's the potential for the occasional typo to slip through.

Having worked in print publishing this does happen no matter how thorough the checking. On the web, the sheer volume of files to manage gives the proofreading task encyclopaedic proportions, but we can also be more reactive and not have to wait until the next reprint.

With the old stack we got used to fixing this sort of thing on the fly as and when it was detected or reported.

In our case, addressing these promptly is paramount as it undermines our credibility. Whereas a typo on a /news or /food page, for example, is perceived as such by the user, in a language-learning resource it may make all the difference.

We could get used to waiting three days but with some nervousness. Maybe an exception can be made for Learning where tickets raised can be addressed more quickly?

Pre-live we also need lots of flexibility for content development. All our content is contained in xml files that we need constant access to, to preview and edit. In consultation with the TPM at the time, a decision was taken early on in the process not to use a CPS and to use extdev to host our xml files.

Finally, we're also used to rolling out in blocks of content rather than as a single build and the content production schedule has been put together with that in mind. For example, of the 12 episodes La Mappa is made up of, we'd like to consider the possibility of publishing in two blocks of six.

I hope this clarifies some of the queries.
