I'm happy for this to go from incubation into development as long as the following points (with regards to the tech arch) are addressed:

  • dynamite - you need to access this to get a playlist for the emp. Don't assume the url, the pid shouldn't change but the url could so get it from the ion feed attribute my_playlist_url. (I've explained this in an email)
  • Gapi - show this as PAL accessed via www.*.bbc.co.uk not datalayer unless your PAL app is accessing the GG web services (java layer) directly (which it shouldnt be as that layer is purely for the GG PAL app to access) - just need to clarify this.
  • show zxtms - I think you're using www.*.bbc.co.uk, downloads.bbc.co.uk and static.bbc.co.uk
  • Caching - I'm not sure what personalisation is within the presentation of the screen so this might not be applicable, also it might not be necessary depending on the actual volumetrics vs load of the pages but you could, if needed, implement the Varnish layer https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/cache/Varnish
  • highlight what specific components you are delivering in this build please? (I know we know but others might not...)
  • The diagram attached to be the one that's updated and put onto the wiki (the detail is better than the one currently on here: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/itlangdrama/Technical+design)
  • Profiling tool - we will have 1 profiling tool deployed to live for all use cases. This work will be carried out by the Profiling tool developers and requirements should be fed into that backlog. This will require separate pipeline, Phil Logie is managing this work.

Thanks,
Tom

Hi Stephen,

I'd expect it to peak at 30,000 UUs per week as a one-off. (And that's an ambitious target). I wouldn't expect it to peak at any single specific time.

It will go out on the Languages Newsletter first week of September. It will also be on the Food blog. Not sure what their traffic figures are.

We're also planning a launch event mid-October but these usually don't translate into any immediate increase in server load.

Thanks

Luke

Hi

Please can you confirm that following the launch La Mappa will be available to users on www.bbc.co.uk/languages/italian/lamappa

Do Seimens / Forge team take care of this - just want to make sure

thanks

Luke

This is looking like causing us to have to postpone Go Live until fixed. Have contacted EMP and FM&T 24/7

EMP team will carry out a fix today https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/EMP-1797?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:all-tabpanel ]

This should fix the EMP issues we have had

Possible Go Live date 5.9.11

Will confirm after today's meeting

Luke,
Please ensure the Event Mgmt Calendars are updated to include this launch, there is a link to the process from the Pipeline Checklist.
Rgds
Siobain

Hi Luke,

has this product now gone fully live following the deployment of OPS-41787 on the 6th September? Can you please confirm.

Regards

Stephen

item.title: [PIPELINE-381] Domesday (1986)
item.description:
Project description [1]: In 1986 the BBC published a survey of the whole of the UK in photographs and pictures submitted by a million volunteers. In 2011 the BBC published part of it online...

Editorial CTA: 5th May for Editorial to
TX: 12th May

comments.comment: Jira and Confluence space requested.
Added to Service Catalogue
Confluence space and Jira project created. Notification in JIRA-1562.

Hi, in an effort to resolve our TA proposal, we have put the following doc on confluence: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/Technical+Requirements+Overview

We would like to propose using a JAVA services layer, but need feedback about the viability of our proposals. Please can you advise the quickest route to getting going on this.

Hi,

Thanks for coming in earlier this week and talking through the proposal in greater detail. Ive taken some time to look through this in detail and also talk to the iSite and DBA teams.

I am happy with the project to further investigate using a Java Service layer and Database data layer. As data is core to the product, you want to search this data, you have a schema, you may want to expand on the data set and the schema over time, and youre not totally clear yet on usage patterns, it makes sense to have your own service in order to present this data via an API, and this gives you the freedom to evolve the product in the direction you chose.

There are existing products that serve predominately read-only data via a service, such as Food, and School League Tables, and so I recommend looking at these, particularly Food, to see how they do things. Also the DBAs are keen to understand what what kind of queries the project will be throwing at the databases, review more formal ER diagrams, help optimise queries, and would generally like to be involved early on.

Can I reiterate that Volumetrics are essential for DDO to understand the impact on the platform. This project has to remain in Incubation while the Volumetrics are being calculated, and while the initial discussions with the DBAs take place to understand the finer details and designs. Once Volumetrics have been provided, reviewed, and checked against the propose database architecture, the project could then move to the Development Pipeline phase.

Please do look through the following projects https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/food/Service+Layer and https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/schoollt/School+League+Tables to see how they approached things, and also get in contact with Chris Parker (Christopher.Parker@bbc.co.uk), the DBA Team Leader, to set up discussion about the database design and optimisation.

Cheers,

Mark

Tech review held Tue 8th Feb 2011.
Attended by:
Aerian: John Crickett (Devloper), Simon Neaves (Director)
BBC: James Burton, Phil Logie, Mark Gledhill, Neil Copeman, Siobain Collins

Actions:
1. Phil Logie: Determine the owner
2. James: Send Neil example volumetrics

Note: Schedule multiple load tests and early if Aerian build their own app
Watchers added.

Approximate volumetrics added to confluence page

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/Volumetrics

Search usage added to confluence page.
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/Search+usage

Just for info:

From: Mark Gledhill Sent: 25 February 2011 09:23

Hi,
As outlined below, Im now happy for https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/PIPELINE-381 to be moved into Development.
Mark

------ Forwarded Message
From: Mark Gledhill <mark.gledhill@bbc.co.uk>
Date: Fri, 25 Feb 2011 09:21:55 +0000
To: Christopher Parker <Christopher.Parker@bbc.co.uk>
Conversation: Domesday
Subject: Re: Domesday

Hi Chris,
Thanks for that, and great to see theyve been in touch and already receiving advice. If there are no obvious alarm bells, and I cant see any from that email exchange, then thats good and Im happy to let them go into the Development phase. I am impressed with this indie, especially at how proactive, organised and receptive to advice they are, so glad to see it is going okay.
Given their tight deadlines I think we should meet the project for a Pipeline tech review at some point just to check everything is going okay Ill get in touch with them to suggest that and sort that out, but theres no cause for concern so far.
Cheers,
Mark

On 25/02/2011 09:10, "Christopher Parker" <Christopher.Parker@bbc.co.uk> wrote:
Hi Mark,
Just been looking back through emails and Rajesh and John Crickett have been exchanging emails, Rajesh has reviewed the schema and made some recommendations on things to do/not do.
From that point, so far were happy with what we have, unless of course anything significant has changed then it may be worth have another quick review!
Thanks
Chris
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From: Mark Gledhill
Sent: 23 February 2011 12:01
To: Christopher Parker
Subject: Domesday

Hi Chris,
Just wondering if the indie Aerian has been in contact with you about their proposed database usage for the Domesday project? They are asking for a tomcat, which where effectively Platform Engineering says the project can formally begin development, hence am just keen to know if you have any major concerns, or can give a thumbs up, with what youve seen so far from them.
Mark
------ End of Forwarded Message

Following on from the initial Tech KO, I have been asked to arrange a Tech catch up. With the go live date in less than 3 weeks it would be good to ensure everything we discussed at the kik off is in place.

Please advise attendees and I'll book a meeting time.

Hi Siobain

The attendees to invite would be:

Paul Goodenough (indie: paolo@aerian.com)
Alex Mansfield (editorial)
Neil Copeman (Domesday PM)
Phil Logie (TPM)

Many thanks

Phil
Technical follow up meeting arranged for Fri 4th March 12pm
Phil Logie 03 March 2011 wrote: Domesday live date has changed, it will be going live in mid April TBC.
Please provide name of Product Owner who can be contacted post go live, with respect to this product.

Technical and Pipeline Catch Up Meeting held Mon 7th Mar 2011.
Attended by:
Aerian (White City): Simon Neaves (Director), Paul Goodenough
Aerian (on phone): John Crickett (Devloper via telephone),
BBC: Tom Broughton, Phil Logie, Mark Gledhill, James Burton, Siobain Collins

NOTES
Tom Broughton expressed concerns with the technical solution chosen. There were discussions around the reasons Aerian did not choose to use iSite - Aerian had consulted with iSite and were advised against this solution. Now we need to discuss the reasons for the chosen solution and Tom needs to decide if he is willing to sign it off and support it, or whether it needs a re-design.

ACTIONS
1. JOHN CRICKETT to forward mail to Tom Borughton and Phil Logie which breaks down the reasons for not going the iSite route
2. PHIL LOGIE to arrange a meeting on Tue for Tom to review the design with John Cricket. Mark Gledhill and Paul Goodenough should be an optional attendees
3. TOM BROUGHTON to provide an update out of this meeting as to whether he is happy to progress with current design or if it needs to be re-visited.
4. PHIL LOGIE to find out from Dominic/Camilla who the Product Owner is, possibly Alex Mansfield.

NEXT STEPS: Once Design/Approach has been signed off by Tom, the next steps would be...

AERIAN to
i. Assist Phil Logie in completing the 'Compliance Summary' & 'CIS Software Weakness Review' on Confluence https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/CIS
ii. Build Monitoring into the Product
iii. Write the Runbook

PHIL LOGIE to
i. Raise a CIS ticket for InfoSec to review information in https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/CIS
ii. Raise a LOAD TEST ticket for the Load Testing team to schedule this and write their scripts (volumetrics have already been uploaded by Aerian https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/Volumetrics)
iii. Raise an OPS ticket for Ops to review the Runbook
iv. Raise MON ticket for the Monitoring team to review monitoring requirements
v. When this is ready to Load Test...raise an OPS ticket to move the product from INT&TEST to STAGE
vi. When this is ready to promote to LIVE, i.e. after Load Testing and InfoSec have been signed off...raise an OPS ticket to move the product from STAGE to LIVE
Nina Bell advised 7 Mar: "Saul Nasse is the product owner at the moment and I assume he will continue to be after launch."

On Tues 8th March Phil Logie wrote:

All

We had a very useful tech catch up this morning for Domesday of which I have captured the following for your information:

Aerian java services layer could offer a possible interim solution with the aim of migrating the service onto iSite post launch;

Tom Broughton requires some additional digestion time for his technical analysis (half day) of the above, will feedback to this group by Weds PM;

Aerian to provide estimates today to Tom of when their current development will be available to view on INT;

Once available then Aerian to check the application into SubVersion ASAP to allow visibility to Tom Broughton on how the service will intergrate with PAL;

Tom Broughton to review his final analysis with Dominik Von Malaise and feedback to this team by Weds PM;

I will arrange a catch up session for technical members of this team tomorrow late afternoon and feedback the outcome of this meeting to the rest of the team soon afterwards.

Many thanks

Phil

Phil Logie
Technical Project Manager - BBC Learning

On Tues 8th March, Paul Goodenough (Aerian)wrote:

Hi all

This is FYI only for everyone but Neil and Alex.

We just had a really good meeting with Lucy, whos signed off on our designs and is happy for us to go ahead from a UX&D point of view.

We (at Aerian) have a few changes to make, which well be doing asap. Neil / Alex, can you guys provide PAUL, TRISTAN and MYSELF with:

1. A suitable image of the domesday machine for Empty dblock, 404 and 501 pages

2. Text, form fields, and associated information for:

a. Update this article

b. Update this photo

c. Contact us about this content

Thats it! If we can get these few bits of information, we can proceed and get this finalised and ready for styling in the next couple of days.

Full steam ahead everyone. Its been a tough day, but were coming out of it in a much better state than when we went in. Thanks for everyones hard work and perseverance.

All the best

Paul Goodenough

On Tues 8th March, Neil Copeman wrote:

Hi all,

Just one or two things to think about, after a chat today with Alex: The OS copyright featured above the map tiles on leaf pages. The copyright date should change with the map i.e. if you're on an 86 map then the text should read " Crown copyright and database rights 1986 Ordnance Survey 100039117" and for 2011 " Crown copyright and database rights 2011 Ordnance Survey 100039117" ->Is this possible?

This copyright info will be differ for the Channel Island & NI.

Phil - Do we know the full URL for the website? Will we have a redirect from bbc.co.uk/domesday? I believe this will sit under /hands on history/ or just history but need some clarification.

Best
N

Hi all,

Following on from yesterday's meeting, I provisionally booked a meeting for Wed 16Mar2011 11am (BC3 D5 M3). This can be treated as the Pipeline Technical Kick Off for the 'new approach'.

I have invited Mark Gledhill, James Burton, Tom Broughton, Phil Logie & cc Stephen Elson (iSite Product Mgr).

Please advise who Aerian attendees will be and if they will be on phone or on-site. If time or date needs to change please let me know.

Hi Siobain,

Our preference is to keep as much time available for development as possible, so unless anybody has objections it is preferable for us to conference the conversation. Could you include John and myself on a meeting request if it gets circulated.

Thanks.

No problem from my side you calling in.
john.crickett@aerian.com & simon@aerian.com addresses added to invite. Let me know if it doesn't come through.

Meeting for Pipeline Technical Review of New Approach held 23rd March 2011 12pm (Alan Partridge)
Attended by: Mark Gledhill, James Burton, Phil Logie, Siobain Collins, and on the phone John Crickett and Simon Neaves from Aaerian

________________________________________
Mark Gledhill's notes:

The Technical Architecture has not been signed off by Tom Broughton yet but is available on the wiki. I took an action to review this architecture. I also stressed that Tom needs to sign off the architecture as a whole, and not just the use of iSite, as there were other components that were discussed (for example such as using News Uploader for UGC, although it now appears that the use of this has been de-scoped).

The project said that they were planning to store 20GB of images on downloads.bbc.co.uk. I flagged that there is currently a project (CDS upgrade - Tim Varley and Fiona Batson are across this) to upgrade the capacity of the downloads server and that this is a dependency for Your Paintings (who want to upload 160GB). The project is already talking to Fiona Batson.

I flagged that the submission of UGC via email may bring up some InfoSec questions, particularly around the use, audit trail, managements of joiners/movers/leavers, etc, of a shared inbox. I took an action to supply an example of a previous CIS ticket that had been reviewed that used a shared inbox.

Action 1 - review Architecture

I looked at https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/download/attachments/29299589/Domesday+System+Architecture.png?version=1&modificationDate=1300878462167 and have the following points:
The UGC process should be added to this diagram to show which systems are being used and which user roles have what type of access
The diagram should include process of images being stored on downloads and then resized using ImageChef on static
Are any other services (such as iBroadcast) being used?
Please make it clear that the End User is using HTTP and the Content Editor is using HTTPS (if indeed this is the case)
Is the Content Editor a BBC person on Reith or will external access be required?
Are standard BBC frameworks such as Spectrum and Micro being used in the PAL?

Action 2 - example CIS ticket

Here is a good example of a ticket where it all went wrong and took some time to clear up and resolve - please read through this ticket, don't make the same mistakes, and supply appropriate information upfront - https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/CIS-212

I believe the project cannot proceed into the Development status in the Pipeline until Tom has confirmed he is happy with the overall architecture. Also I recommend the project talk to Fiona to understand timescales of the CDS project, the impact, and whether a temporary storage solution may be required to meet deadlines in the short term. Once these, and the above points, have been answered, we can re-review the status.

OTHER NOTES:

  • Raise tickets for Load Test and speak with Load Test to see if a provisional test is needed for week before launch (Royal Wedding week a lot of people may be off)
  • Runbook should be ready for review 20-25th April. Email Matt Dellowe when it's ready and he'll assign someone to review
  • As well as a monitoring ticket, ensure to build in the monitoring
  • Continue to discuss the CDS (Consolidated Download Server) upgrade with Fiona Batson. If it's a dependency for Load Test, then Fiona needs to know that date.
  • When Tom B signs off the architecture, ensure the document version number/version date is noted in the sign off (for audit trail)
  • Uploading data is out of scope. Instead data will be collected via a web form - Ensure you think about this, who see's this data, who has access to shared mailbox, how leavers/joiners are managed

From: Phil Logie
Sent: 23 March 2011 14:25
To: Tom Broughton

Hi Tom
Below are the minutes and action points for the Domesday tech kick off for the new approach. Can you please review and provide sign off status ASAP, I have been advised by Pipeline that a comment on the PIPELINE-381 will suffice for sign off purposes.
Regards
Phil

(Version 3. 23rd March 2011)

Phil,

Please update the tech arch diagram to answer Mark's points in Action 1.

I'm curious as to how the figure of 20Gb has come about as a requirements for downloads.bbc.co.uk as the attached email between yourself and Fiona states around 7Gb total space (although that's not including any new images).

It would be possible to package all OS maps into an rpm for static as these won't change and don't require editorial control. Editorially controlled images should go on downloads and optimised via imagechef. (please reflect this in the

Also, please provide the requested volumetrics for iSite usage i.e. adding new content along with expected file size of new images (and detail of how editorial will moderate, check validity of image and optimise pre posting to live). The volumetrics and time period of use for adding new content is currently a blocker on the use of isite for new (user sent in) content.

Thanks,
Tom

23 March 2011:
Fiona Batson raised the question whether the Domesday images should be going on downloads.bbc given there size.
Tim Varley and Craig Taylor (DD&O TDAs) looked at this and advised that the current options in re architecting downloads.bbc.co.uk will not fit this project's tiemlines.
Now, the Go Live date has moved to first week in May, so Tim and Craig are going to dicsuss again. If this is not possible they may need to discuss with Andre (SIS) to alternative assess options.

For anyone reviewing the architectural proposal, please see Tom Broughton comment (23 Mar) which indicates the limits may be lower.
As the CDS is almost at max, any reduction in the project's capacity requirements may may them easier to accomdoate.

Hi Siobain

The go-live is now confirmed as 5th May.

Regards

Phil

On Thursday 24th March, Phil Logie sent Aerian the following mail request:

Hi Guys

Siobain from Pipeline posted the minutes on jira yesterday, I thought it worthwhle sending in an email as a reminder of action points raised etc Tom Broughton has started to feedback today and has requested we update the tech arch diagram (point 1 below) with the UGC process, image storage on downloads, other services being used plus end user/content editor consideratons, external access and whether we are including using BBC framworks such as Spectrum and Micro in the PAL. If you could amend the diagram to reflect these I will then forward to Tom.

I believe once Tom reviews the amended TAD then he will be happy to sign off.

Regards

Phil

On Friday 25th March, Aerian provided the following response:

Phil,

I can amend the diagram to include Micro and image storage.

I'm not sure myself what the UGC process is beyond that fact that we have a form that sends an email, the email goes to ? who/which is ? and they do ? with it.

As far as I am aware the only editorial work for this Phase is the entering of the new dblock data that the BBC has commissioned especially for launch.

If you can flesh out any of the details I'll include them in a new diagram asap.

Regards, John

On Monday 28th March, Neil Copeman asked the following:

On 28/03/2011 12:27, Neil Copeman wrote:
Hi Phil, John,

Please could you confirm that emails sent to us via the form will be submitted using the POST method and transferred using HTTPS?

N

Neil Copeman
Multiplatform Producer
Domesday Reloaded
neil.copeman@bbc.co.uk
07818 446 290

On Monday 28th March, John Cricket provided the following, Phil Logie/John Cricket followed up with appropriate responses:

Neil,

Yes to POST.

HTTPS I'm not sure. Phil can you investigate that? Tom might be able to help?

Regards, John

On 28/03/2011 14:09, Phil Logie wrote:
Hi Guys

HTTPS should always be used when posting personal details etc HTTP is fine for capturing non-personal stuff ie annoymous postings via questionaire for example but in the case of Domesday we are capturing personal details so will need to use HTTPS.

regards

Phil

On 28/03/2011 14:51, John Crickett wrote:
Phil,

I agree, it should ideally be over HTTPS.

What I don't know and can't find any relevant documentation on confluence, is how we would implement that on Forge.

Perhaps Tom can offer some insight/point me towards some relevant documentaiton?

Thanks, John

On 28/03/2011 14:51, John Crickett wrote:

Phil,

Is this an absolute requirement?

If so...

Tom,

Hunting through confluence some more I've come across the Uploader Service which apparently offers us the required functionality:

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/uploader/Using+Uploader+Service+as+an+Email+Service

Any thoughts on using this? Is it acceptable, are we happy to introduce another dependency?

Regards, John

On 28/03/2011 15:25, Phil Logie wrote:

I was under the impression that we were unable to use an uploader tool of this kind. I believe it was the News Uploader tool that was discussed upon my arrival on the project, I am guessing the reasoning for not using that uploader tool is the same for this version?

Tom?

regards

Phil

On 29/03/2011 11:52, Phil Logie wrote:
Hi John

Can you please amend the TAD with Micro and image storage details and I will submit that to the Pipeline ticket and run this by Tom. I am still awaiting a reply from Tom on confirmation for the email form solution/uploader question and will revert back to you shortly.

regards

Phil

On 29/03/2011 12:01, John Cricket wrote:

Phil,

I'm updating it but I still need response from your end regarding (from the ticket):

The UGC process should be added to this diagram to show which systems are being used and which user roles have what type of access

Is the Content Editor a BBC person on Reith or will external access be required?

Regards, John

I have updated the TAD with the latest version (7, Apirl 2nd):

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/Technical+Architecture

Hi John,

Ok, I haven't seen the latest deliverables so am commenting on what I imagine is being delivered.

a couple of updates to diagram:

1. can you show imagechef being served via 'static' and not pal, and show other assets there too like css, mapping tiles (os) etc.
2. show the zxtm gateways (ie. www..bbc.co.uk. static..bbc.co.uk, admin..bbc.co.uk. api..bbc.co.uk, downloads.bbc.co.uk etc)
3. if you're using postcodes etc can you show the service you're using to convert to long-lat or northings-eastings etc.
4. ftp of images comes directly from editorial (not from Alfresco/isite UI).

I'm happy with email process being in separate diagram (probably activity diagram would be fine) and being supplied to CIS via weakness review.

can you send over to me what you are designing the architecture to (ie. spec)? that way I can ensure we haven't missed anything off and we can sign off this part.

Thanks,
Tom

Hi Aerian, Tom,

Apologies if I've missed this information in the communications, but (following on from my comment 23rd March) so as there is no ambiguity, please could you explicitly state:

1. The total size of the Domesday images
2. If the intention is for the Domesday images to go on downloads.bbc

Thank you in advance.
Siobain

Alex, Neil,

Please add your TXs or CTAs to the Event Calendar.

Regards,
Siobain

On Weds 13th April, Karen Slavick provided the following update:

Phil and I worked out a schedule for getting Domesday to live with all it's bits sorted.

You can track it here:

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/domesday/Milestone+Schedule

I'll take responsibility for organising and pushing things through on the BBC side, Phil will keep tabs on Aerian's work. We think we're actually in pretty ok shape, presuming that iSite gives the thumbs-up for the data.
Has the Runbook been sent to Matt Dellowe's team for review yet? If not please email Matt with this.

Hi Siobain

The runbook has been delayed due to the tight deadline for existing CTA's for launch of Domesday. We are almost in a position to confirm live launch on the 5th May, is the Forge process flexible in these circumstances? I imagine Aerian will complete this task prior to full launch on the 12th May.

Regards

Phil

Hi,

Much of the runbook is now complete, but we are aiming to redress this once we've hit our code freeze deadline on Tuesday. Feel free to have a pre-peek if you want, and highlight any areas of concern, otherwise we will review it early next week and get back to you.

OK?

Karen, Phil,

Monitoring requested you add your CTAs/TXs to your monitoring ticket.

Thanks and good luck for this evening.

Rgds
Siobain

Hi Siobain

Now added within the description of the Monitoring ticket.

Regards

item.title: [PIPELINE-341] Skillswise migration to iSite
item.description:
Project description [1]:

Skillswise website offers to tutors of adult basic skills classes a comprehensive and reliable source of curriculum support materials for teaching and learning literacy and numeracy. Currently on Old stack at: http://bbc.co.uk/skillswise.

The site provides a range of online and downloadable course materials that are heavily used by tutors (FE colleges, learning centres, in the workplace) and by learners at home. The learners are typically engaged in formal adult education courses in colleges or attending learning centres in workplaces and community centres. The site is currently the most popular BBC Learning site after Bitesize and has one of the highest net promoter and audience appreciation indices of any BBC site.

This project is to migrate and update the site onto the Forge platform.

Confluence space needed? yes
Jira project needed? yes
Confl/Jira shortcode [2]: skillswise
Conf/Jira administrators [3]: Simon Neaves (Aerian) , Tom Hicks (Aerian), Michael Rumbelow

comments.comment: Jira and confluence spaces requested.
KO to be booked.
Added to Service Catalogue.
Added Michael Rumbelow as a watcher to receive notification of being an admin for Jira project and Confluence space.

Hi Simon, Tom and Michael,

Your new project space is now ready:

https://jira.dev.bbc.co.uk/browse/SKILLSWISE
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/skillswise/Skillswise

You are a space/project administrators for this project.

The Confluence space has been added to the CLAS "team", visible here: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/dashboard.action?spacesSelectedTab=team

You can remove this "team" designation or create additional "teams", using Browse > Space Admin > Space labels > Team labels.

This application has been classified as "Forge" and will now appear on the appropriate 'product' page; see the Products drop-down on the black top nav.

As a Jira/Confluence admin you have the power to add/remove people from this project/space. Please read the FAQs:
Jira Admin: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/jira/Jira+FAQ
Confluence Space Admin: https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/confluence/Confluence+Space+Administrator+tasks

https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Confluence

We also have a mailing list for users of the Forge workflow tools (Confluence, Jira & Greenhopper).
We invite you to join if you haven't already done so:
https://lists.forge.bbc.co.uk/mailman/listinfo/workflow-tools

Any problems using the space, please let me know. Pipeline queries should still go to Tara or James. Note: even if you are not building your product on Forge, if your new application depends on Forge-built products such as Identity you should discuss your design with the Pipeline group to avoid delays at launch.

Kind regards,

DDO Docs Team

Tech kick off held on 31st January 2011. Attendees were:
Mark Gledhill, Manish Shah, Simon Neaves, Aerian reps and James Burton.

Mark Gledhill gave the following feedback:

  • Standard PAL + iSite application
  • Read-only, for adults only, no BBC iD, and low load
  • Want to redesign site and migrate data from old stack

The project raised the issue that a lot (thousands) of data objects will need to be migrated from the old system to iSite and that Editorial need the ability to preview content via the PAL application, but live data should only go into the live system and the release candidate PAL app will be complete well into the data migration.

I clarified the following:

  • Development systems cannot talk to production systems (both at the certificate and network level)
  • Any data stored on test should be regarded as not persistent (thus anyone wishing to retain data must take responsibility for the backup and restoration)

I made the following recommendations:

  • Make an early beta live release so that editorial can at least see something via a PAL app (the ProxyPass will point at the old stack site until live production release), and input into live iSite (preferred)
  • Input the data into iSite on test, and either the Skillswise team or iSite team take responsibility for the backup and restoration of data, and the migration of data to stage and live

I also made the following suggestions:

  • Have a clear data migration plan so it is clear what data is going to be on what environment and when
  • Make sure editorial are very clear what is going on, as losing the confidence of editorial, and thus having to win back their support, can be very time consuming

For a technical perspective Im happy for this project to proceed into development, although I would like to see the following at some point:

  • The technical architecture diagram updated to indicate which other BBC systems are being used (iSite)
  • A plan for how data is going to be input, backed up, restored, and migrated to live, and who is taking responsibility for each step
Updated version of System Architecture Diagram provided by Tom Hicks of Aerian.

For Phil Logie:
Monitoring ticket to be raised.
Runbook to be updated and reviewed.

Note: Development by Aerian (Indie)
Phil Logie advised, go live date moved to 14th April.

Updated Stage and Go Live dates based on draft OPS tickets for STAGE and LIVE.
Please note a 24hr window required between Stage and Ops releases is required.

Siobain,

Please note that the Loadtest ticket has been updated with regards to stage/live dates.

Regards
Tamsin.
The Go Live date on Forge is still achievable. However we will not activate the .htaccess file on old dtack site until 1st Sept - this is when users will see the new site and be re-directed to it.

item.title: [PIPELINE-330] Decommission old Space and History DBs and services
item.description:
Project description: Old databases and services for Space and history can be removed

To be added, description of what has been removed - Action Julian
Remaining functionality to remove is

  • old DBs
  • Services for Space and History

Decommissioning checklist

Task Comment Complete?
i. Ensure there is editorial buy-in on the concept of switching systems off. Julian to check with Ian Myatt and Chris Sizemore
ii. Ensure there is management buy-in on the concept of switching systems off. Per 1.
iii. Ensure all applications have defined lifespans, and inception plus decommissioning dates.    
iv. Ensure all applications have an entry in the service catalogue.    
v. Notice there is a cause to decommission.  
vi. Raise a Pipeline Decommissioning ticket.  
vii. Acknowledge the arrival of a request for decommissioning.  
viii. Technical Decommissioning Review meeting with all stakeholders including TPM, Pipeline, Monitoring, Operations, Information & Archives.    
ix. Consensus reached on fate of application and pages using the application - flattening pages, switching off monitoring, what about dependent systems, etc.    
x. Consensus reached on what response is served from an HTTP request. A 404 page? A holding page? N/A Space and History are now using K&L SDA
xi. Consensus reached on what users will see.    
xii. Technical Project Manager creates decommissioning plan and adds it to Pipeline decommissioning ticket.    
xiii. Technical Project Manager creates back out plan and adds it to Pipeline decommissioning ticket.    
xiv. Technical Project Manager performs discovery.    
xv. Technical Project Manager raises testing tickets.    
xvi. Testers test decommissioning plan on Forge Stable environment, or appropriate other environment (Ext Dev etc).    
xvii. Testers test back-out plan on Forge Stable environment, or appropriate other environment (Ext Dev etc).    
xviii. TPM sign off on testing, and back out of change process.    
xix. TPM raises an CIS ticket to action the decommissioning.    
xx. TPM raises a MONitoring ticket to shut down monitoring of the application.    
xxi. TPM raise an OPS ticket to action the decommissioning.    
xxii. Monitoring Team switch off monitoring for application. Suppress alerts.    
xxiii. Ops Engineers execute OPS ticket and decommission application.    
xxiii. If required, flatten pages.    
xxiv. If required, archive code.    
xxv. If required, Information and Archives rescue and archive historic documents and records.    
xxvi. 24 / 7 Operations check decommissioning hasn't broken other systems.    
xxvii. TPM and developers check decommissioning hasn't broken other systems.    
xxviii. If decommissioning FAILS, Ops Engineers execute back-out plan.    
xxix. Information & Archives archive relevant material.    
xxx. TPM Organise a post decommissioning (wash up) meeting.    
xxxi. TPM Update Service Catalogues as to current status of project.    
xxxii. TPM Raise a Jira ticket (Jira project) to archive documentation.    
xxxiii. Everyone attends the post decommissioning (wash up) meeting.    
xxxiv. TPM closes the PIPELINE decommissioning ticket.    
xxxv. Flagpoles - Chris Harrod to add note to checklist
item.summary: Decommission old Space and History DBs and services

item.title: [PIPELINE-132] Finder Binder
item.description: A service to support the saving of clips, recipes, web pages and other Knowledge content to against a BBC ID in order to create a User Binder for the Knowledge Finder product.

comments.comment: Jira and confluence space requested.
Added to Service Catalogue.

The tech kick-off for this project was held on 28th September 2010. Attendees were:
Tom Broughton (TA in N&K); Erik Upton (TPM in N&K); Andrew Robinson (SE in N&K); Philip Lamond (SE team lead for N&K); Mark Gledhill (Principal Engineer in DD&O); Tim Varley (TA in DD&O); Mark Robinson (PM team in DD&O); Tara O'Reilly (Delivery Manager in DD&O).

  • This project is a rebuild of a feature on the old Food site which had been decommissioned, but the users clamoured for it back. Thus this project will deliver a generic Binder service, it's first implementation of which will be a Food Recipe Binder. Using Food as the context the binder will save/view/delete recipes, search (auto-suggest) binder, simple rating, append notes to recipe, make binder public.
  • A full project timeline was not available but expectation is that this will be developed over next couple of months and go live before Christmas 2010. Developer availability for new feature dev on Food will dry up after this time, and appears to be the main driver of timeline.
  • The proposed technical solution looks like one to handle small-to-medium load with occasional peaks . It is likely to have fairly standard PAL/Service/MySQL/ActiveMQ/Tomcat setup. DB will need to handle GET, PUT, DELETE. Care should be taken to code for (future) volume.
  • Andrew R advised that caching and monitoring for this product should benefit from previous work done on the Food project by using extracted libraries created by Food. We would be interested to see how caching, state, etc, are going to be handled (RESTful URIs, etc).
  • We advised that the generic service be kept separate (in terms of code, documentation on Confluence, IS approvals, load testing, etc) from the Food product to make for easier reuse by other products at a later date.
  • As this Binder service is generic, it was recommended that care be taken to ensure that this is built to scale. And reminded that ownership still remains with this team to ensure that the product can handle the load for all usage going forwards.
  • This appears similir in nature to some of the OpenSocial work. [Action: Tom B to clarify what discussion has been had on this to date and document on the wiki the results of said discussions and why decision was made not to use elements of OpenSocial.]
  • Tara advised that the TPM followed closely the TPM checklist (at https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/TPM+Checklist) and the Pre-Release Checklist (at https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Pre-Release+Checklist) to ensure all aspects of the Pipeline is covered at the relevant stage of the project. This includes IS Approval, Monitoring, Event Management, Load Testing, etc.
  • [Action: Erik/Tom to look into estimated expected volumes and usage at all layers of the product and document on the confluence space. Ensure those volumentrics are exposed to the load test team and also fed back to the attendees at this meeting. We expressed concern that the application may suddenly be a lot more popular than expected (such as by News, homepage, etc).]
  • [Action: Tom/Andrew/Phil to provide technical architecture diagrams on their wiki and let us know when they are there.]
  • Note there may be a potential spike in usage if the conversations with Canvas are successful. There are some estimates extrapolated out for use to 2016.

Closing project due to change in direction of Knowledge strategy, the requirements from this proposed service's dependancies have been descoped and an alternative supported service will be used instead.
Ticket re-opened and back on the pipeline.

project reopened because SNeS bookmarks service coupled with the food api would be able to accommodate the (recipe) binder requirements but only for the desktop and mobile web versions... We also need to provide a service to external applications (mobile apps and YouView):

1. We need to supply developers of external applications with a single API.
2. External apps are going to need to use BBC iD in order to allow a user to store binder information and there's no interface for this.

It has become apparent from serveral investigations and meetings that we are going to need to provide a service that can accommodate these requirements. The service will interface, securely, with BBC iD, SNeS and the Food service (and possibly in the future any other BBC data stores/services) whilst being accessible externally without a certificate.

Tom,
Are there new dates for this now?

hi James,

Live: Feb 24th 2011
Thanks Tom - updated ticket.
Can we get this on the Pipeline View please James, ta!

Hi James,

live: March 17th 2011

3. Name of Indie - or mark as In House
Hi Karen. Did Finder Binder Go Live?
It did!

Hi Karen,
I'm moving this to Production Under Warranty.
The Runbook Review for this is outstanding, please could you action.
Rgds
Siobain

Siobain,
The run book is ready for review. here:
https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/binder/Binder+Service+run+book

However, I'm having trouble finding on the wiki exactly what kind of ticket needs to be raised to request run book review. It would be good to add that either https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/forge/Pre-Release+Checklist or https://confluence.dev.bbc.co.uk/display/archers/TPM+Checklist.

Hi Karen,

LOADTEST-261 appears to be for a refactor of this product's code (v2). Therefore, I think that you need to raise a new pipeline ticket for a new version of Finder Binder and link LOADTEST-261 to that pipeline ticket. Or does LOADTEST-261 refer to a patch release to the version that this ticket (PIPELINE-132) represents?

Thanks,
Tara.

None of the functionality has changed, the technical architecture has not changed, the CIS document is still accurate. As a "refactor," it was simply an effort to optimise class structures and add much more test converage.

Given all of that, is it truly necessary to treat this as a new pipeline item?

karen

For info, the approach is:

  • If a release is just BAU or bug fixes, then it doesn't need a new pipeline ticket
  • If a release has new functionality/new features it requires a pipeline ticket, although you could raise a 'New Feature' ticket rather than a 'Project' ticket, to reflect it's new changes to an existing product

If you raised a new pipeline ticket (i.e. deemed there were new features/functionality) then you can state in the ticket if there's no arch changes or volumetrics changes, in which case a tech review would not be required and likely new infosec would not be required and I'd move it to Development.
So it seems like, according to that criteria, this release of Binder would not need a new ticket, as it does not have new features or new functionality. Agreed?

Not agreed.

You state "effort to optimise class structures and add much more test converage". Whilst this is not changing outward functionality, you are changing code which can introduce risk.

In addition, your loadtest ticket indicates a v2.0 product (therefore not a BAU release). By definition, if you need a new load test then this is a strong indication that you would need a Pipeline ticket to represent that release.

You should raise a Pipeline ticket for the v2 release. Give a good description which would detail why you don't need a tech kick-off (reasons you stated above). Link any new work to that ticket (such as LOADTEST-261, etc) and any other existing tickets which still cover your new release (such as CIS-349 and/or CIS-307, etc).

You should then sail through when you go to deploy to Live.

Please note, New Feature Pipeline ticket has been created and linked.

-Karen

Agreed in DD&O Pipeline View meeting on 07/07/2011, that this product is stable on live and this ticket can be closed.

Project team to ensure they follow up any open linked tickets.

item.title: [PIPELINE-101] Radio Showmaker
item.description:
5 - 19 Learning wishes to develop a new audio editing tool - working title 'Radio Showmaker' - that is specifically designed for school children and which enables clip libraries of BBC audio content to be combined with audio provided by the user. The audio editor will be an online application - initially available from the new BBC School Radio website - allowing audio to be uploaded and retrieved from a secure streaming server. Access will be by log-in and users will only be able to access their own audio. There will be no sharing of audio user-to-user or access to audio uploaded by another user, except in the case of galleries posted by 5 - 19 Learning.

Brief description:

Schoolchildren edit audio using a Flash client
... which sends streamed audio to an externally-hosted server
This audio is retrieved to within the BBC's systems, transcoded to MP3, stored...
... and made available to the learner who made the audio originally.

comments.comment: Will get this set up for you.
Service catalogue item created.
Hi Paul. Please could you advise the status of this project?

The project has been scaled right back to enable launch. This is in part due to the unavailability of services on the platform that were needed to support the original proposition and audio encoding support for Flash recently released by Adobe that has negated the need for a streaming media server. The ID login has also been descoped entirely.

Radio Showmaker is now a simple Flash application that will launch in a standard Glow panel with a standard Javascript check, so the standard code on all pages is very straightforward.

We have started development of the client side code and the target release date is April 18th. I suggest we close this pipeline ticket, and if the editorial aspirations resurface post-launch, manage as a release of School Radio within the existing wiki space?

Would you recommend that we went through a round of load tested prior to launch?

Hi Paul

Apologies for not getting back to you sooner, the volumes going through the pipeline in March and early April meant somethings got overlooked.

I would suggest you maintain this ticket to show what you are delivering/have delivered. Whilst you mention it's 'a simple Flash app', that's sufficient for a pipeline ticket, a number of tickets recently have been to track delivery of flash app.s. #

1. Please could you update the descrption to reflect the content of the delivery.
2. Please could you advise of the current status of this work and go live date?
3. Please raise a LOADTEST ticket and ask the Load Test team if load testing should be run, this may be a simple yes/no
4. Has there been any monitoring added or updates to run books
